o0QXOBoVAiJeIQ6NHAnVBw.text: Absolutely amazing, authentic Punjabi food! Been there twice and both have been good experiences.

dWdTOBnJ_euc0h4pFQunXQ.text: Good place.  I was looking for an alternative to Masala Zone, who apparently thinks it's cool to water down their Butter Chicken, and found this on Yelp.  Good food, reasonable prices.  Tasted like ingredients were good.

OAPYxK7hrZPpawIZLBHGhQ.text: I went here while visiting London. Robert D. had recommended it as one of his favorite Indian restaraunts in the city. We got reservations, which was a great idea since we had a party of 5. As soon as we walked in the restaraunt, the wonderful smell of delicious food filled the room. We couldn't wait to get our food.We started out with the cheese nan, which was super yummy. We had to order more because it went so fast. I got the Kadu Sabhji which is pumpkin cooked in Punjabi style. It was super spicey, which I love. I think it was the best dish on the table. I tried everyone elses and I really liked the Sag, which is spinach cooked Punjabi style. Their were two chicken dishes ordered and I prefered the spicey one, though I don't remember the dish name. The lamb was probably my least favorite, although it was still quite good. Our wait staff was a lot of fun. The decor was interesting. The pillars in the room were covered in a wooden material that swept up and out over the ceiling as if it was a modern art tree. I wish I would have taken a pic. It was very cool. Anyway, this place has been in business for 60+ years and I can tell you that with the wonderful food that they serve their it will be in business for 60+ more. Thanks Robert for the great recommendation!

zs9rapDCkSlsow4QOYVjmg.text: Best I've had in London so far - much better than the slop on Brick Lane.  Stuck to the basics for the first trial run:  Chicken Tikka Masala, Aubergine, Chick Peas & Potatoes, Rice & Garlic Naan.  All spot on.  I could have gone a little spicier but none of those dishes were supposed to be anyways.  The table next to us ordered Prawn Tandoori which looked awesome too, definitely next time.  The service was also very good and the food came out quickly.  What I really liked about Punjab is that it does all the traditional dishes (so far, all very well), and isn't one of those ultra-trendy-annoying-wanna-be-night-club looking joints that seem to be so popular these days.  Just a proper Indian restaurant.  I thought the prices were reasonable too.  All of the main dishes were between 8-12 qiud and portions were appropriate.  Myself and my buddy ate here after work, both hungry and craving Indian food, and walked out stuffed for under 20 each.The only reason I didn't go 5 stars was because the BEST I've ever had was some random place near Munich airport.  I'm reserving my 5 start Indian rating for whichever curry shop can beat that one.  Maybe Punjab will after a few more tries.

FZOQLtewKKBh41Ln9zDhBA.text: Visited this place during my trip to UK.  I was touring around Covent Garden and my friend recommended me this place which was nearby, and I was really glad to be there.  After all day of of walking nothing feels better than sitting down comfortably and drinking chilled beer, accompanied by some tasty food.  We ordered curry lamb kebab and chicken curry and sauteed okra with nan and rice.  Solid taste and friendly services.

rJ3VwCrSFBnkJKOqXj5DcQ.text: This place is amazing!  After having dinner here, my sister and I came back the next night, then I came back two days later by myself.  Everything we ordered was phenomenal.  I remember something with pumpkin I especially liked... pumpkin naan perhaps?  The ingredients were fresh, the meat was cooked perfectly, nothing was bland or too spicy... absolute perfection.  I've only had Indian food in the states once, and I will never be able to again because I will always compare it to this place, and it will never measure up.  I need to make a trip back to London soon!

LTx60ea2pf9eZ5Y_FND03Q.text: Good Northern Indian/Pakistani restaurant.  You're going here for the location, so given that there are far worse choices in Covent Garden.  The plates tend to be rather small, so order more than you normally would as you'll get half the portion you might be expecting.  I suppose that's better though since it's more healthy to eat less.

qMAzd9JJGvEWisaCgK_gMg.text: Excellent Indian food. Good, efficient service by knowledgeable people. Ambience nothing special but pleasant enough. Well worth going back to for the quality of food. Cheerful, unsophisticated.

XZOAXM8TNxaXAPj2HPf1Dw.text: The menu was so bold about its claims to excellence in the daal that I couldn't pass it up. They were right: the best I've ever had. Also good: pumpkin curry and breads (roti, chapati). Friendly service.

Fo29QQbNd2qwkcgEvYzaYg.text: Well, this is one of the places which actually make real Indian food. Been there couple of times. Interiors are quiete modest. Great things to try are the kebabs in starters, and mango-lassi. For main course, try ANY chicken dish, they just make it great. Closest you can get to an Indian taste !!

zksL-p2gkvbYjZpa89p2VA.text: I am extremely disappointed with the attitude of this restaurants' staff. The way we were treated last saturday was appalling and I would never recommend this resataurant to anyone ever again. I have been to this restaurant twice and my husband's been there atleast 10 times. We were under the impression that this is a good establishment until this saturday when we were asked not to even come into the restaurant as our toddler was shouting while we were at the door. The guy told us at the door that we cannot go in as our toodler was making a lot of noise and that we would be disturbing all other diners. He didnt even check if we could calm him down (the screaming lasted 30 seconds only and was because he was hungry, if we were given a table and he was fed he would have been content and quite!). He was very rude and spoke to us in hindi as we are indians too and he ASSUMED that we would understand the language! what audacity!! Why would he do that? It was not like we were there at dinner time when people would not welcome a screaming child next to their table, we were there to celebrate our 10th wedding anniversary on a saturday at lunchtime!! I saw from the previous reviews that another Indian gentleman was asked to leave as his order was less than 15 £, it makes me think that this kind of callous attitude from the staff is reserved for Indians only!! Also why he would not speak to us in english, but shooed us off by speaking in Hindi. We used to have a good regard for this place but now we will never recommend this place to anyone as they are completelly intolerant of having children dine at their establishment and the attitude of the staff is despicable. NEVER AGAIN.

sopG967fJKws7yGC5scUiw.text: By far and away my favourite 'Indian' restaurant in central London; the best Punjabi food I've eaten which hasn't been home-cooked. Just thinking of the menu makes my mouth water  it's all good. By their condiments (especially the lime pickle) shall ye know them, and if you have a couple of papadums while you consider the menu you'll see that everything here is fresh and just as it should be. I have a particular fondness for the acharri gosht myself. This would be a good place to bring someone who says they don't like Indian food (which is a bit like saying that they don't like 'European food', there's such diversity). If they remain unconvinced then they're just contrary.

1Zj1UIxOdpTqQrQirWvdjg.text: A true gem among so many wonderful places for curry in London. Yes, it is in a location that attracts tourists but be discouraged by that. It is truly delicious Northern Indian cuisine.  I love the Jalfrezi and Punjabi Samosa. Chana Masala is amazing as well. Delicious -- fresh and so nicely balanced that it is fun to try to discern the individual spices even though it all blends so well.I've been going for many years and the staff are always the same and that says so much. Everyone is kind and the service is amazing. A long time family business. The owner seems always to be there and making sure the service and food are perfect. And it is.

t8PwnrdZaFNbxD2_6ET9Jw.text: excellent food, impeccable service & the atmosphere was great. fresh ingredients, wonderful masala chai tea and mango ice cream to finish the meal. we're here in town one more day and we'll be coming back again tomorrow

jzffIsF5i6wq2qhCe-7LZg.text: Fantastic Indian cuisine, with excellent range of appetizers, entrees, and desserts. Can get rather busy, but it's a local treasure and well worth the wait. 10/10 for an all around great find, in a charming city.

IaRV-90iMNQlD3h1zKT08Q.text: Really delicious meal from start to finish!! Generous portions. Vegan and gluten free options available. Ask for an allergy menu if you have dietary requirements.

opnHzo1wC__uYSelZr87rA.text: Taste: 3Creativity/Authenticity: 3Atmosphere: 3.5Service: 2Bang for your buck: 3Let me start by saying when in London which claims to have the best indian food your not gonna find it here. I'm free Los Angeles and we'll punjab is about the same as LA; Los Angeles might be better!! First our waiter was very rude, service Def needs work. As far as the food goes nothing special the condiments tasted like pre package jar sauces, their chicken masala just another indian dish nothing that a place that claims to be the first indian restaurant in London should taste like. If you want indian food you can probally find another place that has just as good food if not better i suggest for the price of punjab you go eat at dishoom way better service, better food but make a reservation. Good luck

eMjp2RM4fDY-Q5PSRkKgvQ.text: Food: incredible. You really do need to add this to your London to-do list if only here for a few days. Came with my parents, international Indian fans and they were very impressed. But not with the service! We spent probably an hour here and it took us 20 minutes to eat. The other 40 was twenty waiting for a beer out of a bottle (I mention this because I can open a beer bottle in 10 seconds flat!) (they brought beer WITH food) and twenty waiting on the check. Then verbally suggested a 20% tip. Not too classy. But the food!!! Lamb and chicken cooked to PERFECTION!

pHrxoCF3H700V8e-2b0kDg.text: Tried three Indian restaurants on our 8 day vacation to London and we all really enjoyed this restaurant the most.  Good food, good service, good location.

T4JVW9IRSmOpf1VYthWuPA.text: Tried their house specialty chicken , the stew lacked depth in flavor that Indian cuisine is famous for. The base was pretty much tomatoes with chili powder. I was expecting to taste aromas of roasted seeds layered with other species . And the chicken kabob was surprisingly bland! It came in a flaming hot skillet drizzled with a believe some kind of alcohol. delicious was mango lasi drink.  service was very niceMust try curry chicken & butter chicken! Delicious !

l-j7LZ-nYz61y8fglffA8A.text: I definitely agree with others - don't wait for Dishoom.  Come here and you can eat very well.  We actually wanted something more home style and lighter than the creamy sauces you'd find at typical Indian restaurants.  We asked for the dishes to be prepared with as little oil as possible, but maximum flavor (spices, etc.) and they delivered!  The food was delicious, vibrantly spiced, and not too heavy.

Wg1J4s9hhqXel51k4q7QUg.text: Good food, decent service and ambiance. We stumbled upon Punjab during a recent visit to London. We were on the hunt for Indian food, saw a line out the door and figured it would be an hour wait. Don't be deterred by the line outside, it moves very quickly and we were seated within 15 minutes. However the first thing we were told before we sat down was that we had to be out by 8 o'clock, which was about an hour-and-a-half away. That was fine, but a little strange we were being rushed before we had even ordered. The atmosphere was also very basic inside, it's definitely more on the casual side. We decided to order  a good variety of starters and main plates because we quite enjoy Indian cuisine. We ordered Samosas and papadom with mango chutney to start. The chutney was delicious. We then followed that with chicken tikka masala, vegetable curry, chicken korma and peshwari naan bread. The portions were decently sized, not overwhelmingly big. The food was all good and the naan bread was fantastic. My only issue with Punjab was that we felt rushed the whole time we were there. It felt like they were just waiting to take our plates away and hurry us along so they could seat the next group of people. I noticed they did that with all of the tables in the restaurant, which took away from the experience as a whole. Overall this was a good restaurant.

96PMEyehzXHz-h311ty_Sw.text: This restaurant deserves to have been in business for as long as it has been. With so many restaurants to choose from in London, Punjab consistently offers delicious food, quality ingredients and friendly staff. Locals know about it and hopefully tourists get to appreciate this much-loved restaurant.

-VLrSrgmuHW7dg29gP48rw.text: We originally wanted to go to Dishoom, but being closed for construction we quickly searched up another place and found here. I'm so glad we found it! There was barely any wait and we were seated quickly. The servers were helpful and friendly. The food here is great. The only disappointment I had was not being able to try the dish that lit up on fire. Which every other table seemed to have got instead.. This was one of the best and cheapest places we ate in London on our trip.

9yey22H6UhO7y3XUidI87w.text: Probably the best Indian food in Central London. Curries are very good and prepared fresh. Things to try:- Daal Tarka- Paneer Makhani- chana masalaChapati felt like home made.Drinks: mango lassi had good flavor.

iDc9Ro7454u6_L5XbekzSQ.text: Service and ambiance are nice. We arrived when they first opened and the restaurant had an overwhelmingly strong scent of cleaning solution. Not sure if it always smells like that.We liked everything we tried and the spices in the dishes really stood out in comparison to some of the other places we have tried. The dishes also had a nice smoky flavor.CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA £9.50 No standard recipe exists for this classic dish, however our 1973 formula continues to withstand the test of time, Chicken Tikka served in tandoori masala & tomato based sauceBUTTER CHICKEN £9.75 The godfather of all punjabi dishes, succulent chicken on the bone served in a creamyBUTTER NAAN £2.35 Simple but sumptuous flatbread expertly baked against the walls of the tandoor

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

couwfxsZUxgAhZy2vPGhqA.text: Came here for dinner. Had the samosas, garlic naan, butter chicken, chicken tikka masala and cumin rice. Everything was delicious and flavorful except the butter chicken. The butter chicken was a little pink by the bone. There was no wait. Staff was attentive and nice. Service was quick. Would definitely recommend this place!

HZjDeJH6ENKKOVCy3HhjOg.text: Nice location for this wonderful Indian eatery, there is not much room so its a bit of a shuffle game dealing with the space. We had a reservation and they were very friendly and accommodating. Some of our party was late for a reservation and they adjusted for us. The food was quite good, this is a northern indian place with reasonable prices.

tb5XdjblIJtVKq6gF9phdQ.text: My family and I visited this restaurant while on vacation to London last week. It's an easy walk from Tottenham Court Road tube station and was easy to find. Once seated we checked out their menu and settled on a few dishes for us to share. We ordered the Punjabi Samosa, Acharri Murgha, Tarka Daal, and Methi Gosht to name a few and the meal was delicious. We ordered a mixture of chicken, vegetarian, and lamb dishes. All the dishes had their own unique flavor, spice, and aroma. The staff were all attentive and saw to our every need. We all agreed that we would recommend this restaurant to anyone who was looking to have a great Indian meal while in London.

ojU1BUVBR66rhP4jBSOkMA.text: Came here with my boyfriend when we were visiting London, we both loved it. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala with naan and aloo gobi, everything was fresh. I wish they opened up a restaurant in the states!

lvxLSq-oOhN1GHpuww_BUQ.text: This is a London institution and behaves as such. Waiters are plentiful and efficient, some friendly others appeared stressed. Bottles of beer and pints of lager abound as do young Americans.  Food is fine, portion sizes not too big.

v8qRVR1-nOMa24WBMvgvVA.text: Today was my third meal here. I've enjoyed each one. Amidst the hustle of Covent Garden, this little place would be easy to overlook. Please don't.  Just about everything here has been consistently good, and everyone I've eaten here with has loved it. Despite a minor mix up today with my food being delivered to the adjacent table, service is good if a tiny bit unhurried, and food quality is excellent. A few highlights:Onion pakora - little fritters of gram flour (believe it's chickpea flour) mixed with onions and spice and fried to a delicious crunchHariyali chicken - mentioned by at least one other reviewer, it's a bit showy when it comes sizzling to your table, and it tastes great. Skewered chicken coated in yogurt, coriander, mint, garlic, ginger and chile and cooked in the tandoor. This is my favorite! No sauce, FYI, but some grilled onions underneath are greatBullet naan - naan with garlic and green chiles - not overpoweringly flavored, but really nice alongside the other dishes - I liked the little bit of extra spice this added to my mealOne I won't order again- the mixed vegetable curry - I should've inquired more about this one, as it just wasn't "green" enough for me, having lots of potatoes, carrots, and peas in it. Oh well, I'll stick with my okra or saag dishes next timeDo check this little place out. They take Amex, too, for those who care.

1Tc9a5n6N58hc32-HpJMCA.text: This is the best restaurant in London! After several disappointing meals, we came upon this treasure of a restaurant! The food is delicious and flavorful, as well as fresh. The food is clearly made freshly with real spices and lots of care. The mango-lassi was delicious and complemented the bullet-naan and the curries we ordered perfectly. The service is also fabulous. The service is prompt and everybody is incredibly friendly. Our server, Sudarsham, was caring and super friendly, asking us about our trip and our experiences with the restaurant! The manager, Amrit, also was incredibly friendly and invested in our experience. Amrit gave us theater suggestions and tips on the what times were best to go to the restaurant. We went for our second time this evening and are already planning our third trip back to the restaurant (in the same week). We read rave reviews about this restaurant on yelp and could't help adding to them.

sOHDWPmtCWEIKcvvbpq_uQ.text: Terrible experience. Seekh kebab overcooked and dry. Malai tikka had little flavor. As did the Kali Daal. Nothing even close to authentic punjab food. Stay away.

MWq8JD0umP_u6ig-Kj9Fsg.text: Delicious!!!! Service was not great which is why I'm giving it 4 stars, but everything I ate was super tasty!

3JERFsyJS5USRSsauqZVsg.text: The Butter Chicken was absolutely delicious. Many places make it too sweet; instead, it had a complex flavor combined with a sublime buttery texture. I asked to have it spicy, and I was not disappointed! Next time I'm London, I'll be coming here again.

YpnRBHncw0fdJrKfekboIA.text: Solid 4 to 5 star food, I definitely liked this place and it may have been the best Indian food I had in London. A bit touristy due to its location, but this is a great place to eat.

N1P8n1glGER53rSuIbOwKg.text: baigan ka bharta + gobi aloo !!! ttastyyums

IUwNd4BkSEQgr33d48JiaQ.text: Fun and friendly staff, bustling spot, yummy flavorful dishes, reasonable prices, fast service (generally), and happy customers!  The naan with a little flatter than we were used to but still fresh and tasty - especially the garlic naan.  FYI: Had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table for two at 8p on a Thursday.

YMVLSj-Fwzh8hGNUyWEEzA.text: London is full of Indian food, this one is ahead of the pack!

cSy8uL-FQU7AFPmqWGBN2g.text: This place serves authentic food. Had the Chicken Tikka Masala and Chicken Madras curries and both were amazing. Cheese Naan very tasty and service pretty decent. Worth a visit.

J_yS1vAnccDUHr9SEYG0fA.text: I had heard that London had some of THE best Indian food outside of India.  Living near Little India in Artesia, California there's a lot of good ass Indian food, so I had to compare the Indian food in London.  Punjab seemed like a good candidate.  After getting lost a few times with the damn directions on the Yelp iPhone app, we finally found it.  It's near Covent Garden and Picadilly Circus, but we kept getting turned around.  Punjab is a very nice, classy restaurant. The wait staff were friendly and quick.  There were a lot of people eating there too.  Good mixed crowd and even some customers of Indian decent were eating there, so it looked promising.  Nothing on the menu really jumped out at us, so we ordered spinach paneer, rice, and garlic naan.  The food was not bad, but nothing to knock my socks off.  It was pricey too.  Sorry, but I've had better Indian food in Artesia and at more affordable prices.  Maybe next time I have to try an Indian restaurant in London that is a off the beaten path and not near the touristy part of town.  I would've thought they had a Little India section in London too, but either it doesn't exist or I couldn't find it.

m0JMGWJnxm7UsFMCzsGhKA.text: Punjab is one of my favourites in London. The place can accommodate larger parties and is nice enough for me to take business acquaintances to. Service is exceptional. The average curry dish is about 8-9 quids, which is a fine range for restaurants in the Covent Garden area and reasonable for the quality of the food. The curries are flavorful, though it is not the very saucy kind, in case you are someone who enjoys the curry sauce more than the meats in the curry. The tandoori dishes are fantastic; very juicy. Generally, Punjab does exceptional meats, whether grilled or in curry--very tender and juicy. Try the mixed grill for sure! For folks who want cheaper curry and the super saucy kind in a smaller place, you might consider Tiger Spice.

aQR-5LvVN3D2tz_8oWHYhQ.text: I was pretty disappointed with this place. I rarely get back to the UK these days having moved overseas and one of the things I really miss is good Indian food. Everytime I come back I look forward to having a good tikka masala, but I was sorely let down by Punjab. It looked the real deal, cramped tables, classic menu, everything seemed ok on the surface. The food though was meh. The naan was overcooked and crispy, the chicken was likewise overdone and dry, even the masala sauce was lacking in tomatoes or spice. There is far better to be had in London.

P5FR_RVxbPraNHR18r1tIQ.text: Five of us ate here--luckily we got a table without reservations on a Friday evening.  The staff was friendly and helped us order.  I had Chicken Tikka Masala since I don't like real spicy and it was wonderful.  My son ordered Chicken Madras and wait staff asked twice if he was sure, since it is very hot.  He liked it.  Others also enjoyed their food.  Plain Naan and Garlic Naan also very good.  Not cheap but no where in London is.  Staff was very attentive.   We will go back if we are lucky enough to return to London.

mG-rpueqPVYiH83dEzOfuA.text: I am doubting my fellow Yelpers after seeing this has a 4-star average rating.  Landed in London today, am put up in a nearby hotel for work and was craving some chicken tikka masala.The naan was inedible, the chicken was dry, and the tikka masala lacked spice/flavor.  Rarely do I leave food on my plate (I have a problem of eating everything in sight!), but I didn't finish anything I ordered.  Will continue my quest to get good Indian in London elsewhere...if you're on the fence about coming here, I'd pass.

OHHpU1KNdQbhZRez5C3Ecg.text: Ordered:Chicken Tikka Masala - Unfortunately have had better Chicken Tikka Masala in San Francisco, Malaysia AND Sweden which is a sad statement since Chicken Tikka Masala originated from the UK...and most food in Sweden is lacklustre.The chicken was VERY TENDER, which I did think saved the dish from the lack of seasoning and spice.Rice - The plain basmati rice was perfectly cooked, but was missing some basic spices that are normally added to even plain basmati rice.Had to pay for rice which I thought was odd, but I guess that is the norm in the UK.Butter Naan - Was very small in size and was VERY thin so it was completely crispy like a cracker which was a shame.  It was almost impossible to use the naan for dipping in sauce or using to eat the food on my plate.I don't know if I will go back or recommend to others for the price.16+ GBP for the above items.  I ate all the food but didn't get full, so beware if you have a big appetite you may need to order a 2nd dish or several naan.The staff however was very nice, helpful and attentive.  One waiter saw that I was about finished with my rice and naan and politely asked me if I would like more.  But at 3.50p an order I declined.

AaTLB1ay6yeq_zPgzj62Nw.text: The Punjab is a busy North Indian restaurant near Covent Garden. I called for lunch with a colleague. Despite being fairly quiet the initial service was a bit slow, but the staff seemed friendly and helpful. I went with one of their speciality dishes: Acharri Gosht a pickle-styled lamb curry, tangy & irresistible medium spiced dish served with Naan bread which was very flavoursome and at £9.80 for the curry and £2.35 for the naan reasonable pricing for central London. I'll be back! Recommended.

PzwTJ8eWYFUGyjT_A3_98Q.text: Wow, I can't believe that I find myself so at odds with other Yelp!ers who have raved about the food at Punjab. I thought it was just OK, nothing special. The restaurant itself is a delight, comfortable and welcoming with loads of character and the service was impeccable. However the food, which was the main reason I was there, was good, but not great.Best of the dishes was the Pudina Gossht, Lamb marinated in fresh mint cooked with herbs and spices and green peppers. The lamb was succulent and the spicing delicate it was good but not historic. However, the Methi Murgha, chicken with cooked fresh fenugreek, was bland, the pillau had a dirty flavor to it that matched its grayish colour and the bhindi masala was unremarkable.Great atmosphere, whether you're dating or doing business, but there is much better Punjabi food to be had. Maybe dinner is better than lunch for some reason but I won't be going back to find out.

XSmlpUxPWsdc596kmXwqXA.text: Great Find!We were in London and wanted Indian for dinner since many people have told me that Indian food in London was very good..I asked the desk clerk at our hotel if he could recommend a good Indian restaurant in the area..It probably helped that he was Indian, and he enthusiatically suggested to go to Punjab. It was about a 5 minute walk and we were immediately welcomed by a friendly staff and warm atmosphere. Food was delicious..Got samosoas for appetizer and the lamb madras with rice and nan on side. I like spicy and the when I ordered the entree the waiter made sure to check if I like spicy food..The lamb was very spicy and very good!We def will go back next time in London...

ovuxn7ZGabqDamd7nwMc4g.text: My fella and I are regulars here and always get a huge welcome when we turn up :) this place is run by an extremely friendly bunch of guys who've been with the business for donkey's years. They have a near magical knack of seating groups of people even when the restaurant looks entirely full, and make really great Indian food. As a veggie, my favourite dishes here are the 'pumpkinettes' (on the menu it assures diners that 'Punjabis go crazy for these miniatures pumpkins'), the special kali daal and the aubergine dishes. The bread is also superb - much lighter and crispier than naan at your average curry house. A great place where I'm sure I'll be coming back for many years!

wsNRsTYz3oTGjo3NOBt8LQ.text: The best Indian in Covent Garden, serving everything you expect from an Indian. Could be the best Indian in London, but I haven't been to them all. (Yet). The restaurant always has a queue outside it, so either book or be prepared to wait for yummy Indian food.

Mg9Ada7wVUUMg20i-VeGFg.text: You're in London.  You have to get Indian food.  I don't really think it's an option.I saw this restaurant on one of those shows on Travel Channel or it was on Food Network or something but I had it bookmarked.It's in Covent Gardens so expect it to be pricey for sure.I did not have a reservation but I was by myself and I was there relatively early for a Saturday night so I figured I would chance it and just walk over to the restaurant after going to Laduree to pick up macaroons for my trip home.I was seated upstairs at a table.  The servers were nice and attentive.  The food gets delivered via dumbwaiter up and down the stairs for the most part.I order butter chicken, garlic naan and some rice.  It was the perfect amount of food but man was it expensive.  It was basically one airline breast of chicken and one piece of naan with a plate of rice and it was over 40 GBP.  Was it good food?  YES.  It was really good.  I would imagine if I was there with a group of people and we order a bunch of things we could share, but I have to question how would you share one piece of chicken?Overall, I'll definitely be back again if given the chance since it was really good, but it would probably depend on what else i spent money on during that trip

nkMxQOTjfLJVKktGwlj2iQ.text: Good food , good service Slightly overpriced for what it is but an enjoyable experience overall!

WMYhEVGWnLFkOEl2tjvvJw.text: No complaints! Arrived around 8 pm and was seated in a few minutes. The food is delicious and spicy! Portions are a good, filling size. Would highly recommend.

Fy0r9rNELPj1nKplgkikyw.text: Great Indian food in London -  kids liked it, great flavors - super casual and busy but not overly so.

YcF9ieFWrmRwicCGIEOgqQ.text: We absolutely loved our experience at Punjab. I have a wheat/gluten allergy and they were very attentive to ensuring no wheat exposure. The food was delicious (we had a chicken curry and a lamb dish). The service was stellar--we were welcomed warmly and had the opportunity to speak briefly with the owner as we were leaving. I'd highly recommend Punjab if you're in London.

R6BOKIS76d9-gUNmKCpINw.text: Found this place on Yelp and decided to go in for lunch with my mother who said she does not like Indian Food. I told her give it a chance. I ordered for her. We had Cobra Beer to drink and Paneer Pakora to start (the sauce with the paneer was great!) For our mains we had Chicken Tikka Masala and Pudina Gosht (lamb). The mildness of the Tikka Masala with the spicy Pudina Gosht was great complements to one another. The meat in both dishes was tender and the seasonings were spot on. To go with our mains we had Pilau Rice and Garlic Naan. Both were excellent. If we weren't so full we would have ordered more!The only thing I can say is the service is a bit brusk on cheeriness but fast response times and there wasn't much of a wait between ordering and receiving food.We came in around 2pm on a Thursday and one side was full. By the time we started eating our side had every table occupied as well. The decor of the restaurant is also great with old photographs decorating the walls.Can't wait to return on my next visit to London!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Pilau Rice, Garlic Naan, Pudina Gosht (lamb), Chicken Tikka Masala, and Paneer Pakora. All fabulous!

AXNA-NcnPa9SNgSiwWqSqw.text: My friend took me to Punjab for good Indian food and he wasn't kidding. The service was quick and we ordered a LOT. We shared chicken tikka masala, paneer, and lamb curry. We each got garlic naan bread and I got basmati rice and he got white rice. I also ordered the cucumber salad. Our selection was so good- the curries were flavorful and rich! My salad was sort of sad, I was expecting larger chunks of vegetables, but it did its purpose in cleanses my palate after eating some curry and naan. Overall, Punjab is definitely a place I recommend and would come back to!

k4ojZYnl7-fUaUi3_J37ng.text: After a lengthy visit at the British Museum, we hungered for some hardy Indian food. Punjab definitely fulfilled this desire. Here is my take on the service, atmosphere, and most importantly, the food.Appetizers:We ordered samosas, a favorite of ours, to start the meal.Rating: 3/5The samosas were decent, but lacked the complexity(in terms of spices) that is necessary for a good samosa.Entrees:I ordered the chicken tikka special; boneless chicken pieces with  Tandoori Seasoning and onions flambéed in Brandy at the table side. Quite delicious pairing with mint yogurt sauce that comes on the side. My only complaint is that the chicken was mildly dry and some of the onions were burnt to blackness. The sauce helped overcome the dryness.Rating 4/5My son ordered the Methi Murga; pieces of chicken submerged in mildly spicy tomato sauce with onions. He said that the chicken was very good but the sauce was a bit soupy and needed more onions. Rating 4.5/5Desert:I ordered Gulab jamun; it had a pleasing doughy texture although I felt the liquid it was bathing in was overly sweet and overwhelmed the more subtle flavors.Rating 3/5My son ordered mango lassi; mangoes submerged in a sweet syrup. He said it tasted wonderful, with the syrup covering the tartness of the mango but not overwhelming the flavor.Rating 5/5Recommendation: If you are in the area Punjab is a great place to dine.

bUls3WHgQbAe1GXkFPabhg.text: Just landed in London and needed some good food. And we found it here. I think we had butter chicken and naan...basic. But it was really good.

a2SF3JBS9FzrVE60yNMGaQ.text: I have to disappointingly give 3 stars the Punjab. I specifically dragged my friend here for dinner because I wanted to go to the oldest Punjabi restaurant in the U.K.  The food here is pretty good. We both loved the apps we got (lamb shish and the pumpkin app). My paneer makhani was fine, but I wish it was spicy. Her chicken tikka speciality was a bit smaller than expected. Sugar and mango lassi's were also good. I was not too thrilled that you have to also buy rice. We ended up buying one naan and one basmati. And if we had wanted water we would have paid. But here's where the bigger problem comes. We had no problems with the waiter who seated us and gave us our check. But the waiter who took our orders and brought our food out was a big problem. He's a young guy, probably the youngest there, but that's no excuse for being OFFENSIVE. Let me preface this by saying both my friend and I are American and speak English perfectly without accents (which btw our rude waiter had an accent when he spoke in English) AND YET despite this, he chose to continually say "arigato" and "xie xie" to my friend, thinking he was cute or funny? I don't know but it's completely unacceptable. It made both of us extremely uncomfortable and he never stopped doing it. Not to mention when he brought my rice out he referred to it as "arroz" instead of rice. And he did all of this clearly KNOWING we speak English (better than him for that matter). For these reasons, I'm disappointed that Punjab isn't a place I can recommend to anyone who isn't white or south Asian since our abilities to speak English were questioned while here.

pXOvn0DoqxJfs7Gr1flrWg.text: Fantastic, liked it more than the highly recommended Dishoom, which we also loved.  But Punjab felt a little more comforting, it was busy for sure but we were early and were seated right away.  The food was standout delicious.  From simple items like garlic naan and tikka, with highlights being all the curries and stews we tried.  We found them each to be unique, and we had all veggie items.  Highly recommend.

hx07FL7wKH-qrJOXtFRLWw.text: Good Indian food, but the owner earned the fifth star with his personal service.

VmKk7-HrZSYWm-TQdr804g.text: Tuesday night, this place was fit to burst. We actually came here after failing to get into Dishoom (another Indian joint) as they had over an hour's queue. Punjab also had a queue but that one was significantly shorter. We came here as a group of 5 people but were soon seated in a cushy corner table. The food was amazing, though some were spicy and the staff were super friendly, evoking images of a close knitted family and even posing for pictures with us and at one point, patiently explaining some of Punjab's background with us as they found us standing by a large map on the wall. We were advised to order a variety of dishes and share (which worked out fab for me as I love trying out new foods!!) The menu was expansive but the waiter was patiently and enthusiastically guiding us through it and in the end, we opted for the bold text dishes (which were chef recommendations). Our food arrived promptly and we tucked in. I did admit that I wanted to order more, mainly because it was so good, everyone was fighting for every last morsel! I would definitely be coming back to this long standing establishment, with its genuinely friendly service. It honestly felt like I was in their family home, being treated to home cooked food!! If you want genuine North Indian food then go here! It is also the UK's oldest North Indian restaurant!

Z7HsRf0j-5ohdP5otlUqpg.text: One of the best Indian Restaurants that we have been to.  And the best dinner in London on this trip.  We were promptly seated.  The decor evokes a feeling of old India.  We felt comfortable in our very casual attire.  We ordered Garlic Nan, one of the Chicken curries (ACHARRI MURGHA) Gobi aloo, and some basmati rice.  The waiter suggested some Papadam with a selection of chutney and other sauces. We really liked everything served.  And it was served promptly with heated plates.  Some of the items that came with the Papadam were foreign but tasty.  The Curry was spicy but the heat only lasts a few minutes and was the perfect level for us.  Everything was just good good good.You even get lollipops with your check.  Next time we are on London we will come back.

QMBzS7qJISBMf3oaOXX9cA.text: Another fantastic meal at PunjabBeen eating here for 40 years whenever I'm in town Food and service always exceptional Try the Acharri Gohst with garlic naanSuperb !!!

grguHqvw-bfF9wNoj52h4A.text: Overall, I was disappointed in my experience at Punjab, which has been recognized throughout the world as " The Oldest North Indian Restaurant in London." To be honest, I was saddened by my chicken tikka massala (which, to be honest, tasted more like an American chili than the classic dish I expected - waaaaaaaaaay too much cumin in this recipe). The atmosphere was fine, but nothing special, and the food was a bit overpriced for the quality. All in all, this was a rather lackluster experience with food that was average, at best. While Punjab may be the oldest Indian restaurant in London, it's certainly not the best - by far.

y05370XuYAk4lev50aQGXQ.text: All I can say is outstanding!  I went there two times during a five night vacation in London and once again during a trip there the following year.  This is the best Indian food I've ever had.

_Btqt2rKGKYKJWkmrI_D0w.text: Felt like we needed to have Indian for dinner!! There was a little bit of wait to get in but it wasn't too bad. Ordered the butter chicken and naan for myself! I felt the naan was a little dry and the butter chicken and lacking a bit of a kick that you usually get with the spices. Service wasn't too bad. Our only complaint was one of the waiters had knocked down my friend's full bottle of beer and didn't replace it. We had to ask him to do it. I think I had high expectations based on other reviews I had seen. So I found Punjab to be average.
