OoFHjf0NhKJaojGs8_32Nw.text: My first Indian food experience ever. From NYC where the food is significantly better than London in many categories. We were pleasantly surprised vy this outstanding establishment. The owner greeted all the guests at the door and the customer service was excellent! Food was very good. Highly recommend.

tT01g8cP4sqwyYr29k1mPA.text: Had a wonderful dinner here my last trip through London. The best Indian food I've had in years, combined with wonderful service. It's quite busy here on a Friday night, so be ready to be cozy.

s7hhMLsBdpEX1xCrGX8Z_Q.text: Most racist place.. Went for dinner there with family and friends and it looks like they like to cater only to English people ... Serving Indian people in A Indian restaurant is below their dignity .. The owner was disrespectful and inappropriate with even kids. Just appalling behavior !!! Honestly just full of ..: !!!! Don't waste ur money n time to bear the humility from these dumb racist idiots.

1Q0nITR_N7x3NvuP6FQBqg.text: They have very good food and excellent service. Very tasty dishes with excellent curries. They need to update their restaurant, it's rather poor shape but it shouldn't stop you from going if you want good Indian food

v1ovPf4FuM9txjLIU_ytmA.text: Met a friend here this August, expected a tourist trap given its location, only to find them trying not to be even that. Their claim to authenticity is in their lack of customer service for anybody non-white. Food was mostly horrible, and I do not use the word "horrible" lightly. Only the uninitiated will find this close to Indian cooking. Unfortunately, we are spoiled by Delhi's Gulatis, Karims and any number of choices in SFO bay area.Our meal started with Dry Kebabs that were dry and reheated. Excess of food coloring in CTM and shrimp was rubbery. Their Daal and recommended veggies(we had eggplant) were particularly bland and undercooked. Naan was ok..All in all looked like it was cook's first day at work. Servers were more interested in upping the check and getting us to leave even though we over ordered for six. Do not waste your time and money here, London can do better.

lf9qrZf916VGJht2N3lTGA.text: Inexpensive yet delicious. I have read the reviews and heard people rave about this place for eons, and when I finally made my way in there, it did not disappoint.The food was wonderful, the waiters were attentive and friendly, the price was very reasonable. The restaurant itself is pretty small and decorated with pictures of the family who own it and with some photos of the maharajahs (I think - it could have just been a really extravagant school uniform), which was a nice touch.If you like Indian food, definitely go here

yInwAzOC2HvpKVWVpuIHEQ.text: Very good and expensive Indian restaurant. Perfect service.Very busy, so better reserve early.

uUQ9LpbZtmrymWsbLCSShQ.text: This was a great restaurant. No wait (despite not having a reservation), super food and considerate service, with reasonable prices. I really enjoyed the Chicken Tikka Special, which came out sizzling and seasoned just right. Garlic Naan was very tasty as well.

mqgyvAUI7c9vgm82OJXN8A.text: Great little restaurant near the Lion King theatre. Super quick service and an unbeatable price. Loved it!

73Z8wqaQPh93r-XS4mDRkw.text: Okay, very underwhelmed by the food here.  Came here by myself for dinner based on the generally positive yelp reviews here and not sure if I feel like this place delivers.  Started out with an appetizer of the amritsari fish, then had the main dish of acharri murgha with some plain naan, with a mango lassi to wash it all down.  Yes, food was generally tasty but definitely did not live up to the hype of the amazing quality of British Indian food.  As an example, the fish tasted like it was just thawed frozen fish fried with some spices.  Nothing was bad at all, and I had a generally good dinner, but nothing at all was special.  I've had much better Indian food in a number of restaurants in NYC.  Also, just as a slight aside, I think almost every customer in the restaurant was a tourist, which while not always indicative of anything, in the context of my lackluster meal, does not bode well for the quality of the food. That being said, I had no issues with the service of the wait staff.  Everyone was polite and attentive and I did not feel rushed out at any point.

-LyMBHqjdU1xZgF9xbTihg.text: Great lamb curries and roast chicken.

UtFWJ18BY4ymKo-h4s_Mxg.text: Having been in London for a few months now upon writing this review, I must start off by saying that I've really fallen in love with the Indian cuisine offered in the city, however, as a result, I'm beginning to grow a bit more critical when reviewing Indian as I learn to understand it better.To start off, Punjab provides customers with a great atmosphere for dining.  Located right at the end of Neal Street in Covent Garden, Punjab is a great place to go after a bit of shopping or after work.  Additionally, the service is absolutely fantastic, with quick and funny waiters who are more then willing to help should you find yourself in a bind as to what dish to have (and you will!)As for the food, however, Punjab falls just a tad bit short when taking into consideration that you'll likely pay around 12 pounds if you get a dish with rice and naan.  The serving sizes are a tad bit small (certainly too small to split) for what you pay, and having sampled a bit from the dishes of those around me, I found that the seasoning was pretty much the same even with dishes that were drastically different from one another.  If you're in it for the atmosphere, Punjab is a great choice, but if you're really trying to get the best bang for your buck I might consider looking elsewhere.

HKE9LyoPgWI-JHh4-JVCTQ.text: We had a very late lunch (or early dinner?) around 4:30 here. Loved their cheese naan! Favorite naan in all of London so far!

c6PtQcfvsxVWHxSd4axKGA.text: Let me start by pointing out that I have an increasingly large Italian friendship base, and one thing that Italian's (in my experience) can't really handle is the classic, mouth melting curry. It took me roughly 11 months to convince my partner that this really was a good place to go, and she's glad I did. The only problem I now have is that I have to argue extensively so that I don't have curry every Friday night.The Punjab is pretty close to a tourist heavy area - not necessarily a bad thing, but the obvious fears of quality/authenticity are apparent. Within 30 seconds of sitting down though, the fears are instantly dispelled. The staff are beyond friendly, the recommendations really strong and most importantly REALLY descriptive. It made it very easy for my partner to pick what type of curry would be best for her (surprisingly not the Korma) and which starters would enable her to be a little more adventurous (she had the pokora, which were the "right type of spicy").Beyond the food, the wine selection is, if anything, slightly luxurious for a curry house (I staunchly stuck to my cobra) and received no complaints from my partner, a minor miracle in itself. The best thing about the Punjab for me though is the atmosphere and the place itself. It's a proper curry house - it doesn't set out to be a really pretentious and ultra-modern environment, where you're served minimal portions in a stylish fashion, and it doesn't pander to touristy gimmicks - it's basically like a freshly decorated version of your local curry house - clean, warm and friendly. You will need to book for Friday and weekend slots, and it's always worth trying to get yourself a table on the left side of the restaurant where the atmosphere is a little bit more cosy (and the seating against the walls is a bit comfier than the normal seats). To the right is the primary room, which is great if you have a large group or if you are there on the busier nights, but on an early weekday or early in the day, you can get a little bit lost in the space and feel a little isolated. Beyond that, get the vegetable samosas every time, because the dark red/brown sauce that it comes with is the best thing on the menu.

GI852TqcuysD0-0Bh0fz_A.text: Great authentic indian food for very reasonable prices. No queues. A good recommendation.

7Bnj-No_Hk5tzVS9BrgtpQ.text: Outstanding is the one word to describe this place. Food beverage and staff all receive high marks.

UnSHg_k7i2l4iC_YBS4pjQ.text: As always, very good.  We always visit the Punjab when in London.  The food is excellent, and the service is wonderful.  We are never disappointed.  This time we took some friends, and they were impressed too!  The house specialties are outstanding.

Vc3A57mpqW7gxYs6z0fxHw.text: Indian food of the highest quality with service to match.  Well priced to boot.  The only downside was a wait of about 20 minutes as I failed to book a table ahead of time.Since my dining companion is spice averse, we ordered fairly benign dishes.  On this night, we had the butter chicken, samosas, cholay and garlic naan.  The butter chicken might have been the best I've had.  There was a wonderful smoky component to the chicken that came through despite the rich, luxurious sauce.  That sauce, well, I could have drunk that from a cup it was so good.  As it was, I tried to soak up every last drop with the freshly baked naan.Service was extremely attentive, with the manager coming around a few times to check up on us.Punjab was been around for about 60 years, and it's easy to see why.  In a city that prides itself on the quality if its Indian food, I feel that Punjab is definitely amongst the upper crust.

NlKIZrbeQsh5RaebKr5cxQ.text: Real taste of North Indian food. Delicious lamb. If you want to try real Indian food, aromatic, full of flavour, that's the best choice. Highly recommend.

RTm0ckOiw3-LOkgEnSqCdg.text: Hands down my favorite Indian restaurant in Covent Garden!  IThis review is from when I visited a few years back, but the memories of the meal were like yesterday.We didn't have any reservation when we arrived, and it was a cold rainy London day.  We got a nice seat, away from the door, and proceeded to order.  I chose the tandoori chicken platter and it did not disappoint. The chicken was very tender and perfectly spiced.  The naan was also great as was the raita.The entire dining experience was fabulous.  Service was fantastic and the other diners in the restaurant were very friendly.  I want to come back to London and visit this fine establishment!

aQrvz3Md9oV1BcuSLc6bRQ.text: Good was great and prices were fair. We enjoyed the chicken tikka masala (each our own order!), samosas, paratha and garlic naan. Great service.

VH57btvLSYo3shzz9V1k9g.text: Methi Gosht was incredible as was the service and presentation. The manager came to our table to check up on everything and recommended to get Methi Gosht with Paratha instead of with Naan. A great choice.The Acchari Murgh was good but not as good as the Methi Gosht.We ordered two desserts and they served Kulfi and Gulab Jaman just the way we liked it. A wonderful dining experience.

x5sPCYeb8o2cWmJygoKfFg.text: Food was great. The service for London was attentive and quick. The prices were reasonable. Didn't love the wine, but that was probably a bad selection on my end.

EIBkIxNniVdS_Jj4aK7S4g.text: Food is ok. Nothing to write home about. They charge for every little thing e.g pappad, rice. The entree are at a higher price range and they dont even include rice. Roti or naam coats about £2.50 each just to give an idea. Rice is also not cheap. The ambience and service is just ok. I dont't think I'll be going back.

VQ-4BFtyRjFtCcQXUiuvmw.text: I had the best Indian food I had ever had here and had a wonderful experience. We chose this restaurant based on its good Yelp reviews, and we were not disappointed. When we got to the restaurant, we were greeted by the owner. He asked us where we were from and then gave us his suggestions on what we should order. His suggestions did not disappoint! I will definitely come back next time I am in London. Overall, delicious food, excellent staff, welcoming owner, amazing dining experience.

3dipvLd84BLe53AyaA4-2w.text: The food was fine, but if you are a tourist, check your bill carefully.  I was overcharged and thought that the bill was a little high when it was presented to me, but was in a rush to leave.  When I got back to the hotel, I had a bad feeling about the bill and checked the prices of what I ordered online.  Sure enough, I was overcharged,  It could have been a mistake, but I truly do not believe that it was.  Unfortunately, I paid cash, otherwise, I would go back to the restaurant to get my money back.  It's the principle,  I hate dishonesty.

h_sd76MMMY5g1JIT0oNLVg.text: So a disclaimer - I don't know the difference between good or great Indian food, or even what regional Indian foods should taste like. However what I can say, is that my family and I had an excellent experience here. We came here based off the reviews from more knowledge food folk, and the quality of service, food and the general restaurant environment was all top notch. Our server was helpful, and our choices were all satisfactorily spicy/not spicy. They were also happy to keep our box of leftovers in their kitchen while we went off to the theater. The other option would have been Dishoom, but I'm glad we didn't go there - the atmosphere at this place is really nice, and Dishoom just seems like it's trying too hard. plus their no reservations policy is a little objectionable.Punjab gets a well deserved 5 stars.

YIJqpY-iN2_-y5GcdP4FJw.text: Food was good, not great.  Service was prompt,  but not personal.   Get in, get out!  Also, if you don't say anything,  an "optional service 10" charge is added...I'm guessing for tip?   Also, what the hell, rice costs $3.30!!!  It's good rice,  but it's freaking rice!

jpCdbuEfDM7eYOs_lD750w.text: I'll start off by first ditto'ing Rick G's comment on the putrid stench.Second, wtf?? How is this place rated so highly? Saying the best dishes we tried were even mediocre would be flattery. Blegh. The chicken tikka masala was- ok. And that was the best we had. The spinach both tasted disgusting and was completely unappetizing to look at. You have to pay for rice. The tandoori was bland and boring. SO very disappointed to have wasted my one night out in London at Punjab.And again, the chemical odor, ugh. Voila, my first one-star review.

_mmN8IcMx2Z8OD94twCy1w.text: Incompetent. Made a reservation for 7 people at 9:15pm. Had a long conversation, the man took the booking, wrote down my phone number and wrote down my name (even asked me to spell it). When we arrived, the man acted like we never made the reservation while my party of 7 waited outside. They claimed they dont make reservations. Complete utter disregard for us. Yelled at and everything. Avoid just to not support this business.

23yz-bZsVQY1H34Fc98iiA.text: So, this was the only Indian restaurant we went to in London, but my god was it the best Indian food I've ever eaten. No where I've ever been on the west coast (of America) can hold a candle to this place. We ended up going for dinner 2 out of the 4 nights we were in London! If you get there before 6pm for dinner, you won't have to wait in their line outside.

GPNHqcAjmKNjWJwnCnKYHQ.text: Great service Agnelo AKA Michael and The Governor who we had a lovely conversation with about the history of the restaurant.Prices are like an normal sit down middle priced place in London. I've averaged 45 Pounds for 2 anywhere in London. Lets put it this way I would rather spend that 45 pounds here, good value.We had Butter chicken which was made with real bone-in tandoori chicken (the right way to make it) Delicious.Also ordered the Achari lamb which was equally great and I found my self ordering more Naan to clean up what left in the dish :)So if you are in the Covent garden area and want some nice indian cuisine then this is your place.BTW: Chemical Odder other reviewers talked about wasnt that noticeable but I caught it too.  I think comes from the bathroom, I bet you all were sitting in the hall between the bathroom and the main door. The one on your right when you enter. I think the draft between the bathroom and the front door opening delivers the smell. At least you know that the bathrooms are clean :)

_qZwMcKbZAeLzznf72BJDg.text: Coming to London, one has to sample the curries. Punjab was perfect. Great service, great ambience, great food. And, the place has been open since 1946.I ordered the Lamb Saag and the chicken tikka special. I always order chicken tikka and think I am getting a nice curry sauce with it, and it always comes out without the masala sauce. So I ordered this sauce on the side with the special dish. So the dish is prepared at your table with the server drizzling some alcohol over the chicken tikka dish, which comes out on a sizzling hot plate. The guy lights the alcohol on fire!!!! It's perfect.The Cheese Naan was not as good as I hoped.The guy didn't charge me for the Masala sauce.

mZmulpEpDaefw1cX8g9RNA.text: Delicious food, great atmosphere albeit slightly packed when you're sitting at the back like we did. My favourite Indian restaurant in London!

R55hkY0noAUaY2rsJDmZaQ.text: I visited Punjab for the second time last night and was not disappointed. The place is hopping on a Saturday night, with plenty of tourists, but we waited less than five minutes for a table. The chana masala was amazing, even my dining companions were jealous. The food prices are reasonable and the wine prices remarkably low. On my first visit, service was a bit brusque, but last night they redeemed themselves. I wholeheartedly recommend Punjab!

5LqbrwghuLSRwqrXf8-18Q.text: A lovely place in Coventry Garden. Dropped in for dinner and got seated straight away. They did let us know they needed the table for guest coming in a few hours, no worries. Had classic Indian form tikka to sagg paneer. Non disappointed and would make a return visit next time we come through.

Fv3NTwuEWQaGwuFpnYD2MQ.text: Undoubtedly, one of the best North Indian restaurants in London. I usually order mango lassi in every Indian restaurant. But decided to try salted lassi this time and I was not disappointed. It was perfect. I tried different kinds of breads(bullet naan, chapathi and tandoori paratha), kaali dal and masala chai. It was heavenly. The service was very quick. And the waiting time for a table wasn't bad. We went there on New Year's eve and I thought we would have to wait for a long time to get a table. But, we got a table as soon as we walked in. The staff were very friendly. I would definitely go there again to try the rest of the dishes!

Iv5tzckd7vkiU_X-1ARpwQ.text: Tasty Indian food in London at a reasonable price. All 3 of us enjoyed our dinners here. I had Chicken Madras which was hotter that I've had at other restaurants. That's not a complaint because it tasted great; just HOT! The chicken was breast meat and prepared well.We also liked the Punjabi Samosa and Chicken Tikka Masala, and Garlic Naan. Friendly, efficient staff help make the dining experience pleasant. I'd be happy to come back here again when I'm in London.

IpldHCud3SWVAoHnAfK1Ig.text: Delicious traditional Indian fare. The restaurant is busy so book in advance. The menu is hilarious - see the Garlic Naan description. Indian cuisine is one of my favourites - this stood up well. Go with a group, as portions are large and you need to try a few dishes.

EuVXdD4kHhqLfHXjOKNnKA.text: Not the best chicken korma in the world but the service was so nice and friendly (I ate solo and was happy as a clam) and the pilau rice was great.Oh yeah, the tandoori wings were pretty good too.

2pNRp-7RLYi_PXvFdHzyXw.text: We went there with a couple of friends: the food is exquisite, but quite spicy so be ready. Got the chicken tikka masala, daal, garlic naan, rice pilau. Everything was perfectly cooked and it wasn't that expensive: around 20£ per person

wzxG3j3VAJBeYjlH-buy1w.text: The food was delicious. I would stop in again on my trip if I didn't still have leftovers - and if it wasn't for the 15 pound/person minimum they list in small text on the bottom of the menu. For a meal there is no worry about teaching the minimum between an entrée, rice (or bread) and a drink. It's worth it, too. I waited until a waiter brought me a box for my leftovers to ask for a masala chai and that order was lost. Another waiter brought me the bill and I did not check it for the chai - which occasioned many minutes afterward of curious stares as the staff wondered why I wasn't leaving and I wondered how long it took to make a chai. After a bit I asked a server, who got pretty flustered, checked my bill, and in the end have me a free glass of chai so no complaints.

E-nq_G5PJb3GHz8Zg7P4-A.text: The food was amazing! Excellent customer service. Authentic Quality.  Really enjoyed the environment.

Yv7J2oMK-e9C7PnBrTK7tg.text: Holy smoke this place crazy good. Top notch INDIAN right in the middle of the theatre district. You gotta go!

i6-Tlp5QgO198xIcUNlRdg.text: Fab Punjabi food I loved the food and service and hospitality my first visit to London from California Great owner, his name is Amrit , fantastic personal touch

GWv-42ugtQwNR4o0yxGBwg.text: This was such a delicious meal! We popped in on our way to see Matilda. We had the bullet naan (pretty spicy), chicken biryani, samosas, and a fried fish appetizer that I can't remember the name of. Yum!

JFYblDnQ1sKAVf_TEFfzjQ.text: Really delicious Punjabi Indian food in London! On my one week trip to London this past week we looked for Indian food since we heard that it's your best bet at good food in London (otherwise notorious for having shitty food).The restaurant itself was packed on a Friday night around 8pm, but luckily there was barely any wait (10 min or so). I ordered the Lamb Madras since it was the only item under lamb labeled "hot/spicy". It was SUCH tender lamb - I was actually surprised but it may be the most tender lamb I've had at any Indian restaurant. The sauce was spicy enough, 7/10 on my spicy level scale (I love spicy food for reference). The curry flavor was really yummy, packed with just enough spices for that kick. My friend ordered one of their tandoori chicken dishes and I was equally surprised by how juicy the chicken pieces were (they didn't come with bone, so that's even more surprising). They poured a shot of (alcohol) on her chicken tandoori sizzling plate and lit it up with a match - the fire was HUGE so be wary of your hair! The mango lassi drink was perfect and not too sweet. The only letdown was the appetizer - we ordered the prawn puri and it came with SUCH tiny shrimp (def not prawn....). Skip that appetizer!Overall - food was delicious, portions a bit small for the price (approx 20 pounds per person) as we had no leftovers. I'm usually almost always left with leftovers at Indian restaurants in the States...If I'm back in London I'll be sure to visit Punjab again :)

h0BQDZl1CFEvI0dTsdVJrw.text: I saw this restaurant on one of Guy Fieri's show and have been wanting to visit for a while. It was such a pleasant experience! The staff was great and attentive but not over the top. The food speaks for itself! The chicken tikka masala was so flavorful and the chicken was so tender. The samosas were crispy on the outside and jam packed with goodness inside - a bit on the spicy side, so be careful if you're not into spicy food. The lamb shami kebab was on point! The accompanying sauce was minty and citrusy all at once and really brought out the flavors of the lamb patties. I'll be dreaming of this place for years to come!

nAHml-JBWDFknn8v9P0RQQ.text: AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS FOOD! I happened to come across this place whilst on a walking tour of London and I'm very glad I did as it did not disappoint! The chicken tikka masala has moist, tender cuts of chicken in a delicious and not overly greasy curry sauce. The garlic naan was in fact coated with just the right amount of garlic flavoring and was not burnt or overly crisp. The mango lassi which I also tried was also delicious and not too sweet. Every item I tried was on point! Also, the staff was friendly and attentive! I would definitely come back the next time I'm in London!

ElXyW7qv7GobN0alXn1AdQ.text: What I Ordered: Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Paneer, Samosas and NaanFlavor: This was probably the best Chicken Tikka Masala I've ever had.  I've heard this is one of, if not the first place to serve the dish so if you come here, definitely get that.Service:  Pretty attentive.Atmosphere: Nice traditional old school Indian restaurant decor and music.Price: Good for the quality.Location: Great location.  In walking distance from the West End and Picadilly Circus.  So a nice pre-show meal if you plan on seeing any plays.Other Comments:  I would definitely come back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Tikka Masala
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Samosas

y443DmmS6YOwCy9Zfcrmzw.text: I went here on my only night free in London based on other yelp reviews, and was not disappointed. I do not normally seek out Indian food on my trips, but the reviews were fantastic and again it did not disappoint. I wish I could tell you what me and my guest ordered, but we ordered a lamb curry dish and a chicken curry dish based on the suggestion of the waiter or manager. We had naan bread, and white rice, and the local beers Again, I wish I could say more about the dishes other than the spices were perfect, medium was just right, and the atmosphere was fantastic. It felt very much like a local, cozy place to eat for locals. I would highly recommend to anyone..

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

pWec9FaBvJodQxdEJjTT7g.text: If I could I would give them 20 stars.The food the service is great here.Nothing goes wrong feel free to order whatever you like. The spicy naan was my favorite. Chicken beryani was outstanding.I would go back again when I am back in London.

hpa00eQuYiwLN6J0x1Jr9Q.text: This is the first Indian restaurant in London's history. The menu is quite extensive and there are some unique items that aren't found in majority of restaurants. The food was quite good, but after going to Dishoom a few nights before I felt this restaurant was a bit of a let down based on the standards of Dishoom. The owners and staff were very helpful and took time to talk to us.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Pudina Gosht and Achari chicken were okay but typical quality of what is found in many Indian restaurants
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Amritsar Fish was decent
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka was noisy but lacked flavour.

cbkH2qpdY7udoLumH6L7gw.text: I came to London from Germany looking for good Indian food-- this place was the best. The food was near authentic and their chai tea was so good.We had chicken vindaloo and the shrimp curry-- with some rice and naan. Amazing!

ZEwvgf5vyaymyenFca40Tg.text: This is an awesome place to get Indian food when you're in London. Very home style cooking. Usually not too long a wait to get a table. Not a fancy place. The naan wasn't great but the food is very good. Good stop if you're in the area.

iJrQBwF5GFf-Jm5-fPfAXg.text: I came to London with a group of friends, one of which frequently visits London for work.  I have to admit, I was beyond confused when the first place he wanted to take us was an Indian restaurant.  I did not realize that England's Indian food was so highly regarded! He insisted that Punjab was the best place for us to go.  I was definitely overwhelmed by the menu.  It is quite extensive!  I had tried Indian food a few times before, but I am certainly no expert.  My friend and I decided to split an order of the Butter Chicken (it sounded simple for us beginners) with sides of Cheese Naan and white rice.  Our friend recommended the Chicken Tika Masala, but we decided to play it safe.It actually turns out that we should have listened to my friend.  Although the Butter Chicken was good, it was actually much richer and spicier than the Chicken Tika Masala that we tried!  The Chicken Tika Marsala was mild, unique and delicious.  I will definitely be ordering it during my next meal at an Indian restaurant.Our Butter Chicken WAS enjoyable.  It was very tender and went perfectly over our side of white rice.  However, my favorite part of the meal was the Cheese Naan.  I could have eaten a stack of it!  Naan is an oven-baked flatbread served with Indian food (I did not know this).  The Cheese Naan has a white cheese baked inside the flatbread.  It was AMAZING and I loved it.  I'm actually craving an order as I write about it.The restaurant was casual, but nice.  I loved the Indian decorations and bold colors.  The service was also wonderful.  The next time I am in London, I will be sure to stop at Punjab for some Chicken Tika Masala and endless orders of Cheese Naan.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken

XTnYus3AeXBqjVj8lehVEw.text: Very cute cozy restaurant in Covent Garden area. Service was good and the food was yummy. I had my go to dish (chicken tikka masala). It was good but needed a touch more yogurt. Chicken was very tender and cooked perfectly. My local Indian restaurant make the curry a bit more flavorful so I am used to that. Overall great restaurant

4fyhEgf11f3HjZosjARbow.text: Food: Meh. Ordered chicken tikka masala, chicken curry, naan, garlic naan, and basmatic rice. So, I thought chicken ticken masala was tandoori chicken in a tomato cream sauce. Well, this was very dry chicken breast that was never tandoori chicken in a pretty good tomato cream sauce. Like I said, meh. But basmatic rice and naan was really good.Service: Good. But who cares if the food is meh.Atmosphere: Clean, classy, formal.Visited on 20 June 2017.

QCC7cbiIqW7U6gldQL12ng.text: For the prices we expected high quality. If not from the food at least from the service. However, our main waiter was rude and made us feel like he might spit in our food. The samosas were greasy and lacking flavor, the paneer pakora had been sitting in it's old greese and then reheated. Then the main course arrived and the rice was soggy, which is a sure sign of a bad Indian restaurant.  The kitchen should never have allowed it to come out. We had a Dahl and chickpea curry.  The chickpea curry was good but the dahl was barley editable. Had this been a 20 pound meal we still would have been disappointed but at 60 pounds it was offensive.

-mA-PVr0fxewpAZ3kcAJJw.text: Great food! The chicken tikka Masala is different than I've had at other places. But it's a great difference. It was so tasty. Probably the best I have ever had! Service was also great. One thing both my wife and I noticed is that the staff here is so very nice, warm and welcoming. They even saw a homeless woman outside wearing a brown shawl and went out to offer her some food! I mean come on! Talk about paying it forward! Not only does your establishment deserve an award in customer service and quality and taste of your food, but throw in a humanitarian award in there as well for helping out someone in need! I give all of the staff here my highest respect! That's for making me, my wife and my sleeping son (lol) feel so very welcome in a place that is truly amazing! We were so very fortunate to have stopped by to eat here. Thanks again!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

cxU1DU8wVCz-1FtYMAsxjg.text: Very good Indian restaurant! Good service, nice atmosphere and fine food.If you're looking for a great place to have an Indian meal in London it's hard to beat.

jE-U4XFw5XuJE0LgI__Vyg.text: I wasn't going to leave London without eating Chicken Tikka Masala (it was invented here, or so I'd heard) and made a special trip to Punjab based on the reviews. In fact my wife and I almost didn't eat here because when arriving and asking for a table for 2, the host barked "go outside and wait til I see what I have" which was a little off putting, since it was a cold December night and we had no idea how long we'd be expected to stand out there. We also arrived at the same moment as a drunken group of 8 who the same host basically told to hit the bricks as they couldn't be accommodated.  As we were walking away I heard him calling for the table of 2 so we scurried back and they seated us a few minutes later. The upstairs dining room was much quieter than the downstairs. At first it was eerily quiet but eventually they turned on some Indian music that improved the the atmosphere a bit. Whoever wrote the menu has a good sense of humor. I appreciated that when reading some of the descriptions. After 2 entrees, 2 naan breads, 2 drinks, and the service charge, the total came to £44. Great food, unmemorable service, pricier than your typical takeout. Overall a good choice if you only have limited time in London and you can get in the door.

6si8N7rUlIpPNbcxYlDjzA.text: Best freaking Indian food I've ever had in my life. I can't say i didn't like anything (maybe not the cool cucumber yogurt because i don't like cucumbers)But it was all delicious. I can't stress how much i liked it.Mango Lassi (so good and fresh, share if you can't handle too much sweetness)Pumpkin CurryChicken Tikka Masala (delicious)Lamb Korma Curry (so bombdiggity good i just want to fly back to London to eat it again. seriously)CHEESE AND BUTTER NAAN dipped in curry= heavenIf you want to see a video of the restaurant, its on my food blog here: youtube.com/my_videos_ed…

c5plBZJ_uAyEcwlhpsMZSA.text: We were looking for an authentic Indian meal in London, a city known for its large Indian population. We found Punjab on the edge of the Bloomsbury neighborhood. Everything from the pakora appetizers to the tandoori chicken and lamb biryani was delicious.

rXurrUPuue2AXz-2fakGCw.text: We had dinner on 10/22, meal was fine.  We paid our bill with our credit card, no problem.  Several weeks later we got out credit card bill and we had 2 charges for our dinner, one without the tip ($37), the second with the tip ($40.81).   We've enjoyed dinner here in the past and haven't had any other problems.

1Q65whPX5B8ge_iO1HiFig.text: We came for the first time and we'll  definitely come back! The food was amazing and they adjusted the dishes as we like (not spicy, dairy free, etc) and the service was incredible - the restaurant was full and we felt like we're the only table. We loved it!

penOL7Cv6ZI6TqAsscNHiw.text: Stopped in for lunch after a few less than satisfying meals during a quick stop in London. The food matched the reviews that I had read. I especially recommend the pumpkin curry- excellent. Also, the breads were very good.The place was quiet and the service attentive without being intrusive.

NlgFDa4x9Dqhn7AW7M2Hgg.text: I  am so disappointed!! I love Indian food, and after reading all those good reviews, I decided to give it a go. I went once, I won't go twice. Me and my boyfriend decided to go for lunch, the restaurant was empty, which was good after hearing stories of queues in front of the restaurant. I ordered Chicken Tikka Massala with plain rice. What a shame. The chicken was well cooked, but my tikka massala sauce was just disgusting. It was way too salty and just not good. Didn't taste of tomato at all. I have made tikka massala myself and I know what goes in there. No idea what they put but it was not good. My boyfriend ordered Lamb Korma. We had tasted better. In all, Marks and Spencer is better quality and it actually tastes better... If you feel like Indian good, honestly, don't waste your money, or else, go somewhere else.

UIprHl_nP7ViLrK297v00A.text: I really enjoyed Punjab.  The servers were humorous, attentive, and offered up their suggestions.  We pretty much went with the dishes that were marked as specialties on the menu.  Starting with my favorite, we had:KARAHI GOSHT: lamb curry with tomato and green pepper sauceKADU SABJI: a pumpkin curryACHARRI MURGHA: a chicken curry and punjabi specialty that the menu cited as a must try at least once in a life timeEverything was really tasty and flavorful.  The lamb was very tender, the pumpkin had great flavor and the sauce for the chicken was interesting (in a good way).I would definitely return if I were in the mood for Indian food!

X0RB9ad6kQ_s9qWcToExLA.text: Most delicious Indian food experience EVER!  We stumbled upon this place while strolling Covent Garden. Arrived around 8 pm and were seated immediately in the back of the restaurant - very cozy.  Service was quick, kind and efficient.  The server had family in the SF bay area too!  Small world. We ordered the butter chicken and chicken tikka masala with garlic naan and roti as well has basmati rice.  Both chicken dishes were AMAZING.  the spice level was perfect and the chicken was cooked to perfection.  I was so excited after the meal and told my husband that I could eat this food daily if it tasted THIS good.  Looking for a good place in California to try.  Too bad we haven't found one yet.  I guess it's true that London has the best indian food.  We will definitely be back.

0zioduFFUoDgoxnlVaT_hQ.text: We are in London visiting and it was my dad's birthday. All he wanted was some good tikki masala so I went on the search and found pun jab. I wanted something that was classic and not to stuck up or fancy and just simply good. Punjab delivered. I had the lamb korma with plain rice and naan- the flavors blended together perfectly and were not overpowering. I tried some of the tikki masala as well and it was excellent! The place is small but comfortable and we were comfortably set with a party of 5.  I loved the windows in the front of the restaurant and if I came back I would ask to sit near the front simply to people watch. I've considered moving from Houston, Texas to London simply so I could eat here at least twice a week. It seems rash but I'm still thinking about it. Overall best Indian food EVER!

NxT-_THbsauSYveeJUzv_A.text: Good indian food.  Spent the day shopping in convent garden and stopped here for lunch.  Had the chicken tikka masala which was creamy and just the way I like it.  Also had the saag aloo which was also solid.  Level of spice was perfect (I typically like things medium, so if you like your dishes hot or mild you may have to ask for it).Enjoyed the decor and had a window seat so also enjoyed the people watching.

5rCkfH5a0p4RRF59p2ZDOQ.text: Extremely mediocre food, poor ambiance, weird and powerful soap smell, and high prices. £27 for two with two dishes, a paratha, rice, and raita. Maybe for really good Indian food, or a nice restaurant, but this was not that. Felt like a tourist trap, worth avoiding.Note that they have canned mango as a desert option for over £3. Hilarious.

MGF2ETkWWdwl5tqLsm6N0Q.text: My second visit to this gem of a restaurant did not disappoint. We made reservations and we were seated promptly. We started with the garlic naan and it was great! Then the chicken tikka, lamb korma curry and gobi aloo. Every dish was perfectly spiced and cooked to perfection. We once again had a fantastic meal to remember at this restaurant. Very highly recommended!

c6Rw4wlf5j2kpIj82FcOBg.text: best indian food in a long time. chicken tikka masala and butter chicken.The only Indian food I've eaten has been from Southern California. I wasn't sure how the food in London would be, but I was happily surprised by Punjab. We were jet lagged so we ate at some random time as they were just preparing for the dinner rush, but they were very quick to seat us. We had the chicken tikka masala and the butter chicken. Both were excellent and had just the right amount of flavor without being too overpowering. I would definitely eat here again if I were to come back - plus it's in a pretty convenient location, within walking distance to a lot of shops.

FKGDteqYwqGrfftxpjCrHw.text: We went here for dinner on our last night in London.  Since part of our group are vegetarians we figured that Indian food was a good bet to please all people involved.  We ordered a plethora of dishes ranging in Chicken Tikka Masala to their famous Pumpkin Curry.  Throw in a few more curries, rice, and naan and we were filled to the brim. My personal favorite was the Pumpkin curry...it wasn't spicy...more of a sweet yet savory dish that left me licking my plate.  The Chicken was good too but didn't taste that different from others I have tried at other Indian restaurants.  Next time I am in London I am definitely coming back.

wdkxEpoMPM9NpPXLac22uA.text: A queue at 6pm on a Tuesday evening....it pretty much should say it all...I LOVE the food there - wide selection of high-quality Indian food. It comes extremely close to the Delhi street food, which tastes like heaven anyway. It is also a gem for vegetarians - large variety of non-meat dishes, I'd easily turn vegetarian if I could've eaten there everyday!I love the atmosphere - very homely, cozy, amazing service - everytime it's like you're meeting old friends! Though in a prime location and respectable-looking customers this place is not pretentious, it makes you want to come back there again.When we went to celebrate India winning the cricket World cup we got free sweets at the end of the dinner!Tip - book a table, rather than stumbling outside you'll get your table relatively fast (there is a lot, a LOT of demand...)

8uD_c0TMCGSUMpNG8wuSYw.text: Service was spotty and staff. A bit rude. The 3 stars are for the fantastic garlic chicken and naan. The chicken tiki masala was ok, nothing exceptional.

9p-uxzy1SV-W0JQVc7AYYw.text: I had a very very poor and disappointing experience at Punjab restaurant.I ordered mix grill, yellow lentil and mix vegetable curry.  The lamb in the mix grill was completely dark black and I wish I have taken a picture to prove it. The other meat on the grill I couldn't even Identify what that was cos it was so black and tasteless. The yellow lentil and veg curry was  like a dish from the buffet because of complete lack of excitement and freshness.  The only that's fresh was the nan bread.  This place is a tourist trap, we are all fooled by "the oldest northern Indian food in London" slogan! There are plenty of other good authentic Indian restaurants in London. Please don't waste your money in here. DISAPPOINTED.

Z402wfc3wa1WcxlVDG09tg.text: I wrote a note when I last checked in, booked marked the place and didn't review it at the time. My note was "best Indian food I've had". I'd like to say I've had better from a restaurant but I haven't. Even living in Seattle we have amazing Indian and this one took the cake. I was fortunate enough to try many dishes as we were with a group of 15-20 ppl and probably ordered over half of the menu. This place will NOT disappoint you. Authentic and I hope it stays that way.

YJ-8QUMJfzoebZH31B0iHw.text: Some of the best Indian food I've ever had - granted London has no shortage of Indian restaurants - but Punjab goes above and beyond in the service category, making this a must-stop if you are in Covent Garden. My friend and I had the Cheese Naan, Chicken Karahi and Acharri Murgha. The chicken was succulent and the sauces/spices flavorful without being heavy. Good selection of wine+beers and prices quite fair for London. Where Punjab truly separates itself is in its service - Amrit and his staff go to extraordinary lengths to take care of their customers. My friend lost a family heirloom in the restaurant and Amrit and a few of his staff personally helped us search for an hour-plus after close to find the ring, and sure enough it turned up! I recommend Punjab to anyone valuing fantastic food+service in Covent Garden.

IOVcYHEks4NgL05LVQDAzA.text: I had my doubts about the place from the moment we stepped in and saw the drab, dingy, stained, and discolored carpets, matched by carpet-upholstered chairs.  As we were ushered to the back room we were hit with the stench of industrial cleaner that permeates the restaurant.  What odor(s) are they trying to hide?  The stench was ever-present, and we didn't get used to it as the dinner progressed.They tried to seat us in the back room in between two busy, loud tables even though every single other table in that room was open.  We asked to be reseated to a table in a different row, and after they checked with the host at the front, they obliged our request, but appeared to be unnerved that we had disrupted their normal seating pattern.The food?  In a word, subpar.  I started with a mango lassi, which normally should be cool, thick, and creamy.  Punjab's mango lassi was tepid, watery, and bland.  I strongly believe that it was pre-mixed or came straight from a carton before being watered down substantially to cut on costs.  I didn't finish it.  We ordered a few of the dishes that had received rave reviews on yelp -- the chicken tikka masala, grandpa's daal, a saag dish, and garlic naan.  I wanted to like these dishes -- even just one -- but all were unflavorful and disappointing.If this restaurant were located outside the touristy Covent Garden area, I highly doubt it would survive or would earn the same *shockingly* high yelp ratings.  I would rate Punjab among the bottom tier of Indian restaurants I've eaten at in my life.Don't go.

cCxCKRULHf4D5iV-MBSt8g.text: I admit I had some reluctance to come here as opposed to the newer, more modern Indian restaurants which are more trendy in London these days.  But I have no regrets, it was delicious.  Of course, we ordered the Butter Chicken and Tikka Masala.   Both were so delicious, I ate past the point of fullness.

7tJTobEnRZdttdCuFFs_4g.text: Delicious food with large menu and Attentive and friendly staff. My boyfriend has a nut allergy so they gave us a menu with all of the allergies and dietary restriction labeled which was very convenient. Must visit!

5fCfW8miXgnJF0JYF0hhOQ.text: No matter how frazzled or worn out you are once you sit down at the Punjab, read the menu here and you'll be in good spirits before you even order food. Such a witty little menu. This place gets backed for dinner  - we went for lunch and got seated immediately. They were taking reservations the entire time we were there. Go at lunch.I ordered the chicken tikka masala since it's the most famous dish in London, and I purposefully chose this place when doing research. The reviews weren't wrong! This was the best Indian food I've ever had! The chicken was so smokey, the sauce so creamy and everything in between so flavorful. I'm obsessed and want some now. Get the samosas, the sweet lassi, plain naan and rice and you'll be all set.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

CvbBawp4CFBCtOLAenBWHg.text: the BEST Indian food ever!  my nephew and niece and I agree, it was the most delicious and memorable Indian food- not only was the food extraordinary but the owner Amrit gave that special touch to make us feel like guests.  All the staff were great. Any Americans who go to London MUST stop by lovely Covent Gardens and go to this restaurant-  it will be memorable.

p9gyoxDa5GU6FpwqMYA12Q.text: Really wanted to love this place, and although the food is good, it just doesn't justify the prices to me- I've been able to get some food that's just as nice or better for so much cheaper in London. Seating is very crowded, but I actually like that. Be prepared to wait if you have a big group or go on a weekend.

RolG2Pj6JVREGnQfw7lfjA.text: Good food for sure. We were 2 of us, and since we were not very hungry we ordered 2 Sweet Lassi, 1 Methi Gosht and 2 Bullet Naan. The portion size was good. Bullet Naan was quiet delicious.Definitely recommended.

FIp717rLWm4rvj6gXDKeXQ.text: Great service--exceptional.  We were there early (around 5:30) and they told us we could only have a table if we were done by 7:30.  This was blunt but to the point and I'd rather them say that then tell us no.  The service was great--within moments of asking, we had everything we needed.  We had the Daal, Malai Kofta, and one of the signature dishes (all from the vegetarian menu).  They were all solid.  Everything was on the spicy side (rather than creamy and sweet) and it was good.  Prices were reasonable.

AnxyZboqUcw8xkP61ngl5Q.text: We have heard a lot of good things regarding England and Indian food. My wife and I decided that we had to have it at least once during our UK vacation. Just by chance, right before our trip we saw a Food Network program that had a special on food in London. One of the places that they pointed out was Punjabi. We randomly ran into Punjabi while walking around, remembered it for the program, and decided to eat there. The food at Punjabi was really good and surprisingly cheap. At the end of the meal we were surprised at how low our bill was.We had the Samosas (a must get), the chicken tikka masala, and the saag paneer. All items were great. We shared a mango lassi as well (yum!). Recommended place to eat. We went on the later side and it wasn't TOO busy but I've heard if you good at prime dinner time it can be a bit crowded.

AJ0kEt62CczS7pR_NqU3KQ.text: Delicious meal...pumpkin puri appetizer, cheese Naan, Italian wine...when advising me about the Butter Chicken being bone in vs. Tiki Marsala boneless, waiter in error ordered the Tiki, they ended up providing me some of both to make up it for delicious and great service!  I'll be back for sure!

4wRiXUjMi0HmEMx5NakawQ.text: Indian cuisine lover, easily some of the best I have ever had. Great staff who clearly take pride in their food. Would give them 10000000 stars if I could

xo21urDLvK4rVSA3qkRGxA.text: Punjab was the start of my incredible Indian food adventures in London, and I'm so happy we got to try it! My friend and I came in sans reservation on Sunday around 7:30 PM, and it was totally fine. There were other diners in the restaurant, but it wasn't too full.We ordered the garlic chicken, butter chicken, garlic naan, and mango lassis, and everything was AMAZING. I did prefer the garlic chicken over the butter chicken, but both were great, and the naan was perfect for sopping up all the delicious sauce. Mango lassis were nothing inventive but still delicious and refreshing. Punjab's staff was also super helpful--giving us recommendations on things to do before we returned to our apartment later that evening and even chasing us out the restaurant to make sure we were headed in the right direction.If you're looking for authentic and delicious Indian food, don't miss it! :)

_f0AevKnwiJuld6j3XaayA.text: You absolutely have to make room on your busy itinerary for some Punjab! Honestly, prior to my trip to London, I never preferred to eat Indian food. However, Punjab has changed it all! In particular, their Chicken Tikka Masala! You cannot leave London without trying their Chicken Tikka Masala. The sauce is absolutely delicious with its creamy and flavorful texture. It isn't too spicy either if you regularly cannot handle heat.  To go with this, I actually preferred the spiced rice over the naan. I believe it's seasoned with cumin and maybe some turmeric. I am more of a rice than a bread person though. The only downside of this place is the service. They know they are the best so service isn't all too friendly and attentive. They also slap on an "Optional" service fee. We didn't bother asking them to remove it, considering how long it took to place our order and to get our bill. Nonetheless, this place is still worth check out!

WTvPm5bp9bTSs7TEtqzoxQ.text: Definitely the best Indian I had in London, and I hit no less than a dozen places.  The paneer makhani, my favorite, was top knotch.  You really can't go wrong here.  Definitely a great lunch choice.

YVCYQn2M-XtgZSykXaroMg.text: Was the only tikka masala I tried when in London, and judging by the taste and quality and I'm positive it's the only tikka masala you need to try when there. Also, impeccably fast service.

ccmthU-zSyVfF9Xxl1LmHw.text: Amazing Indian food!! So authentic in their cooking it was like my Indian friend was cooking for me in her home! I loved stopping here for a late dinner with friends, they had quick service and were able to accommodate a vegan diet. I got a menu for people with allergies, and ordered a chickpea dish with a side of rice. It was delicious! They warned me that the food I ordered is spicy, but it was perfect. We had our own dishes with naan to share, it was a perfect meal! Definitely come here if you're looking for Indian food in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

KMpw1RXxIqu8w4LtqW0vHA.text: Was recommended a trendy Indian restaurant which had a massive wait. Found Punjab on yelp and was absolutely delighted. Wait was less than they said, service was spot on, atmosphere was great and food was fantastic!

h27cYotmLTU5QrJu7Fgx2Q.text: We came here on a recent trip to London. My family is Indian and we had heard about all the great Indian restaurants in London and had received a recommendation for this restaurant from a friend. We ordered the butter chicken, saag aloo, daal, and paneer tikka masala. Everything was delicious and very authentic. One of the best meals we had on our vacation.

hewyBpdUs1vzfjO4NHslaA.text: We are recent connoisseurs of Indian cuisine and this place is very very good. Service was quick the food was delicious ....what else can we ask for.   Just make sure you get there early because by the time we left there was a queue of about 20 people out front door.

KebtLNxZkIayog4Auj2JQw.text: A bit overrated thought it was decent Indian food.  Dishoom is way better go there instead.  Chicken Tikka Masala was kind of bland.

UC-S8srhVrUEYFicibGnuQ.text: My Boyfriend and me loved the delicious vegetarian meal. Thanks a lot as well for the polite service. We are coming back

UAuaWIhpTsI1SHuu_Ag3Jg.text: I ate here on my recent trip to London and had an amazing dinner.  The papadums and accompanying chutneys were nice and light, perfect for a summer meal.  The entrees were fantastic as well; if you are a fan of lamb, try the Karahi Gosht, or if you prefer meatless dishes, try Granddad's Kali Daal.  Both are excellent.  My favorite part of the meal, however, was the mango lassi.  It's definitely the best I've had so far.

aG2ed7c5peNnI8ukZAnWgQ.text: Best Chicken Tikka Masala EVER! I swear every time I eat at a new Indian Restaurant in London it just gets better and better. The tikka masala sauce here has some spice to it and is very addicting. The naan bread however, was probably the worst I've had. It was too hard to tear and not soft at all. I'd probably go here again just for the chicken tikka masalaanitaeat.com

IpDVobM8B7oi_XasXv-Xuw.text: I've only eaten here once - and I don't even remember the name of the dish I ordered.  It was one of the recommended ones, and it was good.However nowhere near as good as how much it cost.  Maybe 3 quid is standard in London for a plate of plain white rice, but this meal was only marginally better than what I normally pay half as much for.

H5fTsL84qETU1BvJ4Vu5wA.text: This place COULD actually be amazing. The flavors of their curries are very good and the naan is of excellent quality. However, I personally feel that they skimp on ingredient quality and charge prices that would indicate higher quality. I had a fish curry and a vegetable medley made mostly of canned or frozen peas, corn and carrots. Just not up to standard for the prices that they are charging and for the quality of food that they have the potential to produce.

fseNLFdnA5C7QlYUJWljdQ.text: Had great lunch here at Punjab...  The curries were thick and complex.  The many different filled naan was nice, my favorite being the coconut fruit filled.  It went very nicely with the curry surprisingly.  Desserts were excellent here... the milk soaked cake was my favorite as well as the icecreams.  Service was good and nice ambiance.  Overall, would recommend.

-LXm-225ONFxC4d8s2vxaQ.text: I came to Punjab in search of some good Indian food after a few buffet letdowns. Ordered the Acharri Murgha -- a nicely spiced chicken curry -- at the waiter's recommendation, along with rice, chapati and chilli naan. I really enjoyed the fresh ginger flavour of the curry and the chilli naan added a nice level of spice. I would have liked to keep the dishes coming all night, but on my very limited college student's budget, I couldn't afford to do so... In any case, this place gave me a taste of the good Indian food I've been looking for in London.

baS02NNul0ry2XnaHXxupw.text: Authentic Indian food served by real Indians! This is by far my favourite indian restaurant in Central London. When I want punjabi food, this is my first choice. Lovely staff, always very friendly & helpful, and lovely food every time. Prices are also quite decent for the quality. I have been there already many times and so far, was never disappointed so I'll keep coming back.

NREAunRMU9N_jMiD4yGXvw.text: Great Indian food & great service! Naan, butter chicken, veggie samosas, chicken korma were all delicious. Service was attentive & they treated our school aged children respectfully. Highly recommend.

lL9aHAJEQ6SnpZ8L7j3FNA.text: Strictly talking portion to price - I think Punjab falls a bit short. I thought the dishes were pretty small considering how pricey the restaurant was, and I wasn't expecting only 2 pieces of naan per order. The Chicken Tikka Masala was tasty, seasoned well, but pretty heavy on the tomato for my preference. Other items on the menu were satisfying, but nothing that was memorable. I wish my husband and I experienced the same hospitality I've been reading in previous reviews. Our server was not friendly by any means. The next time we visit London, unfortunately we will not be returning here.

GS132q5h5KAkWouH3xN4hQ.text: Some of the best Chicken Tikka Masala I've had in my life... I took my friends who had never eaten Indian food before and converted them to the point that they still talk about this place from our study abroad days. Delectable and reasonably priced, which goes a long way in London!

w5fZf5-Mh_QU8DmCwwJevw.text: Stay away!Yelp let me down! I was fooled by the great reviews and brought 7 Americans here who had never had Indian food in London. I am so sad that they now think London has nothing better to offer than the mediocre fare Punjab had to offer.It was truly gross stuff. Poor quality ingredients, greatly watered down, and served in a big rush by impatient waiters who pushed more food than we needed by claiming portions were smaller than they were.

hwYAcNGPt2UvyfyYXA_zGQ.text: Perhaps not the topping best, but still most excellent food, good friendly service and a nice feel to the place. Mango lassi is quite good, as is the mutter panneer. Watch out for the madras sauce, though. It's not hot at first, but has a cumulative burn.  Also a really good aloo tikka.  If you are in Covent Garden and fancy a curry, this should be on your short list, especially at such a low cost.

rbganFhY5TOFv1yGB_UKlw.text: Had a great dinner here although extremely loud and had to share a table with two other diners. Probably the Christmas party goers. Never seen so many Cobra beers at once. Great food.

huUcF5LuDqVM2lX6T2SADQ.text: This place was a BIG let down. I went here based on the Yelp reviews. I love Indian food, however, this version was pretty bad. What's with all the lime? Even the hot towels had lime. Everything tasted like it was laced with Pledge furniture cleaner. Nasty.

YP6SEFfX4o2ECsXcDQrfHw.text: Usually i am very stingy with 5 stars ... and i feel that this one is also a borderline case ... but what the heck; this is the very best Indian restaurant in London where i can afford to eat every week if i want. That itself makes it a ***** material :)You must make a reservation before going. The place is small and there is always a crowd waiting outside. You can frequently spot a tall burly Indian guy there ... me :)The person who guides patrons to their tables is a little rude sometime (especially when you are late) ... but given how busy and stressed he seems to be running the place, i can forgive him.The food is fabulous ... everything i have tasted there till date is good. Not a bad dish at all. Be it the chicken tikka starters or the kaddu-puri or the main courses.Punjab claims that its "granddad's kaali dal" is their best product. Its good, but i don't find it special. On the other hand, i would strongly recommend the tandoori paratha.Another of its positives. Punjab makes the best mutton biryanis i have had in London, or anywhere out of India for that matter. Indian restaurants in London usually spoil the biryanis by making them too dry (an extra dish of bad curry that they serve alongside does not make up for it). Punjab is an exception.The prices are a little on the higher side than comparable Indian restaurants (you can easily spend £25 or more person) ... but totally worth it.

ozzX4fSZ8xL0nJsCT61IJw.text: What a fine, upstanding bunch of people the staff and owners are. A friendly, busy joint serving fantastically fresh food. They were busy & booked up and still made space for us when other places didn't want to know. If my prawn madras had been any fresher it would have swum off........a big five stars to The Punjab!

iELIvdy_w8UAkb7beqO7nQ.text: Very good Indian food.  Much better quality than anything you'll find on Brick Lane, while still being reasonably priced.  Vegetable dishes like the Chickpeas and aubergine dishes are fantastic and the chicken and lamb dishes are delicious without being too oily.

RaovZI56n5jDsdlbuUdjQw.text: Not good at all. From arrival we had to ask several times for menus and for our drinks order to be taken. We all ordered popadoms and the relishes that accompanied them were of the cheap, wet and low taste variety. Very disappointing. The main chicken curry I had was OK but nothing special. The three of us ordered plain, garlic and peshwari naans respectively. They all turned up in a single bowl and it was hard to tell which of the dry and unappealing segments was which. Little taste.Had much better food and service at almost every other curry establishment.Will not go again.

xAypAD9SLRN1jdCrPTMbvQ.text: Definitely my favorite Indian restaurant in central London! I studied abroad in London for a semester in early 2009 and now that I'm back in California, Punjab is one of the top restaurants in London that I dream of coming back to. Yes, I'm that big of a fan :P The service is great, we thoroughly enjoyed the humor of the bartender and the owner(?)/greeter guy. And the food is SO amazingly delicious. The channa masala and the korma dishes were particularly drool-worthy. The naan is also quite tasty (check out the description of the garlic naan on the menu - they advise you not to eat their "extreme" garlic naan if you have "erotic activities" planned for the night!) The decor is also very warm and welcoming. You really can't go wrong here :) Ps. The restaurant is fairly small, so I wouldn't recommend any groups larger than 6 people.

GSxlXqpSjqSsR7UUm_weng.text: Was really looking forward to coming here based on the reviews. The food was very good but I was slightly underwhelmed. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala. While tasty, I think that it smelled a lot like canned tomato soup which turned me off a bit. Hubby had some lamb dish and he said it was good but nothing to write home about. I thought that the best part of my meal was the bread- I got a coconut stuffed naan that was good but kind of greasy on the top. I would come back here but I would probably try some other places before coming back. The service was very good.

fNatdMi9cdVc_jC2KtJX8A.text: Ok I first have to say that this review is 1 year old lol. That alone should tell you how much I loved this restaurant, I still think about it all the time! I went to this restaurant last year when visiting London and out of my whole trip my absolute favorite meal was eaten here!!! Their butter chicken!!! It was so delicious I cannot speak highly enough about it! Peshwari naan did not disappoint either. And the mango lassi! Everything was so amazing I seriously enjoyed it so much!! If I am ever in London again this is a MUST go. Service and decor were great as well. Love this restaurant so much and wish they had one in California!

PO50-6TrmDVomAy-JWWXjQ.text: Amazing cuisine and even better service. Chicken Tikka Masala and Acharri Ghost was fantastic. Make sure you get the Bullet Naan if you're into spice. Santana is the best!

FG2F9dob28ft-v8tYFrzZg.text: Had lunch with my husband at Punjab today...Ambiance was nice enough and the restaurant was about 1/3 full on a Wednesday afternoon at 2pm.Service isn't friendly AT ALL ... not sure why? Food was pretty good but the biggest problem was that the spice level was pretty intense. If my mouth hadn't been on fire the whole time I was eating I surely would have enjoyed the chole, the bhindi, and the aloo gobi much more. The rice and naan were good (no spice obviously).Prices are quite reasonable.Overall I just wish the food wasn't so spicy! If we could somehow get mild food we'd definitely return.

-zQXTx6NVKcxWuJs4TNjcA.text: We came to this restaurant after reading Yelp reviews. Arrived at about 6:30pm, one party ahead of us. Despite seeing several open tables we were told to wait, and took about 20 minutes to seat the 3 of us. The ambience was good, and the food aroma was inviting. We ordered buttered chicken which consisted of two medium sized pieces of chicken that was covered with the yellow spiced curry, but dry on the inside. We also ordered the goat tandoori which came in 4 kebabs, well seasoned but very salty. Also ordered buttered naan and sweet naan, both just okay. The service was definitely a low light, had to ask for water 3 times, and they never came by to refill. The bill came quickly though, and surprised to find they already added tip. Overall not impressed with the food, bad service, definitely not recommended and would not come back.

TKVBQ8SaPT_cwqJhPAByRQ.text: Awesome. We tried another restaurant that had super long lines. We happened to be walking by some locals who said that line is ridiculous. Especially since the food is better. We walked with them and were very happy we did.

aeNeSSNPvCPfvCBkRai3lw.text: What a great place! We are visiting from Los Angeles, and saw results on Yelp. We knew we had to have curry at some point during our trip, and we weren't disappointed. Even without reservations, we were quickly ushered to a table and food came our perfectly -- savory, flavorful, and delicious! We ordered the pumpkin on bread, butter chicken (savory as it should be , not sweet), methi gosht (might not be spelling this correctly!), bullet naan (garlic and chilis! Heaven!!), aloo paratha, and butter naan. This was enough for dinner and some leftovers for tomorrow :) Besides that, the owner and staff are wonderful -- friendly and good-natured. Definitely recommend this place!
