Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Savory and mild Butter chicken and methi gosht (flavorful fenugreek lamb dish). Also, some bullet naan (garlic and green chilis)

Jf8_ruGtJsa33y9_S-Zq3g.text: Really delicious authentic Indian food. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys this type of cuisine. And I will visit any time I'm in London.

fQAk4htgLffdv-_mRqYZ9g.text: Tried to get into dishoom but was 2.5 hr wait.  This was a great 2nd choice.  Just 10min wait, food was great as was the service.

SGgjvFl_pCJjae0yiXCC2A.text: Simply amazing. Cannot say enough good things about quite possibly the best meal, and hands down the best Indian cuisine I have ever tasted.We ordered off the vegetarian menu. The paneer and dhal lentils were to die for. Our group left nothing to spare - it was all so good.Our servers were attentive and hospitable (amazing!) and our group was even able to chat with the owner before we were seated, and as we were leaving. A very nice man with a lot to be proud of! I will remember this meal forever. Thank you Punjab!

BwlcJD71vo9RK8c7opQ0NQ.text: Overpriced. Below average food. The taste is blended.Not very attentive service, server seemed annoyed after couple questions about the menu from us.Seems a lot of people come here for pre show dinner only, most of them finished meal really fast.One positive star is their interior design is quite nice.

f-kTvyy7Sq2A6wKBDJYWoA.text: Punjab has been highly recommended by so many travel articles including Condé Nast Traveler. So naturally I had to try this place out! My sister and I absolutely loved their delicious, fragrant dishes. My favorite dishes were their Chicken Tikka Masala and Grandad's Kali Daal! These dishes were so powerful in flavor. You won't be disappointed with these two! Service was excellent. Would recommend this place to anyone visiting London! Can't wait to come back!

7Y4ZqRdyQaKoG4jAY699mw.text: Awesome atmosphere. Quick wait outside. They keep things moving. Very clean, and great attention to detail. Food was excellent. Highly recommend

67FOmXX2tOZTudwKPF-_OA.text: Great food and service.  Their menu has some bold font items that are specialties.  They are awesome!  Affordable food. Popular and a good location. Happy we made this stop!!!

vdc2cAQY--v9eP0ehuS9Ag.text: Excellent Indian food in London.  One of our children does not like Indian food. But even she greatly enjoyed the lentils, samosas, and other items. We had a blast at this nice restaurant.

mamivSs-eORrLfi4kkj3iw.text: Had the itch for some Indian food, after searching for a few in the London area, I found this. I made my way from the hotel which was a quick 10 minutes via Uber, arrived and was quickly seated.The waiter took my order, I ordered a plate that I will do it some justice and won't even attempt to name it because I asked the waiter for something he would recommend and I believe it was curry lamb. I told me what the name of the plate was but I'll be honest, it flew past my head, all I know is that the plate came with naan, some rice, and the lamb in some orange curry sauce.I loved it, the food was really good, the service quick and the cost wasn't too bad, for dessert I had some mango kulfi which was also delicious.

ntDwGkKHANqN3N7RfTgVbg.text: Great food and ambiance in a very busy street with lots of choices. Recommend stopping here first

IRNKMtP050QzUjI7V7Khjw.text: We loved Punjab!! The food was excellent and service was fast and very friendly. We had the Acharri Gosht and loved it!

D23cq1IZmQ6mVC6qczdTMQ.text: My wife and I have a tradition where we go to the Punjab before going to see a West End show. We get here at 6, and we leave with plenty of time to get to the theatre before curtain up.The food is always great, and the staff are extremely welcoming. It's no wonder this in the the UK's oldest North Indian restaurant.

UeM-0ikKAw-_wLRwKV4LNQ.text: After walking around London by myself for hours, I stopped in at Punjab for lunch. The staff was polite and prompt, and the food was delicious. I got the acharri gosht (lamb curry) with garlic naan. The naan was thinner than what I'm used to, but whatever. The location is nice too--lots of shops nearby and close to the British Museum.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

elb0n2Qzu-zPFGn28OBo5A.text: This was a really great restaurant. They only take a handful of reservations ahead of time, but when I called they said that 50% of their tables are available for walk ins. We arrived on a Thursday and got in within a few mins. The food was sooooooo yummy. Loved the vegetable kofta and chicken tikka masala. The dal was very good too and the garlic naan made things really complete. The service was attentive and kept things going. Would highly recommend coming here for quality Indian eats!

gXOfJCoT5sZHBWrlcF97Vg.text: This had the best chicken tikka masala that i've ever had. Real good service in a nice part of town. Excellent. Wife had the muhtar paneer, which was also very good. The samosas leave something to be desired, but other than that, its brilliant!

Rds_gI2Trr4P2Qg9S7asHA.text: Coming off a disappointing curry house the night before, I was hopeful my experience at Punjab would turn things around. It did.The food was amazing. I had Grandad's Kali Daal, and even though I'm not normally a vegetarian, I was blown away by this meal. It was rich, not overly creamy (most likely yogurt-based), and perfectly cooked. The lentils were firm to the bite but thoroughly stewed. The naan was the right balance of pliable, but crunchy. Even the plain basmati rice I ordered was perfectly cooked.The service was punctual, but as others have noted, it could have been friendlier. The waitstaff wasn't rude, just cold and non-interactive. I would have given Punjab 5-stars had the service been better. But everyone there was so aloof, I docked them a star just on that one aspect.The interior is intimate and cozy. Nothing mind-blowing but very relaxing.All-in-all, Punjab restaurant is well worth the visit if you're seeking a well-priced, authentic, delicious stop on your culinary tour of London.

P-v6bW-pBnmSX-kySlRdAg.text: Sometimes it's easy to forget what a great Indian meal is when there is so much mediocre out there. Glad to say that after tonight I have been reminded again. Their no reservation system works because their service is so efficient, so even though it was Friday and they were rammed, we didn't wait too long. Food was very tasty, chicken succulent, sauces just right without relying on over spicing and naan supper fresh. A great curry house in the centre of theatre district - but given that it's been going since 1946 you probably don't need me to tell you that.

nwLYSl-_WjZPLjkG5KNalw.text: Good food with decent service. You won't be sorry you came but there's probably some better Indian in london , they did have air conditioning during the heat wave in london while we were there. If you're nearby its worth the eat.

lSO_htTKSbZWm23S1nPQLQ.text: Decent food. Rude and curt staff. Didn't check in one between ordering food and drinks and when I asked for the bill. When I asked for the bill, the waiter finally asked if I wanted I refill on my drink which I had finished 20 minutes earlier. There are better places in London with less entitled staff.

5yqLM13QJS_Df8W3vcOwBA.text: I do not know what all the hype is about. We had a reservation and were seated in a lovely room. When the food came we were shocked to see only 1 naan for 2 people. That's just weird. I ordered the Tikka chicken and it was OK, it wasn't anything to write home about. It was just OK. It was so quiet during lunch that it really was no fun. I will never go back again. Keep your hype, I'll just go to my amazing neighbourhood place that's yet to be discovered.

Hwq5IqX1c_2IY4ZMQhrirA.text: 3.5 stars.So Saturday around 7:45 pm for a table of 2 there was only about a 10 minute wait. My recommendation is to book in advance for sure no matter what party size you are because why not? The line can get quite long and it isn't entirely predictable, so might as well be safe.Shortly after we got in the line, it became quite long quite quickly. A group of about 10 behind us was told it would be a 1.5 - 2 hour wait.Now the people here are mostly fun and jovial. There are a couple of servers who were a bit cold and impatient, but generally speaking people are smiley and friendly. The expediter at the front who passes the dishes to the servers is super friendly. The food here is really interesting - you'll see things here that they don't have elsewhere and vice versa. I would recommend actually going with a Punjabi dish here instead of something you can get anywhere (like a generic tikka masala or korma). We went with the acharri murgha and chicken malai tikka.Acharri Murgha - an classic Punajbi pickle-style chicken, medium spiced, and a bit tangy. Now let me say a word about the "pickle-style" - the sauce is flavoured with pickles in the cooking process, but there are no actual pickles in it. The pickle taste is also certainly not overwhelming, which I was really afraid of. This was a delicious, unique, flavorful dish and I would highly recommend it. I haven't tasted much like it before and I would absolutely get it again.Chicken Malai Tikka - chicken breast marinated with cream, cheese, and yoghurt, cooked in the tandoori and served sizzling with onions on a skillet. This dish was just ok, but nothing special. I expected much more from the dish. The chicken was super soft, tender, and creamy, but there wasn't a lot of flavour and it wasn't interesting.The hariyali chicken tikka really caught my eye, but I was too afraid to try it because it's apparently a very very strong coriander taste (with some mint as well) and some of the servers seemed to think it could be overwhelming.We also got steamed rice and naan, which I wouldn't say was one of the better ones I've had.Overall though, I was very happy with the meal, the staff, and the acharri. I'd definitely recommend giving this place a try.

W4EVAzqg5uDqtzz9TKhPaA.text: Went with wife and daughter last week while visiting from US.  Food was Tip Top, I had the chicken tika masala which was tender and tasty.  Wife had butter chicken which she enjoyed.  Duaghter enjoyed her eggplant dish,  Apps were delicious and plentiful.  Highlight of the meal was the Naan, which had coconut and dried fruit.  When we return this summer to London I plan on going back.

g6T7RdcaOLjYnsCi2FgGhQ.text: While on my first ever trip in London, I felt the experience could not be complete without an Indian food tasting.  The English food had thus far proved to be a mediocre affair, but I had heard great things about the Indian food.  While strooling through Covenant Gardens I noticed many street signs attempting to lure tourist into other Indian restaurants; Punjab did not engage in this practice but I was lured to it all the same.Punjab is a fourth generation family owned restaurant and bears the title of being the oldest Punjabi restaurant in England, which I think is very cool.  The menu is quite extensive with over 100 different options to try and each choice complete with is own colorful description about how succulent the dish is.  And, the food was amazing.  I ordered the Acharri Murgha because it was quoted as a once in a lifetime experience, and I have nothing to say against it.  Also, props go the management who provided my mother with an off the menu version of chicken tikka that was free of spice sicne she cannot tolerate any.The pricing is expensive and all naan and rice is done a la carte which add to the price.  The beer, however, is reasonable.  I had a Cobra, it complemented the dishes.

sw3DHbCih75UMFEaZbeDXw.text: Wanted to go to Dishoom but they don't take reservations for under 6 people and despite being told that they turn around tables quickly, there was an hour long line outside. That's just a huge waste of time so we Yelped nearby and settled on Punjab. Glad we did because it was several plates full of awesome.There were three of us and we ordered the right amount of food: two chicken dishes, two veggie dishes, rice and naan. We even had desert. Everything was excellent including the pickles for the popadoms.I am very pleased that they had air conditioning upstairs since it would otherwise have been unbearably hot.

GU9_3bm5Z7m18m8IPv8ukw.text: Excellent chicken tikka masala. Definitely one of the better restaurants in London. However, must get there early to beat the crowd. Very clean and quaint.

D0jkVI3ApvX5TwnQS28P5A.text: We dined at this restaurant after freshly arriving from Paris to London for the first time.  We looked for good Indian restaurants on Yelp! and this was a well reviewed one.  We had a 20 minute walk from the hotel to this place and decided to stop for a fruit juice on the way (my wife was starving and it was hot).  As soon as we got into the restaurant, one of the server rudely said "No outside drinks allowed".  And then continued to tell us that we can go drink it outside and come back.  When I say rudely, I mean he was kind of ordering us and making us feel uncomfortable as if we just sneaked a drink in at the Movie Theater.  So that was a bad first impression.  The Menu looked good though.  Much more choices than usual.  I ordered Kadai Chicken with Garlic Naan and my wife ordered some Yellow Daal with Chappati.  The Daal, Chappati, and the Garlic Naan were good.  The Kadai Chicken, on the other hand, was really bad.  I could barely bite into the chicken it was so hard.  After our first bad impression, the service was not bad.  I think it is important to treat your customers with respect and "ask" them to "please" refrain from bringing outside drinks instead of ordering them and making them feel uncomfortable in front of other customers.The food that was good was average.  The food that was bad really takes the rating down another star.  And the outside drink incidence takes down another star.

GpeQMgXiYg7_6ZWw2VqQyQ.text: After two days in London on vacation, my mother and I experienced one of the most incredible meals. Punjab is not to be missed. Right around the corner from the hotel and pretty centralized to everything else (such as Covent Garden and Holborn) it is incredible. We had chicken tikka masala which was fantastic, garlic naan that was soft, crunchy and delicious, and another type of chicken coated in mint and coriander. It came out sizzling, warm and tender. Perfect. Why hadn't we come here earlier?Highly recommend this place for anyone local or anyone visiting the area. Oh and the service is outstanding. Attentive and patient. Gets the job done. A+

Exn3whNawpdemR69BOVW5A.text: Food was tasty, but service was lacking.I got the butter chicken and the saag paneer.  The butter chicken was as advertised, two pieces of bone-in chicken smothered in a creamy butter sauce.  The saag paneer had a decent kick to it.  I saw someone get the chicken tikka special, I think I will get that next time with a side of masala as one of the other reviewers recommended.Worth a stop if your unsure which quick Indian place you want to jump into.

P5ne29SEEDnqPuFJJ_iiTg.text: Every time I'm in London this is a must stop for a terrific Indian meal. Service is always great and why I've been coming back for 10+ years.

P6YyIgu7Ypfn4f6sfPAcqw.text: My family and I were looking for some great indian food on our recent trip to London, but didn't want to make the trek to Whitechapel. Thanks to yelp, we found Punjab in a fantastic location near Oxford st. The place was busy, and we were seated right away even though we didn't have a reservation. The servers were nice, and the food was great. Definitely order the butter chicken (although our bowl only had two pieces of chicken). We ordered the garlic naan, despite the funny tip on the menu. The garlic isn't really as strong as the menu warns, so I wouldn't worry about not getting any action after the meal! I would definitely return!

NstjHF1Q0fiL1N64mpCpMw.text: If you are craving a curry in Central London, this is probably your best bet.  Lamb chops came sizzling to the table. Tasty!

yhRDnkiP28UA1Pw0rSdk6A.text: We really enjoyed this restaurant! This was our first meal in London and we had heard that London has some great Indian food. We wanted to go to Dishoom, but couldn't get in. In retrospect, we are glad we landed on this place. We were able to get in without a reservation. The bartender that greets customers as they walk in was very friendly. The service was excellent. We had 3 waiters/servers for our table of two. The food came out speedy fast. I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and my girlfriend ordered Chicken Tandoori. We were both very pleased. It was very tasty. We also had an order of the garlic naan which was standard. The prices were reasonable (just under £30 for two). I would definitely recommend Punjab to anyone that is in the London area and in the mood for Indian food.

y5rDQ_M7ZgsIeqAeJQwAEA.text: Touted as UK's oldest North Indian restaurant, Punjab is really just upscale Indian food. There are variations on the naan and the basmati rice is overpriced, but you can't argue with the well cooked curry. My acharri gosht was perfectly cooked and the lamb was tender. While my brain was telling me that cottage cheese did not belong in gravy, butter, and cream, the paneer makhani was delicious and tasted more like tofu. The prices were a bit high for what you get, but at least the food tasted good.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Paneer makhani, gobi aloo, acharri gosht

4V4Xi1lOBQsetO4_UhqGLg.text: I've been here a few times and it's always busy.  The food is pretty tasty. However  It is standard  North Indian fare with a few unusual dishes thrown in.  We had chicken Madras,  chicken Korma  and a couple of veggie dishes-saag aloo and mushroom masala.  I  asked for the Madras to be extra hot. Usually this can result in a psychotic chef's revenge by emptying the entire tub of chili powder in the dish,  or alternatively  it remains resolutely pretty mild.  This Madras was bang on.   The food was very well put together.  It does what it says on the tin.  Prices are a little high though.  Service is harassed though reasonably friendly.  You can do a lot worse than the Punjab,  though if you're looking for more cutting edge Indian food then look elsewhere.

8eWNb4Vhf8eh4R7LfQobKw.text: Manager is up front rushing everyone in and tells you quite bluntly that he has a table but you must be out by a certain time. The idea behind it is that he must rotate the tables 2-3 times for dinner, and it shows. Wether the food is good or bad is irrelevant, you can't enjoy it when waiters are staring you down for you to leave! As soon as you put your fork down, they are at your table to clean up. We refused to tell them that we were done, 5 times in less than 7 minutes, just to let our food go down to your stomach,We were seated in the back room, which has 4 long tables, canteen style. There is a thick carpet in the room and dust accumulates on the black side boards on the walls .. disgusting. This place has a lot of potential, but when managed as it is, is just plain sad.Save your money and go eat somewhere else, there are better places in London.

uvBoEHAzjVaklhvLzuDqcg.text: Punjab what can I say. Good quality food but Shitty service. We were forgotten(4 tables who arrived after us received their food before us wtf). They also charged our table for an additional naan.....that we never ate)... I never ever write bad reviews but after tonight's dinner I have to. I was so hungry and sad that the staff forgot about our table that I started to tear. Bye punjAb. I'll go to dishoom

V2KCUUBt38q9hXsSQVN2oQ.text: This place was very good. I came here with my family on our way to the British Museum

y_FiLVyg7Q3_6NLBYLMGRA.text: Great Indian restaurant with a very differentiated menu, for every kinda of taste! Excellent quality-price considering that it is settled in the heart of London. Friendly place, excellent both for a dinner with friends or a more serious occasion.

QYiZ4Gw4M3yUy7Fiuaq8Yg.text: Food is okay. Butter chicken ... Meh ... It's alright . And then . Well . Food quality is alright ! It's just the staff Is the reason I downgraded this review from a 4 to a 2. To begin with, in 5 mins , the same waiter asked 3 times : are u ready to order . ( as if I am in his way if I don't ) And when I asked for recommendation and asking what the indian dishes were ( I was searching on my phone earlier ) , and then he fucking took my phone and then did some tapping ( hard!) and then satisfied himself with what he found as a " bangai" food pic and then threw my iPhone 6s on the table ! Basically he has used my phone without my permission and Hey ! Throwing it back ! That was raging !! And then when we ordered , me and my friend said one only even after he said it s too small for both of us, and we said no, and when he confirmed the order , he just was like : 2 naan yeh ? I was like ONE !!!!! And then he asked what we want to drink and we don't feel like ordering any beverages but just tap water . He shot this look of " order so little !" At us ( at this point , it is pretty subjective ) . Anyways . Got through the end ... And then once they quickly cleared the table , there stood the dessert menu and when we said no , next thing on table was the bill, even we didn't ask for it. We didn't touch the bill for like 2 mins cuz me and my mate were chatting . This staff interrupted and was like : everything alright ? There are people waiting outside . We were very upset by the service . Probably won't go again .  This kind of fast food restaurant is not what we look for and customer service still trumps commercialized food ! Even fast food allows u to sit for awhile. And besides , had better Indian food around the area .

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

_ChUySbSPGKBHupZHtlXBA.text: Same as others had reviewed, we originally went to Dishoom down the street, but had a 40 minute wait at 10pm. Came here and were blown away by the flavors.  Great service accompanied fantastic food. I highly recommend!

CBWp-DkUGcSKKk1n9i9fIQ.text: Very good food! Actually best food I had in London! Service was excellent! Very friendly and polite!

siIQbmGkSehY6xwjzVolvw.text: The service was friendly, and the food was delicious. The portions are perfect, had plenty of food. It was very congested inside, very tiny tables with barely any room to walk around, which is probably because so many people are enjoying the great food.

EAeICwsesR7eDyvMKZEMNA.text: My first taste of authentic Indian food was at Punjab and it certainly didn't disappoint! Holy moly, the food amazing and the service was friendly. I ordered the lamb curry (which was extra spicy) and the white rice as well as the chicken tikka and a side of naan bread. Everything was delicious. I dream of the day I get back to London and go over to Covent Garden to get my Indian food fix on.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Menu.
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka masala and white rice. Lamb curry on the side.

22Xvs4B69Bfos1ssEoHxmQ.text: Great service and food. The cheese Naan is a must.No reservation was needed, came in and was sat right away.

_ac6MXanc9REelqGO10UPA.text: This two-story restaurant is good, and apparently very established. It is not my favorite by a long shot (try Indian Express in West Kensington), but I would go there again if I was in the area. Service was sufficient, but not as refined as some of the Indian restaurants I've been to recently.The portions were generous, and the Acharri Ghost (lamb) had delicious flavor without being too hot, although the lamb itself was just a bit tough. The Chicken Tikka Masala was good as well. I really liked the Grandad's Kali Dall, and I ladled it over my Pilau Rice to form a great concoction. I have no idea if this is the proper way to eat it, but it worked nicely and nobody kicked me out.Long story short, this place can leave you walking away happy, but I can't guarantee that you'll fall in love.

uUllRPpNvTLIUKEyHYRe0Q.text: Excellent food, amazing service, authentic and reliable quality food.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

ENMyuOUvXPw2uNzNTnG8Uw.text: I always visit the Punjab whenever I go to London. Did is always good and service outstanding. The Methi Lamb is my personal favourite. I would not go anywhere else in central London.

1lC-FPrOrWV7bZJCo744gA.text: This restaurant was recommended by many on a recent trip. It was good but for sure did not live up to the hype. Service was excellent but food lacked spices and depth. If you like blander food this is the spot for you.

kR0dHhmgei1tTrrpuHBCHw.text: We came here based on the reviews and proximity to our hotel.I enjoyed the food here but not sure if it's the best Indian curry I've ever had. I know there's many types of curries from different regions but I guess Punjab is not my favorite. It's a little too tomatoe-y for my taste.I've never been to an Indian restaurant where I had to pay extra for white rice. The rice usually comes with the curry. And not only that but when we got the bill, the rice was 3 pounds so that's about $5 USD for just white rice. We ordered two. If we had known, I would have gotten more naan instead. Some of the naan were cheaper than white rice.The service was ok. Nothing great.The place seemed pretty touristy. No one at the nearby tables were English. They were either Japanese, American or Swedish (?).

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken on the left and chicken tikka masala on right

cG6SdsQ62kcpGBKojwR0_w.text: We wanted to go to Homeslice around the corner but the wait was too long and so decided to go here instead since there was sort of a small queue and we always passed by it wanting to try it out. The food is good. The daal Makhani tastes like my moms and that almost brought tears to my eyes :') the service is O-Kay at best and the ambience is also a bit strange. Overall good food, but I don't know if I'll go back again!

p-jL7ZKbijie-n1Zd6aSdA.text: Very friendly welcome and attentive service for my family of 5 children under 13yrs old on a busy Friday night at 8:30pm. So thankful!!! Great depth of flavor in every dish we tried - butter chicken, tikka masala, black lentil dal, samosas, mango lassis, even the cheese naan. A bit too spicy for my kids after growing accustomed to our favorite Indian in blandly spiced Germany. Easy to get to from Tube station nearby.

etacy0SYy9mhw9lc3ZzXkw.text: So so so good! Cool looking space, very clean and seems like they have two waiters per table, so you are well taken care of. Very reasonable prices if not on the cheaper side for the high quality. I will for sure be back!

Y24KlgeQcwSGda8kLR8cjQ.text: We ordered the butter chicken along with chicken marsala accompanied by rice and naan, of course. I really enjoyed the butter chicken, it had flavor but I definitely wouldn't consider it "spicy." I will admit that I don't have the most refined Indian pallette in the world but the chicken marsala sauce tasted much like the sauce in a can of SpaghettiOs if we're being honest. The service from the staff was excellent. They seated us immediately and made sure we were always looked after. The meal was relatively costly for what I expected, about £35 for the two of us.

ktwdixUFhWBqucZhJp7gPA.text: Came here cus I saw it on TV. I have 0 regrets! Service great and the food so so tasty! Id love to go back! And i will!

ThRz6j_ZiZErrx7F0LKViw.text: Some might erroneously call me unadventurous for never straying from my order of chicken tikka masala at an Indian restaurant. Others might correctly recognize that I simply wanted to honor "a true British national dish" (shout out to you, former British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook) in one of the world's most multicultural cities.Dishoom is definitely the more popular Indian restaurant in London, but I didn't want to risk having to wait for a table. Punjab fit the bill perfectly. We were promptly seated and ordered chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, garlic naan, and rice. The garlic naan was so good that it has now ruined all other kinds of naan for me. Both of our curry dishes included succulent, juicy chicken. While the butter chicken was extremely flavorful, I wish we would've gotten a vegetable dish instead because it started tasting a little repetitive. If you're torn between Punjab and the Dishoom in Covent Garden a few blocks from Leicester Square (even if you're already in line for Dishoom), don't hesitate to give Punjab a try. The decor here looks a bit traditional and outdated compared to Dishoom's trendy atmosphere, but you can't go wrong with the curry at Punjab.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Garlic naan, rice, butter chicken, and chicken tikka masala

hEUtqtPOxx9Is0ATTfJR8w.text: Was pleasantly surprised at the menu . Service good food nice but lacked the Punjabi kick for what the name  stands for . The so called  head manager/ waiter was loud and was sure walking a thin line as he talked , and chided others in Hindi ,not realizing we knew Hindi . The bill came with an option of a tip . Purposely put in a 50 pound to see if I would be asked  ,but to my surprise there was no option asked and I was given one pound less by the man who was chiding others , pity there was no one to tick him off . Well I guess that's Punjab  in 1946

SLBEdx73_sUY8LPnNTRLNw.text: One of the best if not the best Indian mealI have had. The shrimp tandoori were out of this world. #londonturist

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

Du6rc9Ra9sxwMk5cXf1i0A.text: As tourist at London, we wanted to taste authentic Indian cuisine since all my good friends told me that the Indian food in London is better than that of native food at India. When we stopped at Trafalgar Square which is 10 minuets walk to the restaurant, it's time to try this one. The lamb biryani was very good, chicken tikka masala was good too, less tasteful than I expected, curry lamb was tender and tasty. Decent quality and portion. The service was fast and courteous, environment was casual.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

SmP4Cn04nA-QJx4WvlYrpQ.text: Walked over to Punjab absolutely starving after trying to check out another restaurant in the area and I'm so glad we did. Walked in and we were warmly greeted by the team at the door and also saw there was a great variation of ethnicities as far as diners which is a good indication that this was going to be a great experience. One of the guys came over, took my friend's jacket and placed it on the chair - truly gentleman move right there and asked if we needed some suggestions for a great meal. We asked for time to review the menu, made our selections and anxiously anticipated our food to come. Out first, they bring you a gratuitous aperitif - a thin and crispy flatbread with four salsas/salads - mango puree, onion/tomato/cucumber diced salad, this delish apple/mint chutney mix and some type of spicy pickles I think (forgot to try that though). We ordered an app of ground lamb and lentils formed into patties and OMG - this is patty heaven! The rest of the meal consisted of saag paneer And chicken tika masala - all absolutely divine! My soul says too bad I dont live here but my waistline is grateful! Excellent job all around!

vdICegCtU8nTxgf1OZZqRg.text: This was reputed to be the best Indian food in London but I don't think it is. Interesting photography on the wall - enough to give it one more star. It was good but not great. It's in the West End and a fun location. I'm waiting for a truly great Indian food in England. Any suggestions?

YIP5Lmw8aGVL_F46WEiRBA.text: Decent, best way to describe it. Service was good. But was initially a bit spotty. The food was average. Just average. Disappointed as I was told London was the place to eat Indian food. I am also fairly picky about my Indian cuisine and was so surprised at how average my food tasted. Oh well.

XTizG8mgiSj4pgt8DpLZ4g.text: Must try Gazar Halwa!For an Indian and especially Punjabi, this is definitely a historic place. First Indian restaurant in London. Authentic old era building feeling and beautiful neighborhood. In SOHO close to oxford st, and many other London attractionsNo long wait times even on Saturday. Welcoming staff and interior with history. Nice clean and good presentation. Good music and not loud.Probably not good for kids as space is little congested.Ordered Chana masala, dal makhani, tandoori roti and gazar halwaRatingsChana Masala 4.5 I hope it was slightly less tangy. Good balance of spicesDal Makhani 4 Spices delicately balanced but I felt some Masala was missing maybe because couldn't taste ginger and garlic.Tandoor Roti 4 was not crispyGazar Halwa 5 SUPER DELICIOUSService 5Overall 4They accept AmEX (not a big deal but important for business travelers)

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

rfvIF7Z4Td5XFx5iLdzIXQ.text: Had a wonderful meal here on a stopover in London. It was recommended by a friend and I'm so glad we stopped in! Very easy location and excellent staff who were very attentive but laid back to let you eat as well. Kid friendly too!The pakora were crispy and wonderful. My husband had a chicken dish that came in a sizzling fajita like platter that was pretty awesome and I had the chole which was just enough spice and super flavourful. It wasn't spicy to cover up blandness but just enhanced all the ingredients. We overheard another couple talking about gluten-free options and they were being more than accommodating which is great to hear. Reasonably priced too, we defintely will consider visiting again next time we are in London.

9Q-3BULBzADExo11lzjAMg.text: I LOVE Indian food and was excited to try this restaurant. I always order Chicken Tikka Masala at new places so that I can find out how it ranks to my favorite places. The dish was not very good so unfortunately I will not be back!

TOzKswmXPw_Dq9ZQ6JL89w.text: We arrived for dinner about 5:30 pm on a Saturday after taking in a 2:30 show in West End. The place was already busy but we were seated promptly. It filled up shortly after we arrived. We selected Punjab because it was highly rated on Yelp and once again Yelp was right!!I don't eat a lot of Indian food, but this is the best I can remember. Our amazing appetizer was Kandu Puru, the pumpkin bread. Our courses were Acharri Murgha (chicken curry) and Methi Gosht (lamb curry). Both were exceptionally prepared, tender meats and truly delicious sauces. We accompanied it with cheers naan which was also delicious. My favorite of the dishes was the chicken curry. The menu states "has to be experienced once in a lifetime" and I'm glad I experienced it!Service was fast and extremely friendly and attentive. Highly recommend!!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

h9ppzEpbkSfpUbtUltwlAg.text: We were looking to go to Dishoom, but the darned place always had a 90 minute wait, and I wasn't planning on standing in a line outside in the cold weather (yes, that's what they make you do in many of the  UK restaurants!), so we came here. Even though we were here at 9:30P on a Thursday night there was still a 10-15 min wait. The service was generally very friendly, especially the hosts. The food was a bit of a hit/miss. Excellent butter chicken and Chole, and pretty good tandoori chicken. Very mediocre lamb biryani. Lots of meat but the flavor wasn't particularly good. Chicken tikka masala was okay and the naan was ok.

WsU0pwB6KB8vJqFCZrKyFw.text: Our experience was not a bad one... but when you're eating Indian in London man do you have a lot of competition so at this point the food needs to be damn good in order to have a high rating. The service was very good and the wait was not too long on a Saturday evening- maybe 15 minutes. Samosas were alright (I feel bitchy saying meh), and the prawn puri and king prawn bunha were also ok. They were slightly disappointing from flavour and temperature. Keep in mind that I've become snobbish when it comes to Indian food in London at this point. I did, however, love the cheesy naan. It's a very subtle light cheese inside the naan and adds a beautiful creamy and fluffiness. It's a nice Indian restaurant in a very good location but you can find much better (and much worse) elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Baigan
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka masala
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. King prawn bhuna

DhKm42M5gRTIHJNrvSJOtQ.text: The food is delicious especially their bullet Naan I enjoyed the malai kofta more than the paneer entree! While The Samosas were good!

Q7XF7-ZuxZHCkFANGVuOgQ.text: Real good, not great but real good. If you like traditional Indian, then you'll love this place. Service was great.

6IIJ94O_iKBsu-Wcf7NxXw.text: My family and I were in London for the first time in March. Did you know the national dish of England is Chicken Tikka Masala? It's a long story, but google it sometime. So, we had to order just that with some curry as well. They were fantastic as were the appetizers and side sauces. They even served us a complimentary sparkly dessert custard! Everything was delicious and the staff were so nice. Quick services too!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

JxXghsuZOcF-7KJ8S01fOA.text: Punjab was great! There was a line to get in and we were seated very quickly. Good selection of traditional Indian food and beers. We had the Paneer Pakora to start which we didn't love but it was still nice, think pakora generally goes better with a lighter batter. The aloo gobi was amazing, perfectly spicy and lots of flavour! The Tikka Masala tased awesome but not as creamy as usually get more like a tomato curry than creamy tikka masala. Overall the service was great and really enjoyed our food!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

0fxczsX6685JDO3Gs_sDFQ.text: This review is a bit dated but ended up coming here again for my second trip.  The inside is very clean and gives a sense of coziness. You can easily tell that many locals come to this location and for good reason. The staff are very pleasant and the food was okay but just what I needed. I wished it had a bit more spice to the Chicken Tikka and Jalfrezi but that's possibly due to me comparing what I eat back home in Los Angeles. Overall, it was a pleasant experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

HACnpxCW3Z3XMUeaDtOEqQ.text: I had thd samosa and chicken curry.  It was delicious along witn indian beer.  Servers were very friendly Prices are fair. The restaurant itself could use some updating, thus not a 5 star review.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

Wu3oBbHsxdS6QA3mTkaJUQ.text: I knew while I was in London that I had to eat some Indian food. After spending a full day at Warner Brothers Studio we went to Yelp for suggestions. Punjab had the highest stars with the most reviews, most places had under 50. We arrived around 7:30-8p on a Monday night and the restaurant was fairly crowded. We put our names in and waited about 10 minutes before being seated. Our waiter was friendly and personable, he made suggestions that we gladly took. We ordered:  Tikka Masala, butter chicken, saag paneer, gobi aloo, and acharri gosht lamb, cheese naan and rice. We definitely ordered too much food. My friend also ordered samosas as an appetizer for herself. Samosas: my friend loved them, they were hearty and the pastry they were cooked in had just the right amount of flaky texture to it. She wasn't a fan of the mint chutney she ordered with them and I tasted it and was also underwhelmed. Tikka masala: delicious. The chicken was juicy and tender and the sauce was rich and creamy. I wish it had a little bit more spice Butter chicken: the sauce was AMAZING. I couldn't stop dipping the naan in it. It was the right amount of spice and so flavorful. The chicken also was cooked wonderfully and fell off the bone. Lamb dish: delicious. Flavorful and juicy. I only had a small amount of this but my friend was in love. Saag paneer: was good, not great. Would probably pass on this dish if I came again. Gobi aloo: my boyfriend loved it. I didn't try any. He said it was the best he's had. Cheese naan: cheese and bread are the perfect pairing. This didn't disappoint. The flavors of the food and the service definitely makes me want to visit this restaurant again if I'm ever in London. It's the oldest Indian food restaurant in the city!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Tikka Gold beer. Just okay.
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Ordered way too much food. It was all delicious.

B6miyOrr7MixR5mEzCAQpQ.text: Excellent. Food was exceptional and owner sat us down and gave us a little history and food recommendations. We had some great chicken, lamb and vegi dishes.  Seems very popular and you may want to make reservations.

oFITWDxEY2gY2lcqtEJ0yw.text: The best parts were the service and the naan. It's a bit of a tourist trap, but almost everything in central London is to some extent, so I can't fault it for that- plus I'm no local either.After years living in Singapore within a 10-minute walk to Little India for my weekly Indian fix, this was my first taste of classic British style Indian food. I had to try a chicken tikka... and it was ok. I've now been there, done that. Meh. The black dal (Grandad's dal) was ok. And so was the lamb korma. All around average. So far in London I preferred Dishoom more, however it is a much more modern restaurant. I opted to take the in-laws here, to Punjab, as I knew it was more traditional restaurant (quiet, good service). Not a bad place at all, but with all the Indian places in London, I'll try somewhere new next time for something more authentic, unusual or innovative.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Food

xw8qszMDIs212_IH-TVLig.text: We arrived with a large group of energetic children for dinner and were seated promptly and courteously. Traveling with children can be met with annoyance. I'm allergic to dairy and my server was incredibly conscientious and helpful in every way, assisting me to find the best dishes to accommodate, and setting the dishes I ordered carefully aside so as to avoid intermixing. Nirag was who helped us. He rushed the food out to help with the children and in every way was so attentive. For the flavors of the food, everything we tried was fantastic!

_-q7VcdXq4VI1mQrSr_Ojw.text: Great time with the kids. Good was great as always but I forgot how good the service is. Awesome.

vAZzDjSMHn8Dy6iZAdAJkQ.text: Amazing curries - definitely try their specialties. Very rich and complex in flavor and the ingredients tasted fresh. Great service and a pleasant dining experience overall.

1tRBwSyAfm4t2lq0GjSOcA.text: Excellent food and great service!We were seated right away and were informed that they needed the table at 7.30 and would we still like to sit. There was ample amount of time to eat so we sat down and looked at the menu. We ordered poppadoms, achari murgha, methi gosht, punjabi chole, rice, and pashwari naan. Everything was very yummy and in particular the chole was very tasty. I wish there was a little more heat in the lamb and chicken dish, but I'm sure I can ask for this next time I'm there.The servers were very attentive. Will defo be back!

deI8x03DC_QbWKhoIyeg2w.text: We went here for dinner while visiting London and LOVED it!  We got an assortment of dishes that were all great. The service was excellent. The owner was talking to us while we were waiting for a table. My son remarked on how he likes spicy foods so the owner sent over a sample of the Chicken Madras sauce for him to try. This evidently is the spiciest thing on the menu. My son thought it was the best thing he ever tasted!!! We'll crave this yummy place now that we're back in the States!

baxsTA7LjZoUolcVIXABHg.text: It was my first time eating Indian food (as a well as my super picky husband). This place was awesome! We had the chicken tikka misala and tandoori vegetables! They were delicious. The cheese naan was also amazing. We are both hoping that we can find something that is close to this at home!

LrZz61oDcynvbt2LGmu2eA.text: On our nightly wander looking for a place to eat dinner while on vacation my husband and I were planning to hit up Dishoom; however, the line was very, very long and we were very, very hungry. We checked out the map of the area and found Punjab was a quick walk from where we were and, since we were in the mood for Indian, it seemed a good choice. Let me say, I know nothing about Indian food and I have only ever had it twice in my life prior to this, but if I lived in London this would be a go-to, hands down. The food was absolutely delicious and largely sized, the staff actually provided a carafe of water for our table, the drinks were well priced and large, and the staff was friendly, too! I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and I wish I could find something this delicious close to home. My husband ordered one of their spicy dishes and it was definitely spicy (he tried denying this, but the color of his lips told the real story). We also had a flavored naan and the plain rice, both of which were delicious and helped stuff us. We also had no clue that this place was included in a Guy Fieri show, but luckily it wasn't super crowded when we went. Overall, go here. It's delicious, it's filling, it's just what you need if you're looking for Indian food in the Covent Garden neighborhood.

BaCmYLdu1rb4xXuyCT6BkA.text: We came here on a Wednesday evening for dinner. For a party of 6, the wait time wasn't bad at all - probably only 5 minutes? Anyway, we were seated pretty quickly, which was nice. One thing to note is the seating arrangement felt pretty cramped - separate tables were really close to each other, which made things a bit more uncomfortable.Since I'm not an expert on Indian food, I let my friends pick our dishes since we were going family style. I think we went with a Chicken Tikka Masala (apparently a classic), Acharri Murgha, Karahi Paneer, and another paneer dish that I've forgotten. For sides, we ordered 3 garlic naans and 3 butter naans. The food took a while to come out, but when it did it all came out at once. Maybe for that reason the dishes weren't as hot as I would've liked them to be, but it was still warm enough.I'm not the biggest fan of cheese, so the paneer dishes weren't my favorite. I did, however, enjoy the Chicken Tikka Masala! And the other chicken dish was alright, too. The garlic naan was pretty tasty, but it was a bit too oily for my liking. Overall, I thought the meal and experience were just ok - nothing special, but then again maybe that's just because I'm not a huge fan of Indian food to begin with.

RBDZmVOfnWykbdNcYihY_Q.text: Although I am no great expert on food, I think I can tell the difference between meals that come from a can, or a box, and those that come from the hands of a staff that knows what it's doing. The staff at Punjab knows what it's doing. The tikka masala is complex, as is the khorma. By complex I mean that I could taste the separate ingredients working together. My son, who has eaten a lot of Indian cuisine, says it was the best tikka masala he had ever had. Plus the service is relaxed. No one rushed us. This place is well worth a return trip.

FlEIYcdJj2ph9fCZUC_K7A.text: This was my first time in London and my first time having Indian food, and I have got to say, it was delicious! When I get back to New York I have to search for a spot like this. Really cool atmosphere and awesome food. if I'm ever back in London, I will be back at Punjab! Get the butter chicken!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

hBETVOYl9EKAaLFCfDBjVA.text: The food was pretty good, portions not huge and glasses were a bit dirty. Overall it was a good experience, but the waiters were a bit too pushy with drinks and food, continuously suggesting to get double of everything and more of this more of that. If you're in central and craving Indian this is good place

gT3b22HCESrCY61RwlOL9w.text: One of the best indian food I have ever had. It is no wonder that my colleague recommended Indian food when I told him about my trip to London. I am sold. Bread was warm, every dish we had was tasty, five of us shared our food and we wipe down each plate clean. The server was super friendly and professional, he gave us suggestions since it was our first time there. I saw someone there wearing a really cool sheep t shirt and actually went up to him to ask him where he got the shirt from. Too bad it was from a local market, and I didn't have enough time to go.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

2xAx-8zEQ6xLU-QzeJs5lg.text: If I were to pick between Dishoom and Punjab, I think I would pick Panjab. The wait time never exceeds 20 minutes no matter what group size. All dishes are pretty solid, from Lamb Korma, to Acharri Murgha, to Chicken Tikka Masala (just to name a few that I've tried). The Mango Lassi was good. But the mango juice was a bit watered down? I think I'm just used to a more nectar like consistency for mango juices. Special shoutout for the Chicken Madras though. The waiter warned me that it's very spicy and I didn't think too much of it. But seriously, never have I ever tasted such a spicy curry, let alone food. I was literally sweating buckets from this. My friends sampled my dish and felt the burn immediately. I think I felt it 1/3 of the way in. I wouldn't say it's a numbing kind of spicy, but more like a slow burn. Nonetheless, I thoroughly enjoyed the dish. But the strange thing is, I ordered the Lamb Madras a few months later and it wasn't half as spicy as the Chicken Madras? I already ensured my waiter that I can handle my spices... But I guess you really have to emphasize that you want it SPICY SPICY. I also like how the waiters throw in freebies every once in a while. My Panjabi friend asked for a Panjab specific bread called bhature, but was told that it's not on the menu. Around 15 minutes later our waiter brought out a basket of bhature specially made for her, free of charge! There was another occasion where I got a plate of papadam accompanied with various chutneys and pickled vegetables, free of charge once again! How awesome is that?! Overall great food, fantastic service, and reasonable price. I don't think my expectations for curry will be the same after eating at Punjab. Highly recommend this place!

0wrlbZPf_pdTZNDz8Somqw.text: My first time in London, and my first time eating authentic Indian food and what a terrific experience.  The service is great. The servers stand nearby and are waiting to serve you with a smile. The wait was short and the wine was delicious!  I wish California restaurants had the same service.  Bravo!!! One more thing, the manager Agnelo, surprised us with a sparkling desert. What a great guy.  Cheers Agnelo!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

qRjWITr5nIS65pMWXUM-OA.text: Amazing! Recommend sticking with the items in bold on the menu. We got papadum to start. The main dishes were chicken tikka special (when it comes out they light it on fire on the table!), chicken tandoori and butter chicken. Sides were malai kofta, saag paneer, rice, garlic naan and cheese naan. Everything we had was delicious. We also celebrated my parents 30th anniversary. The waiters all signed a card and brought out a nice ice cream dessert with a candle in it. The owner came by at the end to wish them well and see how we enjoyed dinner. We'll be back again :)

dN5Eqjv0VB5VVFQv3lmdQQ.text: The ultimate gem of Punjabi food. How did miss this! All these years in London wasted!Unbelievably good. Friendly staff with a great sense of humour.Super fast service and no reservations. You won't have to wait long to be seated.Trust me, you don't need to reserve here, just walk in anytime.You might not realise how big this place is until you actually get in and explore it yourself. There are multiple floors and no matter where you sit, you'll have someone around to serve you. They serve traditional Punjabi food and some non Punjabi dishes too. Unfortunately I was so hungry and seduced by the look of the dishes served in front of me that I forgot to take pictures of them, which I usually do to post to Yelp. And when I started having them, I was in trance, so wasn't aware of much going on. One thing I noticed is that this place is filled with tourists and foreigners. Well that explains it. This restaurant is more famous than many others, search the web for "Oldest Punjabi restaurant in London" and you'll know. I will be eating here many more times. They have a wide variety of things on the menu, Punjabi Chicken/Mutton dishes are fabulous, but so are the vegetarian ones, so I hope to try out everything on their menu in the coming few years. I so regret the time I spent in London, not knowing this place existed. Don't repeat my mistake.

OO53p0ts9f69Mt6nVwB0ag.text: The food is good, but not that perfect.The place a little bit small there is no personal space you can share the conversation with the next table.Try the chicken masala and chicken butter. And the vegetable and lamb biryani.And at last don't forget to try the cheese naan.

AQ63VphOgNnMp57Yp9NsAw.text: The best Indian food I've EVER had!!! If you're visiting London, you must go!!!

a56GInlLwj0OnRMN_tMvQw.text: Cannot recommend this place enough! Food... delicious. The staff was SO kind and helpful, it was clear they wanted us to enjoy ourselves and our food. We weren't sure what we wanted to order so they helped us each make decisions based on what we have liked in the past. I loved the butter chicken, two in our group got vegetarian dishes and loved them as well. The portions were also the perfect size, not too much and not too little.As a side note, you should read the fine print on the menu, it had us cracking up. Start with reading the details under Garlic Naan.

f6Zs2GOtkhK2A89mFstL8w.text: Anurag was super excited about this place, having seen it on Andrew Zimmerman. I honestly really wanted to like this place. The place is very small and cramped, and the service was pretty poor. Even in the tiny place, the server didn't make eye contact and we had to flag him down several times. When the server did make his way to us, he was very bent on overselling dishes to us and had us over order, honestly. The food was very average. Other than the kaddu poori, which made me think about home (which was something we grew up eating), everything else was sub par. The naan/ roti was too hard and the Kadhai chicken was not great The daal was also very bland.I don't know if we came at an off time, but our experience was sub par and I won't recommend it/ come back again.

D5MR3k07Dc7XiYRsXLQ3wA.text: I'm not going to lie, British food proper isn't much to write home about, but they've been smart enough to bring the best that the Empire had to offer back to London, and Punjab is a case in point. We were there pretty early (maybe 6ish?) on a random Tuesday, and had no issues getting a table for two as walk-ins, but they were steadily busy so your mileage may vary. Service was proper; friendly enough and efficient, and both our beverages and our food came out remarkably quickly. Additionally, we had no issues getting the check when we were ready to depart, which is a change of pace from most of continental Europe.My colleague's Butter Chicken was excellent; flavorful and a touch spicy (or perhaps I've been eating bland German food for too long). Definitely a solid choice. However, we both agreed that the Pudina Ghosht (a mint lamb curry) was the real winner of the meal. I don't think I've ever had a mint curry before, and I'd order it again in a heartbeat. Spicy and packed with herbal flavors, but without the sometimes overpowering richness that comes from some of the more common curries (at least those that are common in the US). Absolutely fantastic!One tip: the meals don't generally come with rice or naan, so make sure to order a side of them if you want them!

2XguM5h8b3DSx60-a7SlqA.text: Punjab definitely lived up to the hype!  Yes, there is a queue on most nights. We visited on Saturday evening and the wait was about 20 minutes. There are heat lamps outside - Nice touch. Every dish was simple and outstanding. The service wins our Best in London. Bravo Punjab!

zs0C9Gn3zluzhwZWysM6HQ.text: Walk-ins seated via party size with larger parties seated firstOwner is out front, very charmingService is fast, quick turnaround so the line goes fastExtremely effecient service - they didn't get it wrong, it was probably you. ;)Light takes on the heavy items were used to in the US.Meats cooked very well-being even white meats came out tenderNice sized portions. We were able to finish without being overly fullInteresting mix between friendly and brusquely efficientDelicious flavorsHighly recommendWish we could've stayed for dessert

2DMhRupxPIQF1wgFo5pSXw.text: This place was amazing. This place was mentioned by guy fieti on a tv show, I'm glad I stopped by. Excellent service, amazing food, great prices. I suggest getting the garlic naan with whatever you order. Don't be afraid of the spicy dishes, they are manageable. I will come back here next time I'm in London.

vqtlmLpb7ZcaVRSr3OpMcg.text: Pujab has a separate menu for vegans and vegetarians to leverage when ordering. I ordered the gobi aloo with roti and really liked my dish overall. The cauliflower and potatoes were cooked and flavored very well. My only gripe is that I asked for my food to be cooked extra spicy and I felt like my entree was not spicy at all--huge let down. They brought some little peppers over so that I could eat them with my dish but I prefer spice to be cooked into my meal. I recommend they spice dishes they way their customers ask going forward.

IoO8_dv4nhXtoQhglyUuag.text: I LOVE Indian food and eat it almost weekly, so was excited to try some tikka masala in England. Came here since it seemed to be authentic and at a good price.The service was great. Very prompt and accommodating. We started with samosas with a great dipping sauce.We followed with the chicken tikka masala, mixed grill and garlic naan. I asked for the chicken tikka masala a touch under "Indian spicy" which is how I normally order it in the US (a 10 Indian spicy usually knocks me out haha!) Not sure if they assumed we couldn't handle their spice level because we are not Indian and from the US, but it was not spicy AT ALL. My boyfriends mixed grill was good, but he also requested a side of spicy tikka masala sauce and it was again not spicy at all. They quickly gave him a spicier sauce, madras, which was better, but still not nearly the spice we are used too.To be clear, the food at its core is good!! However, we have found at many different types of restaurants in London that the spice level is just not what we are used to in the US. If you are an American craving spice, would just recommend asking for a much higher spice level here and really most places in London.

pBhKpkfiNKygpWkUcjAwBQ.text: Punjab has created this Indian food Monster in me. I recently stop by their location in Covent Garden while on a trip in London and Oh my Gosh! It is a bit in the upper price but well worth for the quality of the ingredients, efficient service and definitely the location. We had the Lam Biryani £14.50 ($19), Saag Paneer £7.95 ($11), Chicken Tikka Masala £11.75 ($15.50), and Tandoori Lamb Seek Kebab £12 ($16) and obviously a serious overload of Naan bread £2.50 ($4)! Every dish was excellent, perfect mild spice to it. Creamy Saag Paneer and Tikka Masala. All these dishes just went perfectly with each other. And what would Indian food be without Raita?? It was so creamy, and fresh! Hopefully it is not too far away my next trip to UK so I can definitely touch heaven again!! Cheers!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Menu on March 2018

CAcReBVIsjPvhBo5GY7UAA.text: Punjab is located on Neal St at Convert Garden area.  It's one of oldest Indian restaurant in London.  We came here for lunch and arrived 5 mins before they opened.  However, there were few groups of people waiting in line.We ordered more than enough for our last day lunch in London coz we really enjoyed authentic Indian cuisine in London.  Samosas - It was just ok and taste didn't like fresh made. Naan - We liked it the sliced garlic on naan. Gobi Aloo - Cauliflower and potatoes lightly spiced and sautéed, it's good.Chicken tandoori - Roasted chicken marinated in fresh yogurt and tandoori masala.  Chicken quite tender and moist, so delicious. King Prawn Bhuna - Jumbo prawns curry was excellent and just made us fell in love with curry.....Overall, decent service and very reasonable price.  I would recommend to visitors (like us) and like to try causal Indian food.

DXjQmZ32sOJvo49TgK8r3g.text: Good service, food is satisfying. I really wish they had traditional chai. The place is very conjugated. Serviceman are attentive but at times I feel rushed by them

zuwaxiwPC6rxoZgjq6rYfQ.text: Located in beautiful Covent Garden (aka the theatre district of London), Punjab remains true to its authenticity. Open since 1945, It's apparently the oldest North Indian restaurant in London. The decor inside is traditional with purple as it's predominant color. The seating is a bit cramped in here, as tables are quite close to each other. The food here is great. My family and I got the mango lassi, saag paneer, naan, tandoori chicken, lamb madras, and chicken madras. The mango lassi was creamy and fragrant. But, I still think it doesn't even compare to the mango lassi in Singapore, which was mind blowing. The saag paneer was less creamy compared to one I usually eat in Houston at Naseeb. But, I did appreciate the spinach flavor that's more predominant at Punjab. The tandoori chicken had a nice grilled flavor and was moist. It went well with their naan bread. Now, the best dish on their menu by far was their lamb or chicken madras. Strong curry flavor and spicy as hell! Thank goodness we had enough rice to calm the spice. I would definitely recommend eating this. I can't wait to come back to this restaurant whenever I visit London again. It would be a wonderful dinner choice before a theatre show close by. I'm sad I missed the Harry Potter and the Cursed Child play that was currently playing nearby when we were there.

ghavzyRXNdqd2a2D2eDSzQ.text: Amazing food and service- loved the EVERYTHING and worth any wait there is- right near covent garden- wow!
