koO09X3ZxoEmbC0Z4s01CA.text: The restaurant was recommended by a friend and when we arrived it was packed. Fortunately, we were able to find a table for 2. I looked for recommended items on the menu and ended up ordering the butter chicken-a Punjabi speciality. Well, when it arrived I took my first bite and  it was insanely spicy. To the managers credit he saw the face I made after that first bit and asked me if anything was wrong. I told him it was very very spicy. He then had the waiter bring me some yogurt to calm the spices down. if you love spice this is your dish. If not, stay away from it.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

J6J5eeA5t2yGWdejPkQ6pg.text: The was the ONLY restaurant that was a repeat from our previous London trip.  We have been daydreaming about coming back since our first London trip 9 years ago. Reasonable price with fast and friendly service.  I wish I can have the naan bread and the chicken tika marsala again right now. I also appreciate how it's bright light inside so I can see and take pictures of my food.  The couple next to us both ordered a sizzling plate and it smelled great too! Will definitely come back if I'm lucky to visit London again.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Dinner 2
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Dinner 1

VAqDL0ZwDFipSbTU6wAFQA.text: I came here because of a recommendation from a friend in Los Angeles and thought my tastebuds were in for Nirvana.  The line out the door was a good sign, but sadly my hopes of finding Nirvana at Punjab was not so. I came here a couple times during my last trip to London hoping things would get better.  I did meet some nice people who shared a few of their dishes with me so I was able to taste more than I would have by myself - that's always nice!  There are some good things, but mostly I left with a poor taste in my mouth and bitterness in my heart. The service was consistently fair to middlen. Anytime someone comes to take your full order without suggesting appetizers or beverages it makes me feel like they want you in and out as fast as possible. Is this a fast-food joint?  No?  Then let me try to enjoy the experience you have to offer. I asked the server for suggestions since every chef has their specialty, but I didn't get any. "Whatever you feel like" doesn't sit well with me.On my second and third visits I ordered different appetizers.  Each were very hot, tasty, fresh and perfectly seasoned with dipping sauce that add the right amount of "kick-ass" to your tastebuds.  The stuffed eggplant didn't seem to be stuffed with much of anything (it was cut down the middle and roasted), but I could eat roasted eggplant any day of the week and be perfectly content. The chicken Korma was like puréed baby food without any of the flavor or spices you might expect. No cashews, raisins, or any other seasonings you'd normally latch onto to please your palate.  Such a disappointing dish. They wouldn't let me order it "spicy."  I was also told that people have nut allergies, so I guess I can't have nuts at Punjab either!  I realize there are different styles of cooking, especially when it comes to south Asian cuisine, but I didn't enjoy the bland nature of this dish which I generally love and call "my favorite" at other restaurants. Here is what upset me the most and left bitterness in my heart:  I had already experienced different dishes throughout my stay in London at Punjab with a variety of meats, but on my last night I ordered a different chicken dish (my cardiologist would like this).  When I tasted the dish my tastebuds said "baa baa baa" and not "cluck cluck cluck."  It was lamb, again. I love lamb so I ate it anyhow and didn't complain, but as I was leaving the restaurant one of the owners said, "I saw that you ordered chicken, but I switched it to lamb because lamb is better."  I don't mind a prefix menu if that's what I'm ordering, but intentionally changing my order and NOT telling me is WRONG. If you want me to try something different, then give me a taste and don't force your opinions on me.  I was consistently asking the servers for suggestions and they wouldn't give me any!  I already had plenty of lamb at Punjab and wasn't in the mood for more, but I ate it, again. How would you feel if you ordered a cucumber sandwich and the chef said, "I saw you ordered a cucumber sandwich, but what you really wanted was a BLT so I changed it...oh, and you're still paying me for it."  I'm generous with two stars.

-H5L9ugJim32aLeMPSbb8g.text: This place was much better than the other Indian restaurant we visited.   The chicken curry, curried lamb, and naan very very flavorful.  The service was impeccable.  On my list for when we return!

vH4SGwBKWs410zX09nwD5g.text: Straight bonkers. I mean the food and service here is fantastic. The girl doing the seating outside was amazing. Biriyani is to die for. All around this location is just a great place to eat great Indian food. Its not deconstructed to some other weird dish. Just really damn good Indian food.

7qd0VJVxGsTy2O2wf2-fgA.text: Showed up without a reservation on a Thursday night.  Only had to wait a few minutes for a table for one, despite being a small line.  Ordered the Chicken Madras, garlic naan, and a Cobra beer.  Food was out in minutes.  Too hot to eat!  Chicken was spicy, and the naan awesome.  Both of those combined with a beer...AWESOME!  If you are seeing a show, and need a quick place to eat, this is it.   All around awesome!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

ouCRuxt328IywEYO6JhCng.text: Excellent vegan options. They offer a separate vegan menu from which I ordered gobi aloo with rice and samosa. Delicious!

suOijZ4Bxa6X7TUnoGfkeA.text: A classic Indian restaurant in the heart of London, specializing in the north, specifically the Punjab. Don't expect modern interpretation of Indian food, fusion or anything like that - expect a typical British Indian restaurant, done just right. I've visited the place many times before when in London, mainly owing to its central location, and it never disappoints. Prices are very reasonable too, despite the prime location.

R9QH6blUvtR8fyj_jyTRuQ.text: 3.5 stars for me.  The food was good, but nothing special that would make me want to come again.  Had the Chicken Tikka Masala, samosa, vegetable curry.  Garlic naan was blah. I dont know why this restaurant was so busy, but there was definitely a crowd.

y0PWy-T2EwAnrgL1Lao0vA.text: *Be aware of the £15 minimum per person purchase, our neighbors were kicked out for wanting to order apps only, see below*We ordered the vegetable biryani with vegetable curry, chicken madrasa, bullet naan and a beer. The rice and chicken madrasa was very flavorful, spicy and worth the order. The bullet naan wasn't anything special, the cilantro and chillies didn't add much flavor. *Food was delicious, however, the lead waiter was pretty rude to other guests (we were there at 3:30 pm: he asked a couple to leave for only waiting to order appetizers, and a father wanted to sit next to the window with his daughter but he wouldn't let them).

cktNYpoBhmr9_2Rk44jkrQ.text: I've always wanted to visit this restaurant since it is supposed to be the oldest North Indian restaurant in London. We ordered the vegetable pakora for an appetizer, but found some hair in it. Not good. The mango lassis were good but not great. We ordered the malai kofta with vegetable biriyani and Naan (bullet and garlic). The naans came way after the kofta was almost gone - not good again. With some many other Indian options like Dishoom and Gymkhana around, I will not be back.

cxW0F5umzpYBrcQ6lPAM2A.text: The Resturant is nice and clean & the waiters are attentive .I ordered the samosas , nothing to spectacular but it was perfectly cooked not oily or over cooked For the main course I ordered the lamb chop curry , & tikka Masala  , white rice  and garlic nan bread.I was warned by the waiter that  my lamb chop curry would be spicy,  which I love . However , the curry sauce wasn't as spicy enough  to me . They gave  a nice portion of pieces of lamb chops with the bone. I enjoyed my meal very much but wish it was spicer.The tikka masala was very well prepared the sauce was so good and fresh . The garlic nan bread was so good and hot and perfect to use to dip up the sauce from your plate  I didn't order any drinks just seltzer( sparkling )  water

MfJCq5qby_WFpK9E91bYOw.text: Nice ambience and service. Seated quickly. Food was good but for London standards was just 'ok'. Lacking salt all around and I'm not one who likes a lot of it.

mI0GCF7gX-EZxeMVAKFxwQ.text: Excellent service and excellent food! This place was very authentic (according to an Indian friend who I spoke to after going here) and reasonably priced. Everything is a la carte, however, which I wasn't aware of so it took a little while to get everything ordered that I needed for a full meal. Nonetheless, the food is hearty and the spice level is right on point. I'm someone who enjoys fiery foods and felt that their spice level was adequate. Great place!

44mw434m9k2n8JSPXhAxBA.text: Pricey, but the best Indian food I've ever had, and my home is close to Fremont, California. Make sure to get a nice cobra beer with your meal :). We had a paneer dish, but the butter chicken and lamb korma were sooo money. I wish the sides of rice and naan were included though..

JPqy8H2GmwfhUoGtXoEODA.text: Punjab is a fantastic restaurant with the most amazing staff! I highly recommend this restaurant for the authentic cuisine and the family atmosphere. Amrit and Angelo certainly understand the meaning of fine dining and great customer service. Thank you for a fantastic meal!

M5GYdDyq8izXaSI0ovTrOg.text: Well beyond its Use-by date.  Decor is tired.... threadbare dirty carpets and worn furniture.  Food was also a huge disappointment. I love Indian cuisine .... but you can walk down any suburban UK high street and get better than this. Having visited India several times, with a name like Punjab, I had especially high expectations of the tandoori dishes...again a huge disappointment as the meats had none of the smoky charcoal flavor one expects from genuine tandoor cooking. Moreover the "curry" dishes had no depth of flavor and all seemed to have been microwave reheated as they were delivered to our table within less than 2 mins of ordering. This place is trading off a long past reputation.

CeJSpB8uipYYhgxcq9YAtQ.text: The most amazing Indian food I have ever had, period. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu and I'm totally addicted to their curry! The service is amazing! I have a food allergy and the staff went out of their way to make sure there was no cross contamination. I would eat here every day if I could!

-lWdgEDzPmGxPLopdRCkFw.text: This place was incredible! By far the best meal we had while in London. The Chicken Tikka Masala with rice and a spicy naan is a must try. Definitely plan on coming back when we return.

qlAAle7Kx2mv3KHZpaahsQ.text: Loved this place!  Best Indian food I have ever had. The flavors were incredible. Loved the tandoori chicken and cumin rice. I'm a light weight when it comes to eating spicy food and I was able to eat many things on the menu. The servers were so friendly and helpful and very fast. The restaurant has a great environment.

RFJUSyTXLfUP1k3sR1GRwg.text: I loved the food. And the wine is more than what I'm use to. My boyfriend and I shared the chicken tikka masala because we thought it would be too much for the both of us. Know that you need to add an order or rice and vegetables because it's not included with the main dish. We also added cheese naan, which I also loved! Lastly we ordered a milky dessert with bread in it and I also thought that was delicious! I would definitely return here for more meals. Service was extremely professional and friendly and quick.

MwkyPO3eS1Q-w_c1aYknAQ.text: We were originally going to try Dishoom but the line was so long, so we opted to grab takeaway from Punjab.  One of the best Indian meals I've had!  Note that if you grab for takeaway, you get a discount (as with most places in London).  While we were waiting for our food, I ordered a mango lassi which was perfect and not overly sweet.The garlic naan was buttery and had excellent flavor and giant pieces of garlic (which is a plus to me).  The chicken tikka masala had so much flavor, and the lamb korma was very creamy.  I think this place had the hands-down best tikka masala I had.  The prices are going to be a little steeper than what I'm used to in America, but we had leftovers that were still great the next day.  Service was excellent for us while we were waiting for our food, and they made sure to provide us with all the utensils that we needed.

coN275nODl02aChL4dIQEw.text: What a great find for Indian food!  On a busy Saturday night, the staff at Punjab were welcoming and highly efficient. After just a 15 minute wait, we were shown to a table upstairs where our drink orders were taken shortly after being seated. I had the house red wine, Borsao Garnacha 2014, which lived up to the fruity, full flavor as described on the menu!  Yum!The vegetable samosas were great as an appetizer with a slightly different sauce than what I've had before, not too sweet, not hot, but flavorful - almost like a barbecue sauce. I had the chicken tikka masala and my husband had the Achari Murgha. My dish was tender and flavorful, definitely stood out among the many tikka masalas I've had!  The Achari Murgha was spicy and full of flavor, a completely different set of flavor than either of us had tried before. Both dishes were excellent and were well complemented by the garlic naan. We were impressed by the setting, the great food but especially by the service and care taken by the staff. We were greeted by the owner and he took time to speak with us on our way out, too, showing real interest and pleasure in our experience at his restaurant.

vbBIfSReANst5XM9lioxxQ.text: One of our friends was on her way, and the staff didn't give us a table until she arrived. This is not the hospitality I would expect from any decent restaurant.

DJ7vRhgiR69ZpY-M_af5og.text: recommended by my indian friend as the "BEST indian food outside of india" that she's had, Punjab was one of the first restaurants i tried after landing in Londonwe were pretty underwhelmed by the food 2.5 stars.. but maybe because I didn't order the famed chicken tikka masala--grandad's daal: BLAND--lamb korma: this dish was ok--acharri chicken: too tomatoe-y for my taste--Garlic naan: pungent but pretty good--we got one order of Flavored and another order of unflavored rice for the 3 of usa reasonably priced meal for londonBill includes a suggested 10% tipNOTE: the 15 pound minimum order per person is flexible & they only print that on the menu so people don't order solely appetizers

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. flavored rice
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. acharri chicken
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. grandad's daal

4z-S65PhGWLj-gA_UC9Daw.text: Great food! We'd been looking for a really good Indian restaurant and Punjab did not disappoint. Staff was friendly and courteous, and the food was outstanding! A few other tourists (like us) but also a good number of locals -- always a good sign. After a full day of sightseeing we were exhausted. We didn't feel rushed at all and somehow managed to finish everything. We'll definitely be making another stop at Punjab the next time we visit London!

gATLyJeKnz38CTdMOjl3ww.text: I arrived here on a Saturday evening for dinner. I was alone and it just took them 3 mins to find a place for me but even for large parties reservation didn't seem to be required.The service was quick and courteous. I have ordered an Achcari lamb, which I loved -- it had the right amount of spices and it took no time to arrive -- but I think it can still be improved. I will go to this place again!

VA_X_-sKO77F21H0mKbm7A.text: Not quite five stars from me, but still very, very good.It's easy to see why you need to book or else expect to wait in a long queue, as the atmosphere is great and the food superb, giving you a great dining experience.The menu is an interesting read.. I won't spoil it but if you read the descriptions you'll find it hard not to crack a smile or five.And the food, what most restaurants are famous for... I had the kadu-puri for starters (after the obligatory poppadoms of course!) and it was soooooo good. A light and slightly crispy pastry/batter filled with curried pumpkin yumminess.After that I had a try of three vegetable curries which were all cooked very well and had an abundance of flavour without being so hot that I couldn't enjoy them.The one thing that stood out as a negative, however, was that as a vegetarian, whilst there were a lot of options, I felt that a lot of them are what in a lot of other places you'd find as side dishes. I kind of felt like something was missing, like I'd missed the main course and gone straight for the extras. That's not to say it didn't taste great or that I left still feeling hungry, but when I go back I'll see if there's not something I can order with a bit more substance.Prices? We all had poppadoms, mains, rice, naan and alcohol and paid a little over £20 per head. In other words, not cheap, but not bad, and certainly worth it.

T72ldP9mCKkrfn8zMKcBGw.text: When I lived in London about 5 years ago, Punjab was a regular stop on the way home from work.  The staff is so friendly (especially when you're a regular), the food is delicious, the prices are fair, and everyone I brought here fell in love with this place.  "Punjaaaaab!!!" became a regular chant when someone asked the question, "Where should we go for dinner tonight?"Hope it's still as good as it was!  Definitely going to pay a visit when I revisit London next...

bPRmfIOIcee3RS1OkE-a3g.text: Best Indian food ever! Try the Pumpkin curry, I want to go back to London just to eat that again it was to die for. Do make advanced reservations or you'll never get in.

iS_-7o7mGoDF2oT7BeIXgA.text: Is Punjab fancy and exotic?No.Is Punjab completely delicious and a pretty good deal for the West End?Ohyesohyesohyes.Punjab is a pretty special slice of curry heaven, right in the middle of tourist-central Covent Garden (don't judge).  Tasty, non-greasy, fresh Indian food (including "Granddad's Dall"), at prices that make you think you could come here pretty regularly.  Worth every moment on the tube, surrounded by smelly, dirty people.But book in advance. It was absolutely heaving on a Friday night, and we had to fight off the folks waiting at the front who hadn't made reservations, because they seriously were clawing at us for our table.

IetHo_wlW58DO-ykFn16Uw.text: I live in a town with numerous Indian restaurants, so while I'm not a connoisseur I certainly have had experience with the cuisine. Everything we had here was excellent, from the naan to a vegetarian daal and flaming chicken tikka. Service was professional and efficient (not sure what the complaints are about here). My lone complaint is that they pushed our table in a bit cramped in order to keep a main aisle open, but really that's a trivial thing. People at the next table were Canadians who said they'd been here last year and made sure to come again in their visit to London this year, and I'd certainly be happy to go again. Recommend.

VahdKqW4AMbCuENzXIldbA.text: The service was good, the restaurant upstairs is over lit and soul less. One does get the impression they want you in and out as fast as possible. The food seemed very ordinary, pre cooked and waiting under lights, nothing special. I always  seem compare other indian restaurants in london to Rickshaw in Battersea square which is amazing. So I was disappointed,

itjTluU2hVfoYUAYBnHU2A.text: Punjab serves the best Indian food from all the places I have tried in London, Holland and the US.  When I'm there, I'm family! ;o)  There are days that I've been for both lunch and dinner!I'm a vegetarian and usually order 1 or 2 vegetable dishes which is plenty.  My omnivorous friends are very content with Punjab as well as their chicken, lamb and fish dishes are very good, according to them.  I strongly recommend the Saag Panir, Chana Masala and Vegetable Kofte.  And the Gobi Aloo of course.If you go on a Thursday - Sunday night, I recommend making a reservation as Punjab is very popular.  Also, if you're with a large party, making a reservation would be a good thing to do.  Enjoy!!

lI5jNu2rJrl41C8kQCa7rQ.text: Wow! This place is pretty special. The décor has that authentic lick of yellow paint with pictures of classically dressed Indians and well set tables to complete the scene. At 6 o'clock there were people waiting outside for the doors to open. At 6:15pm the restaurant was almost full. Patrons of Punjab clearly need their tandoori fix.The service is professional with many servers waiting to take your order, meaning you are never left waiting for something. As for the food, I am going to keep it simple. EXCELLENT! Whether you are here for a quick eat with friends or as a romantic couple, this Indian eatery has a touch of class you will surely enjoy.

tJfNornRv6T1AqoKvu1BbQ.text: They say the Indian food is good in London.  This is where to get it.  It is so delicious that a couple days ago, I came here, completely stuffed my face, eating well being what a healthy portion should be, got appendicitis within 36 hours, and now I've just left the hospital to share with you this culinary war story.  Might have been worth it.  Don't over eat.

Tz4aVTCF5jSzPE8PAZUItw.text: When I was in London recently I ate here and I have to say, this food was amazing. The experience is such that when you walk in to restaurant you feel like you are in India. The wait staff was helpful and the portions were large. The food was fresh and hot and reasonably priced. Even given the fact that it was in a theatre district area in London! Covent Garden is a beautiful area and this place is worth making a special trip to- I ate a bit of Indian food while I was in England and this one was the best! Be sure to get their Nan and their chicken tikka masala. Amazing stuff!

f1N86vDeptUyACoEkCK5SA.text: I agree with Danny K - 'service' is a misnomer. Waiters seem to begrudge our requests. We asked to sit by a window but we were told that that table was for 4 and we were 3 so we should sit at a table for 3. They did concede after the blast of air conditioning was raised as an issue - kind of spoiled the feeling of a treat out. Courteous interactions were sparse throughout the rest of the meal but I remember the food being good. The loos was unisex - good for some, but  in a relatively small space.

ryNG3xLWboDFpLvv5hTOHA.text: I'm surprised by all the great reviews. The food is decent, but just mediocre. The menu is quite boring as well.

K-XpfXaysZp3Luj_CxIfjg.text: This was one of the better Indian meals while we were in London although we wished one of our brown friends were with us to take us on a complete culinary tour.  When in London, stick with Indian.

SB-AV5hT7LKhKPc8dNNfUg.text: Got butter chicken here. Was delicious. But I was starving at the moment. But, I'm sure it would still be delicious were I not starving. They charge extra for the rice. Also, the selection of beer was pretty lousy (I guess you a can expect that from an Indian restaurant). And the Rasmalai for dessert was delicious. So, 4 stars for them.

9UK8I-3v1p0zHwmUYFCiyA.text: So good!  I went to get lunch here with a group of friends and everything was delicious and they were very accomdating to a big group of us (8 people). Can't wait to go back.

8HUAqanle5-J0y5uljmmOA.text: Thank you yelpers for the fantastic recommendation.  The pumpkin curry seemed like an oxymoron on the menu but thanks to the other reviews we read, we gave it a shot. It was fantastic! The cheesy naan was light and perfect, not a hot mess of grease.  I've passed on the name of this place to my sister and her friends as well.  The prices were extremely reasonable, it was warm and comfortable and the service and servings were plentiful.  I'd go back in a heartbeat!

fg40gsfFv-UfSOGn1CWU6Q.text: Top notch service and food - everything was excellent.  Went there for lunch and had dal, naan and mago lassi.  Wish they had one in the US! :)

HaFzkQaSlXuDwumSKGQLtg.text: Delicious Indian food in Covent Garden. It was a few minutes wait on a Friday evening for three, but then seated and fed in great time. We family-styled peshwar naan (sweet, yum), saag paneer and another saag potato dish, chicken tikka masala, lamb korma, and surprisingly good red wine and of course big bottle of cobra (beer).

RZemZli0N0tX4ol2s88asg.text: The best recommendation is that my better half .. who hates Indian food .. enjoyed dinner at Punjab. Expert use of spices perfumed our lamb and chicken dishes. Friendly, expert confident table service.Will definitely return on my next visit to London.

uaaMSaxegeuXblEXwcdSbQ.text: This is a "must visit" restaurant whenever I am in London.  You just simply can't get Indian this good anywhere I have been in the states (although, you could say that about almost any!).Typical for London, the dining spaces are tight...and there can be a wait if you don't have a reservation.  But don't let any of that deter you from trying this gem.

h-5moFe7d70dqBsVsyeYnQ.text: I have a friend who is from India and her mother flew to the U.S.  I had the honor of trying 10 of her homemade dishes and each was better than the last.  I thought going to an Indian restaurant would be a bad experience after tasting authentic homemade Indian food.  And then I found Punjabi.  WOW!  The texture and flavors of my dinner was over the top exquisite and the service was top notch.  I live in South Florida and don't have many options but I may just have to fly to London to Punjab to eat.  Florida restaurants need a lesson in service as well as cooking.  The waiters and staff made me feel like I was a VIP from the moment I walked in.  If you want the real deal....go to this place.  5 amazing stars!!

Q_n37Q0-fyGvogOiEzxwww.text: Brits know how to curry, and Punjab is tops. We went for the English classics like chicken tikka masala with lots of buttery naan - sublime. Perfect after a busy morning at the British Museum, and before exploring the nearby bookstores.

gHgPGaU5v_1rHt1s66e2rQ.text: My friend and I stumbled upon this place purely by coincidence, and we're glad we did!  I'm no Indian food connoisseur (and therefore some of your opinions may be very different than mine), but I'm still very willing to assert that the food here was pretty darn good!  Every bite was savory; the restaurant did well with combining an interesting mix of flavors.  The naan was delicious, the butter chicken was succulent,  and the chicken madras was my favorite (although it wasn't as spicy as I had expected).We loved Punjab and will return in the future if the opportunity presents itself!

Vrjq1X4L23L-3smysL-6Bw.text: Been twice this week!  Food is great, service wonderful, and the price is so reasonable for central London.  Tried the house red from Spain and was pleasantly surprised with the quality.  NO reservation but they seated us quickly.

1bgV73ZzrCEx-ljyjcnYcA.text: Best meal during our week in london. Right around corner from apartment we stayed at. Just order. Everything was excellent and reasonably priced. Bill was half what we paid at another indian place just two days earlier and food was on same level. Cant wait to return.

xPLTL_GCHthyfBO-Sp5TQQ.text: We had a group of 24 high school students and this was the final meal of our trip. The service and food were both very good and they were very accommodating and helpful. Would definitely recommend for future visits.

m3ngEUOHLRdbLu0eUMMPLQ.text: Excellent food at decent price (for London).  We had the Acharri Murgha (chicken), Methi Gosht (lamb in Fenugreek), mushroom masala, and Kadu Sabji (pumpkin curry).  My girlfriend and I generally don't eat lamb, but we ordered the methi gosht based on the waiter's recommendation. It was excellent, and my favorite dish, with the pumpkin curry a close second.  My girlfriends liked the chicken best. The mushroom masala was good, but not fabulous like the other dishes.This was my second visit to Punjab and I'm looking forward to going back on my next visit to London.

G2MSfo2139RT8MYAK6uemA.text: We were visiting London from out of town and were looking for a low cost meal. we found Punjab on yelp and gave it a try. the food was so good the first time, we went back twice! the second time was even better than the first! fantastic chicken tikka masala, raita, vegetables khorma, and their specialty Punjabi dishes from the grandfathers recipes. the palak paneer was good- but the rest was memorable. Go HERE and be happy you did

7wnWsrMsfHF6dx1zPjk3uQ.text: We came here for our first dinner during a work trip to London.  The food was absolutely delicious and just what I was looking for in great tasting Indian food.  The kadu puri (pumpkin in a crispy puff) was a great starter along with cheese naan.  We then ordered chicken tikka masala and vegetable curry.  Both were perfect!  Wait staff were all very nice!

r1SVwOMauluqyESUCrpaWg.text: I am so glad there was a 2hs wait at Dishoom, enticing us to do the three minute walk over to Punjab, where the staff was welcoming and the food delicious. I'm admittedly not a connoisseur of Indian cuisine, or much of an adventurer in regards to food, but I did enjoy my classic chicken tikka masala and mango lassi. My BFF was equally satisfied by the food and ambiance. A bit of a splurge, in comparison to other places about London, but it /is/ near Covent Garden, and you do get value for your money. We went on a weeknight and didn't need reservations, but I'd suggest getting them if on the weekend. I don't doubt this place fills up.

AzORfZpgOoXpP7OIheAp0Q.text: All parts of the meal went super well here: the poppadoms were crispy and fresh, the naan perfectly cooked and the chicken tikka masala was creamy and flavorful. I can't tell you how disappointed I've been with other places' chicken tikka masala. Either it is too sweet or a bizarre neon reddish color that puts me off.The service was amazing. They re-filled our water cups multiple times during the visit and asked us how our meal was. That in itself gives them a big 'ole star from me. Pleasant atmosphere, delicious food and fabulous service.

J_uAwACixuquJEGEvBe_gA.text: The staff was very accommodating especially with our large group and lack of reservation. The dishes were tasty. I highly recommend.

Gsc5U2tKF46QWV0FS7QKJQ.text: best Punjabi food I've had in a long time, the chicken tikka, ghobi alu, and lamb madras were all delicious. Sure the ambiance was mediocre and the place had a weird chemical smell... who cares.. the food was amazing, stop being stuffy.

olXeHdsETJTXKlFmWY6BYg.text: There are few restaurants that I will wait outside of until they open.There are even fewer restaurants that will be completely full within minutes of opening.And there are yet fewer restaurants that will completely justify both the wait and proceeding hype.Punjab is one of these restaurants. Situated smack in central Covent Garden, I can only assume this restaurant gets a lot of love from visiting tourists, and perhaps the only reason I can think to avoid it.  (All yelpers have something against going to a place listed in every guide book as "the" place to go.)... Unless it's this good. In which case: roll up your sleeves, perfect your perfect American accent, throw 'dem bows (if necessary, of course) and wait in line. It's worth it!

bBKAnRrgwn4l5zshGkI4lg.text: I love Indian food! We eat it at home (CA, USA) but our my trip to London we wanted to see what the UK had! We loved this restaurant so much that we ate there twice on our short trip. We went way out of our way to try many well reviewed restaurants, but back we were. We couldn't resist it. Don't miss it! One of my best memories from this trip.

LKCfsRab7vDzyUlp46fTPQ.text: This place is amazing!!! I am visiting from Los Angeles and I have had my share of Indian food and this place was extremely delicious. It is a MUST!

HFGeQD4lkLLo7sZywgXyEA.text: Not that I'm an Indian food know-it-all, let me start off by saying that eating here was like eating at any Indian restaurant worth its curry in Jersey City, Iselin or Edison, NJ - those in the know will know what I mean, but at least there you get more food for your money - I'm not looking for an all-you-can-eat buffet, far from it, but the butter chicken had two pieces of chicken in it - c'mon! The sauce was delicious, though. Don't get me wrong, the food here is good - Punjab is touted as the oldest Indian restaurant in London in continuance operation, and for good reason. The pumpkin curry was probably the best thing on the menu - spectacular.  All the food was fresh and tasty.  We ordered a variety of dishes, rice dishes, nan, chicken tikka masala, etc.  The wait staff was very attentive and there when you needed them.  The Sikh patrolling the rooms, making sure everything was done just right, transported you back to the time of the British Raj - the good times, not the bad.Anyway, that said, food was good, prices a bit high, and typical of London you gotta eat ethnic foods or die trying.

ZVjFy_6uPF4MiuBoFjVqRA.text: Had samosas to start and the butter chicken with naan and raita for dinner.  We were excited after the samosas,  they were delicious.  But the chicken on the bone (it was actually the tandoori chicken) difficult to eat with the sauce. Oh, and the sauce, so greasy,  oil was floating on top. Our poor naan was overcooked.  Service was fine.

KR2mi4uJoIb3AaSJblHl4w.text: Great experience from beginning to end....welcomed at the door by several staff members, sat quickly, served immediately, and the food was incredible!  Highly recommend this authentic Indian experience to everyone!

I7mr9_NCqcfFrBh78W5mRg.text: I'm not super fussy (or an expert) when it comes to my Indian food, but I really like this place. Super friendly staff, good food, nice area of London. It's not a really fancy place but they still do a great job with white linen tablecloths and candles etc. I really enjoy coming here and will come back again.

Rs7BQhkI0ryK50nOPrp-gg.text: We went on a working lunch here today. For a Tuesday it was surprisingly busy (I see Indian/Punjabi food as a night time meal really). We went based on Yelp reviews, obviously, and we weren't disappointed. It announces itself as the UK's Oldest North Indian Restaurant and the photos and articles around the room provide you with its history. The decor isn't anything to shout out about but it's simple and comfortable which I liked.The waiter was slightly abrupt but in a comical way. He provided us with the wifi password via the menu (butterchicken) and helped with the food recommendations - I'm glad he did! We started with popadoms, pretty standard, but the chutneys which accompanied them were unisual particularly the greeny grain looking one (not sure if the name - sorry) which was tangy yet delightful.We then shard the Samosa's - crispy not soggy pastry (which does happen) on the outside, and the inside was almost creamy, stuffed with meat and potatoes with fantastic flavours running through.Now to the dish I was prompted to try, the Archarri Margha, I truly enjoyed this! You could tell that the ingredients were fresh and that they take pride in their special dishes and you could really taste tang!It was first Punjabi food experience, it won't be my last!To note: the prices are really decent especially for a restaurant in Covent Garden.

xD0fgfjISLKmMcbKKqz7Rg.text: Definitely get the chicken tikka masala! So good! Don't order the buttered chicken if you aren't expecting a slight kick. We were seated immediately upon arrival (party of 2), and the staff was very attentive and kind. The fried lentil and lamb appetizer is delicious, but be warned -- there isn't much of it. So don't order to split if you're hungry! Portion sizes of the entrees are larger than one might come to expect in London. Decor was interesting and cool -- one might call it slightly dated, but when the food is that good, who cares? The restaurant is easy to find and within walking distance of an excellent ice cream place!

Ej33N4ARZd3psZgK7F5SwA.text: *Very rude behaviour*Apparently there's a rule that the order should exceed 15 pounds per person.We were a party of four visiting - one of us wasn't too hungry and our order fell short initially. The waiter first pointed the rule out to us with a rude "can't be done."After finding out about the rule, we told the waiter that we'll order dessert in the end to cover the difference. Yet again the waiter in his border line accusatory tone said "what if you don't?"My Rating is not because of the rule - the restaurant is entitled to keep it. However, I do think the waiters could do a much better job of explaining it to customers understanding that they're not thieves trying to trick them.

bwzpCczfb3RQqPUlD8LlNw.text: Wonderful food.  The owner was incredibly friendly.  I especially loved how friendly they were to my kids who have nut allergies.  We rarely eat Indian food because of their allergies,  but they really enjoyed it!

9FBnniMNolwsoxm1zO__vg.text: My hubby really wanted Indian food in London, and our first choice was Dishoom, but when we got there we saw it was closed for renovations (we probably should've checked the website in advance...), so we quickly scrambled and found Punjab. There was a 20 minute wait, and the little wait area is so tiny and crowded. We moved around as people came and went (it was raining outside, duh, so couldn't wait there), after the time passed we were seated at a table upstairs. The restaurant is huge and it was packed. My hubby really wanted to try some stuff he doesn't see on menus in the US, and he did, I can't remember what it was that he ordered though (something very spicy), but he really liked it! We also ordered samosas, naan, chicken tikka masala, some veggies, and rice since it did not come with the meat dishes, weird. The food was good! The flavors were very authentic and tasty, the naan was delicious! The service was ok, I kept having to ask for water, which seems to be on par for London (I had to basically beg for refills everywhere!) but overall this place was pretty good! We definitely left quite full!

Y37qVPY2xdCDzCuP4nBzDw.text: One of the best north Indian restaurants outside of India! We ordered vegetarian curries - paneer  tikka masala, the best Channa Masala I ever had, naan and biryani. Everything was so delicious. Great service too. Will definitely return when I go back to London.

WmbP888jeA1OTIzEXQJ2wQ.text: We went to Punjab because there was a wait at another Indian restaurant. We were seated promptly, but the table was a little small for our family. We ordered naan and I got chicken korma. There is only one circle of naan per serving, would have preferred more per serving. My chicken korma was excellent and just the right spice amount. Went well with rice. I enjoyed my food. My biggest complaint is that they charge you for your water, which comes in fancy bottles. Overall, a nice Indian restaurant that is centrally located.

-UrY1Jb63ylxwpT-RBzkcw.text: We went here for a dinner, on a weekday night. we expected a long wait, but were seated in 5 - 10 minutes. The service was prompt and courteous. We started off with vegetable samosas. For main course, we ordered the butter chicken and baigan as gravies, with rice and naan. It was one of the best Indian food I have had outside India. The butter chicken reminded me of food in local dhabas in Punjab :') we absolutely loved our dinner here!

xhgslubfr4V_wPw-PXyRFA.text: BEST indian food in London for sure (Coming from someone that grew up in India!) Flavors were authentic,the laccha parantha was on point and the service was friendly. The naan is one of the best I have had here in London. The quality of the food is as good or even better than dishoom and the setting is more authentic. I'm so glad to have found this place and will be a regular patron moving forward.

18695qbcS6RKSBdmGjeDvQ.text: Dined here for dinner during our recent trip to London. We actually initially tried to go to Dishoom down the street, but they had a 90 minute wait. When we asked the hostess at Dishoom about other good Indian restaurants in the area, she directed us to Punjab. We had some papadams and samosas for appetizer. My wife had the chicken tikka masala, and I had the lamb roganjosh. All simply fantastic. The following day, we trekked out to the famed Brick Lane for some more Indian food, but honestly, Punjab blows away the Indian food on Brick Lane. We will definitely make a return trip to this restaurant on our next trip to London.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

QWX1G49bDkyJRQzax6X9RA.text: We wanted to dine at another Indian restaurant but they had an hour and a half wait on a Saturday night. We walked to Punjab hoping to get dinner. We were fortunate to get a table for four.Ambiance: bare minimum, no great wall decorations. It is a series of small rooms.Service was good but they tried very hard to rush us through dinner. We fought them off. Manager was nice to take pics of the foursome outside.Food: was good, northern Indian. Our vegan friend ordered sweet and spicy pumpkin and a lentel dish, tarka dall. We also tried the prawn puri, spicy shrimp on a crispy puri. Very tasty. We also ordered 2 butter chicken entrees, a Punjab specialty. Delicious, tasty and very enjoyable.Overall, a nice experience.

qGRLe8_G-5TXZvZL6WOYDg.text: London is known as a mecca for delicious Indian food. You're more likely to find a place selling tikka masala than the traditional English fish and chips while visiting. Because of this, I knew I had to try some good Indian food when I went to London. I knew it would be the best Indian food I can get without actually being in India. While doing research about where to eat, my sister and I stumbled upon Punjab. Punjab is known as one of the best Indian restaurants London has to offer. On any given night, you will have to wait up to an hour to get seated. My sister and I arrived at a good time. A bit before 7pm, and with hardly any line. Since we were only a party of 2, we were seated in about 25 minutes. The restaurant is much larger than it looks on the outside. When you first walk in you think there is only one room for dining, but then you see that there is another room, and even more seating upstairs. My sister and I were directed to the upstairs seating. The ambiance of the restaurant is very homey. Punjab isn't trying to be fashionable, and it isn't trying to be the best in London. This is just some good Indian food without all the hoopla. When we sat down, we knew we wanted to get something to drink. After looking at the drinks menu we decided to get the India Grover's Sauvignon Blanc. We thought it would be interesting to try some Indian wine. The wine was wonderful and refreshing. When I came time to order appetizers, I knew I had to get samosas. I can't have an Indian meal without trying the samosas. The samosas offered at Punjab were some of the best I've had. We also split some garlic naan. I garlic naan was just as good as the samosas. For my meal I got the chicken tikka masala. Chicken tikka masala is my go to Indian dish, and it was renowned in London. I just had to get it. The chicken tikka masala was outstanding. I loved the tomato based sauce that the chicken comes in. My sister got the karahi paneer and thought it was great. There were no complaints from her about any of the dishes. The entire meal was absolutely perfection.The service was also really great. All the waiters and employees were very nice, and courteous. I also appreciate that we were only waiting outside for 25 minutes when it was very cold outside. My only issue with Punjab is that I don't live in London and I can't visit as often as I wish I could. Punjab is a restaurant I would recommend to people visiting London.

6fGs1sziaA8xtd0Gnt8MXQ.text: Good if you're feeling some Indian. Portions are on the smaller side, but the flavour is definitely there. Can be a line but it moves quick. Clothing can smell of spices after.

twKbCg2L5R7Nl03XGQuueA.text: So recently I've become an Indian food lover. London has a plethora of Indian food restaurants located on every corner. I wanted to find a good one for our first night in London. I looked at reviews online and I found Punjab. Upon entering it looked pretty busy for a Wednesday night they have it set up with almost a fine dining appeal. We were seated right away, which is always a plus in my book. I ordered the Strongbow cider to drink, which I was told was London's signature cider but I had never tried it before. To eat I ordered the garlic naan, the dahl, and the chicken tikka masala. Everything came out pretty quickly and it was all very good and I devoured it down but the stand out for me was the garlic naan I think it was the best I ever had. The service was friendly and attentive. I'd recommend this place to every fellow Indian food lover to try out.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

2NIwR6SwW957P4WM8_onrw.text: Ok... my favorite food is now Indian food. Indian food made from  this Pakistani family at this restaurant. WOW! That's enough said... spicy deliciousness that made my 10 year old ask for more and more.

HWa4r8d_GiqVyLO0i8kd9Q.text: The amritsari fish is ok. It's like fried fish with a lot of seasoning in the coating. The dipping sauce is very good though. Then we had butter chicken,  lamb madrus, and acharri gosht. They all taste good but similar. All dishes tend to be a bit salty. Lamb madrus is the best as the meat is most tender and the dish is most spicy. The garlic naan is perfect. The cheese naan tastes good but a bit oily. The service is pretty good in general.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Cheese naan
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Acharri gosh that
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken, lamb madrus, garlic naan

nPiKD-NDBaC47GbGoYIcIw.text: You must try it the fooooooood is so goodYou must try it the fooooooood is so goodYou must try it the fooooooood is so goodBut it's very spicy be careful

KrXvXF2P0BSnk3qwDwgIdQ.text: Visiting London for a couple of weeks and I found this place on Yelp. I love, love, love Indian food, so I put it on my list early on to stop at. When I got there the line was pretty big and I wasn't too sure how quickly it was going to move. I easily put in a takeaway order and my food was ready in 10 minutes. The owner of the establishment was incredibly nice and even threw a couple of jokes my way even though it seemed like a mad house inside. I wouldn't normally think of this, but this place really splurges on the takeaway packaging. The containers were sealed really well and the bag was sturdy and leakproof, in case the containers didn't work. The only reason why I mention this is because this made it really easy to go through the Underground on a Saturday night without getting curry all over the place.I ordered the Kadu Sabji-their signature pumpkin curry (because I'm American and Americans love all things pumpkin this time of year), plain rice, and garlic naan. The food was PERFECTION. The curry was nicely spiced and had whole chunks of pumpkin in it that were perfectly tender. The garlic naan was also something to write home about. Very soft and chewy. Though, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone expecting to get a kiss afterwards; I suppose unless you both eat it then it cancels out. The meal is definitely enough for 2, which means I have some left over to enjoy tomorrow!Go here, seriously.

kzL9eLgk-guR0qoWLbsgAQ.text: You never fail me Punjab...everything I eat when I go is perfect and fantastic...always worth the wait.  See you next time!

_SpfIKy768rNoDNRbcyvPg.text: I'm so glad we found this Covent Garden gem! This restaurant is in a tiny house, complete with a dumbwaiter for serving up the good to second floor (unique for us Americans).Walking up it looked like a club with a short line outside, but we got seated quickly and the service and food were fantastic. My husband was weary of Indian food but he was impressed with the chicken tikka masala, you can never go wrong there.I had the mutter paneer since I going for a milder dish. It was amazing! Make sure you get the Pilau cumin rice, best rice I've ever had anywhere. We miss Punjab, Indian food is terrible in Texas. :(

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Mutter paneer with basmati rice.

-5xE3RpU3Vc0XtYGdG-Bpw.text: Nice people but slow service, but incredibly delicious food. It's not necessarily cheap, but you get a good amount of food.

cfpJ9xiPCnEHOOwLurFI6g.text: Best service! I was so glad we found this establishment which not only have a great staff and amazing food, but so much history behind it. Everything we had was amazing. Definitely the spot I will be visiting when I'm back in The area.

Iddsylgg5-PjFOH8meOt0w.text: My coworkers and I spent a Saturday in London. I am huge fan of Indian food so it was a must for me. We searched Yelp for recommendations based on our location. The first spot, which I won't name, was more of an fusion restaurant with a limited menu. I knew it wasn't what I wanted because it didn't even smell like an Indian restaurant. Where was the aroma from the spices??? Fortunately, was able to convince my coworkers to look for another restaurant when we came across Punjab. I knew we were in the right spot the moment we walked in the door. We didn't order anything out the ordinary. We shared some chicken masala, Korma chicken, the chickpea dish (I don't believe it was called chana masala here), aloo gobi, rice and garlic naan. Everything was delicious and flavorful!!! One of my coworkers had dietary restrictions so we requested to speak to the manager. He was very attentive and accommodating in fulfilling his needs.  We ordered a bottle of Indian red wine called India Grover's LA Reserve.  It was excellent!! My coworkers told me they were glad I suggested finding another restaurant. I'd definitely go back and highly recommend the Punjab restaurant if you're looking for great  Indian food.

67x-rTckjJGDHiHI-JqN3A.text: Wanted a nice feed for our last night in London and could not fault a thing. One of the best service we have ever experienced, the staff were so friendly and on the ball... so attentive & quick! The food was amazing, butter chicken was to die for. Would definitely return!

dNyMejM8Jh5pniVfDKGqeA.text: The wifi password is "butterchicken" - how awesome is that - I had to laugh a little when the waiter told meThat said - in hindsight maybe I should have ordered that - can't go wrong with butter or chicken. The chicken tikka masala however was excellent so either or I'm sure both are good. I'll be honest - I found this spot after getting an hour and 45 minute wait at Dishoom - no thanks, nothing is worth almost a 2 hour wait. I found Punjab which is just a few streets down and I'm glad I did. No wait at all and seemingly more authentic. Of course I had to get the chicken tikka masala - the chicken was some of the best I've had at an Indian restaurant - super moist and tender - excellent. The curry base was great as well - it was a little on the lighter side - was hoping for more spices and robust flavor. It wasn't on the menu but I got mixed vegetables in a tomato based curry which was also very good. The dishes don't come with rice or naan so I ordered a white rice and garlic naan - the rice was just plain rice, should have ordered the one with the seeds. The garlic naan was good but not as good as the bullet naan which I added later on because of the pictures. It's not as spicy as you would think (bullet naan). The samosa was delicious - crunchy outside and soft pillowy potato mash inside.  I also got a masala chai tea - very good and spicy. One of the better meals I've had in London - great Punjab food! Portions are good, prices are on par for the city - total came out to about £43 for 2 ppl - appetizers, main courses, drinks.

zivLsWS8iQGflMgevoWywQ.text: This is the best place I've eaten in all of London.  It's not a trending setup but if you want food that is freaking great, just come here and stop messing around with everything else.  I love the Punjab Restaurant.

tmafyQK_1hywjpIG5MZXAQ.text: Best Indian food I ever had. From the service to food, everything was perfect! Many thanks to staff for providing exceptional service. Cheers!

sV4kyPYArZYFatgxry6WWA.text: The curry here was stellar.  Get the Chicken Tikka Masala with some rice and naan.  This place has been around for several decades and has a history of their delicious Chicken Tikka Masala.  It's in Covent Gardens, so it can get very crowded with tourists.  Don't come during peak hours and you will have an easy time finding seats and ordering.  Staff was very professional, but expect a gratuity tacked onto your bill.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom

0Tur0BRj_PO1dRLZF8FxRw.text: Great tasting food.  I had chicken tikka masala and sag paneer.  Lots of cheese in the paneer.  Food was spiced just right.  A bit expensive. They charge for rice aide dish.  Same dishes were $30 in NYC vs 30 pounds in U.K. .  I would highly recommend.  Line was fast less than 10 mins to be seated on a Friday night.  Lighting was awful.  Not a romantic place to take a date.

epi6UihkOeabA1kMf3p5pw.text: It's pretty good given the touristy crowd and location. Good food and attentive service.I had the khari ghost, which was good, but I did expect more of a kick to it. The lamb was also not completely tender.My friend got the butter chicken, a London staple, but I didn't get to try it.The garlic naan wasn't the best I've had. It has thin slices of garlic on top. I almost prefer it when it's finer pieces.Mango lassi was fine, but not very sweet. I think it's a good option if you're around central London. I liked the attentive service, but I'm not sure if I'd queue up for it. There's always a line out the door.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Khari ghost and butter chicken

-2LCZNiit6DWwGFRpVqrVA.text: Similar to some other reviewers here, I also wanted to go to Dishoom but the wait was so long and we really wanted Indian food so we yelped and found this place. I'm glad we did! The service was a bit rocky at first. "What you want? ... No you wait. Let me finish writing."  Uhhhh, what??  But then the waiter came back and was okay again. He served naan and garlic naan, both deliciously buttery and soft. We almost wished we saved the naan to eat with our meal instead but gobbled it up quickly. I loved my chicken Tikka special- the spices marinated in the meat perfecto with an abundance amount of sauce to mix with the rice. My husbands butter chicken was a little bit dry but he said the flavor was bold and spicy, just the way he expected it. We didn't have room for dessert unfortunately but a mango lassi was quite enough for me to leave happily and satisfied.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka special

Zuenjl3CABrkCgkLS2p3jw.text: I came to Punjab with a few friends for dinner and had not only a great experience but some phenomenal indian food.  We came on a Friday night and weren't sure how long the wait would be, but they were able to seat us within 5 minutes of arriving.  We started out with Samosas which were delicious and not at all greasy.   For our main course we shared chicken tikka, butter chicken, along with two standouts the bullett naan (spread with chopped fresh chilli and garlic) and the saag paneer which was beautifully spiced, not oily and tasted like fresh spinach.   Not only is the food good, but the service is also on point.  Our waiter was attentive and food arrived fast, hot and as ordered. A+

WlCGKmsONo17xe45mbzGvA.text: A few of my friends and I came to London for the day on our way back from Glasgow. We had been craving Indian and decided we would on our last night. With the help of Yelp we came across Punjab. It was the best Indian I have ever had, I am very loyal to one family owned one in my home town but this exceeded all expectations. The food was delicious, staff was friendly and helpful. We had ordered butter chicken, tandoori chicken and chicken tikka. No food was left! I would recommend making a reservation, we were lucky at 6 to get a table. Leaving though we saw the line out the door and along the restaurant! We met briefly with the owner who was extremely generous, he is part of the fourth generation running this restaurant. I know my next trip to London I will be making an other appearance! Thank you Punjab!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Our wonderful dinner! Every last drop was eaten! As well as vegitarian samosas to start

2KRJtaKK6oB4pehzW9uckw.text: Nice, authentic, home made flavors and feel to the food. Service was great and the ambience was cozy while feeling a bit dated, which is likely intentional. Overall, good experience and I would dine here again.

CELmIusjstZxzP-9_9wwSg.text: The food here is reallllly good. I had a little bit of everything because I was dining with a large group. They have several spicy dishes that are actually spicy enough to taste the difference. They have 4 or 5 different kinds of Naan. We were kind of loud due to the size of our party but the way waitstaff was as very understanding and patient with my group.

lOpSJ8tlCr4vWcIkCyAOrg.text: Excellent meal, great service, and only a 20 minute wait on a Friday night.

-xzNIKz5OzLBW5h4S7SLtw.text: This was our best meal in London! We were seated right away, service was fast and accurate, and most importantly the food was delicious. Chicken was slow cooked and fell apart. The menu has tons of options - so there's something for everyone. Great place!

Y2yEIMO47EAYvadYysrOMA.text: Delicious classic, light Indian dishes. Owner was so friendly and accommodating. We loved the carrot cake!

Q1XV-vE9_Jbn1jsLZ--tyQ.text: Solid and reliable spot for northern Indian cuisine - I always swing by at least once when I visit London. Both lentil dishes (yellow and black) are to die for. Love the methi gosht. Acharri and karahi dishes are also really good here.I get the feeling this place tones down the spiciness, so if you're a regular Indian eater and like spicy, make sure to ask staff to bump it up a bit. For example, the biryani dishes are not nearly spicy enough in their "standard" forms. Same with the jalfrezi - the basic flavor is very good, but could definitely use a bump up on the spiciness. That said, once you request spicy, it really does get spicy!Also, one of the better gajar halwa I've had. If you're a fan, make sure you save room. Even if you're not (and you don't hate carrots as a dessert), give it a try.Go at lunch to avoid the queues.

W-9rJgnwtR6FZk1FjGfxjA.text: SERVICE:The customer service here has some serious room for improvement. Between the moments I stepped in the restaurant to the moment I stepped out, each interaction with the staff felt very impersonal and unfriendly. If I say "Thank you" to a waiter, he would just stare at me and walk away. When it was time for me to pay, the person who inserted my credit card didn't even say a word. He just took the card, printed out a receipt, let me sign it, and walked away. Not a single eye contact. Wow. On top of all that, I'm required to give a "10 percent optional service" fee.PRICE:My total amounted to 14.25 GBP for Butter Chicken with rice. That's about $23.63 USD for those living in the states. People say that this place is cheap but I think it's expensive. I have been to other Indian restaurants where my total is about 11 GBP for the same or more portion of food. FOOD:I ordered the Butter Chicken and rice. The Butter Chicken included two pieces of chicken still on the bone. The gravy was good and had a slight spiciness to it. It goes well with rice or naan (not included in the price). If the customer service was better, I would have given this place a 3 out of 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. What is this "optional service" fee they included on my bill?
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. The rice costs  3.15!
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken. Two pieces with bones on.

3R8sKf7UTEG-wCTJ5Qg3Vw.text: I'm torn on this one. I feel like it was four star food but a three star experience. The ambiance was very strange and it was overpriced. The food was prepared very well, the naan was tasty, the jalfrezi was exactly the right amount of spicy. But I'm not accustomed to paying nearly £4 for rice or naan. If you're in the area and looking for an Indian place to duck into, this is a reliable option, though not the cheapest for what it  is. They give you lollies with your bill, which strangely really excited me. I will give the experience four stars overall on account of the incredible menu descriptions. In particular, check out the garlic naan description and the brief paragraph under the Lamb Curry heading.

yVlFzFsSKz2_Ysy9wRfcZw.text: I've walked past this place for years, always considering it as somewhere that was likely to be a tourist trap. Glad I finally considered it as had quite a delicious meal.I definitely recommend that you treat yourself to some Poppadoms as the green mystery sauce they come with is really tasty, whatever it is. I picked one of their 'traditional' options, I forget the name. It was really nice as were the chapathi and the chilli naan that accompanied it.All washed down with a pleasant Cava. Nice all round meal.

OTii_Juvge00-O9aY8R5Fg.text: I recently spent several days in London and wanted to eat some great Indian Food.  Looking at Yelp, Punjab seemed to be among the best so we decided to give it a try.  I won't say it's the worst Indian food I've ever eaten.  No, it's truly mediocre.  Dry, flavorless naan, poor quality rice, bland dal... everything you'd expect from a mediocre Indian restaurant.  I hope those who thought this was the "Best freaking Indian food" get a chance to eat at better places.  They can start a few blocks away, at Dishoon (it's not the best Indian food I've had, but definitely better).What makes Punjab one star, though, is the painfully strong odor of industrial strength soap that permeated ever nook and cranny of the place.  And after sitting in that horrid stench for an hour, it also permeated every nook and cranny of my skin and clothes.  The crazy thing is that this soapy smell seems to be the result of some towels that they give you at the end of the dinner, so you can clean your hands.  Or maybe, so you can get a chemical peel.  Either way, it was ridiculous and it totally ruined any chance we might have had to enjoy our meal.There are many more Indian restaurants in London.  Give some of them a try instead of this place.

JQXGNIaxKl9h6OjWD3SW5w.text: After attempting to make a trip to Little India, we made a quick decision to get back on the tube after our mission had failed (the area didn't look safe for women to walk around at night), so we re-routed and decided to go to Punjab which was our 2nd choice after reading reviews on Yelp. I'm glad that we did! We really enjoyed this quaint restaurant. Our friends raved about the Indian food in London, so eating at an Indian restaurant in London was a must on our to-eat list.{ORDER}* Chicken Tandoori - the best chicken tandoori! The meat literally melted in your mouth, it was oh-so-soft!* Butter Naan - after trying the regular naan, we decided to get the butter naan after seeing the table next to us ordering multiple baskets. We loved it! The butter made a huge difference and made the naan very moist.{DON'T ORDER}* Acharri Murgha Chicken Curry - we weren't impressed with the flavors and the pickled, tangy flavored was unexpected and ruined it for me.* Garlic Naan - too dry* None of their desserts - the wanna-be carrot cake came out super hot and did not resemble anything like American carrot cake. It felt like eating mushy carrots. The other dessert, not sure what it was called but it was in a white liquid form was a huge disaster. {ENVIRONMENT}* Great service* Quaint, clean restaurant* Located in Convent Garden (safe area, lots of retails)Punjab is UK's oldest Indian restaurant. That tells you something. They're doing something right!

photos.caption: Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. dessert, not good
Photo of Punjab - London, United Kingdom. dessert, not good

0stGx-d4ntsl7Qh32SgTNw.text: AMAZING!! Honesty some of the best Indian food I've yet to enjoy and in such an awesome location. First, we got lost and looped around from the Covent Garden station to Neal Street. Not really sure how that happened, but we loved walking around, it's such a funky and fun area. Finally we found it and were greeted by such a nice gentleman who kept joking around with my boyfriend and I. From the instant the door opened you could smell a variety of divine spices and we knew that this place was going to be great.We ordered chicken tikka massala, mixed chicken tandoori, a lamb curry I can't remember the name, plain naan, garlic naan, and white wine. SO GOOD! Will definitely be going back again. Great charm with good service and amazing food. Can't really get much better than that. It was a little pricier than expected but definitely worth it. Get there sooner than later or you'll be waiting outside because this place is so popular! I found the reviews here on yelp to be very helpful so thank you to you all who have enjoyed it and GO FOR IT for those of you who haven't!

_o8Sl1i2n6Ma2HJJ3nhqIQ.text: This was the most bland indian food we have ever eaten. Did they run out of spices tonight? The black daal, a recommended dish, just tasted like cream and beans. The paneer was too dense and bland. The stuffed eggplant was really good, but that was the only standout dish.

Ax6EiMTqacLu6Sc8yRqMPw.text: Delish. Fantastic garlic naan and chicken tiki masala. Overall good service. We dined on a Monday evening and sat upstairs. Quaint location

CJ2TeEEoFFfRllKUDf-Vxg.text: We were looking for British-style Indian food and this place was great. Prompt friendly service and really tasty food.This is a popular place but they hold aside some tables for walk-ins. I think if you go right at 8pm once all the theatergoers are gone you should be able to get a table.Rice and naan are a la carte but that seems to be the custom in London.

I4yb0N9rO3K9tTYCNJ_4YQ.text: We had a great expiriencie, for us it was the best indian food we had in London. We ordered the lamb karma, chiken tika masala, rice with cumin and the garlic naan. Not only the food was good but the service was great.

XTrk6WFKbdVybCzAtQaz-w.text: UK's oldest North Indian restaurant serves perhaps the oldest and driest Tandoori meat. I must say to the 4 of us visiting this restaurant this came as a shock as it has gotten tons of high marks. The seehk kebab was as dried as the chilly used in it, the Boti kebab was chewy as an old dried leather belt and the Tandoori chicken bland. Chicken tikka on the tandoori menu was the only piece of meat that was somewhat up to the standard. In general the tandoori menu felt not tender nor marinated long enough. Butter chicken or Acharri gosht are the items to go for, but then again they are no better than much less exclusive and less up-scaled Indian restaurants in London. The portions, and we are not Americans, were too small for the price asked. Basmati rice and nan are good but nowhere as good as the prices indicate  nor are they any better than other Indian restaurants. The service is okay but deceiving, they do love to accommodate but they also love to sell and perhaps the worst I seen in London happened here when spring water bottle could not be opened at the table because it was "slippery" but conveniently  was replaced in the bar with another bottle which had already been opened. This is one of the oldest tricks in the book and at these prices and with this reputation  it shouldn't take place here. For a party of four and only 2 bottle of beers being the only alcoholic beverages served the sum of 114£ is much more well spend somewhere ells than Punjab.

yYOCHjjYzlVZuGQ8GtbPVg.text: No need to wait 2 hours for Dishoom's. 5 minutes up the street. Excellent service. Started with Garlic naan and cheese naan- very good. Had chicken acchari muggers and chicken madras-both excellent. Chicken tandoori was moist.

vIQpFgt9JRMBVnOVQNL8RA.text: Delicious, authentic and priced right! We ordered samosas, tikka masala, methi Murgha (subtle with a nice kick at the end), and of course butter naan and Keema naan.  It's location in Coventry Garden is ideal for a great meal.

IPhgLFz1_U_AN_lffkkCug.text: Butter chicken was my best meal in London two years ago. Enjoyed their variety of beers as well. The neighborhood is fun to walk and offers several great options. This is one of the best.

Vi_XQsOxiT-q96J5ET-aqQ.text: Pick anything on the menu and it will be the best Indian food you have ever had. Well worth waiting in line for a table. If you don't eat at Punjab while in London, you are doing yourself a disservice.

KlnL5jfYRjkxWphxMzX8uA.text: Absolutely delicious!!! Must go to for Indian food. The cheese naan and chicken curry is absolutely delicious!

7tLd19cr4pvCHbk5cqvN_w.text: I do not recommend this place. it is very small and one the starters came I found three little hairs. they took the dish away and remove the hairs. Again I would not recommend.

cd2xjFdBHMowUH8zGSG-AQ.text: Dependable Indian in the heart of the West End. I've been going here for years and the place is almost always packed. Its good solid indian food and very quick service. The decor won't win any awards and its not fancy. But sometimes you want tried and true.

6PA-A_RD1EQUEtcfbj6OWA.text: nice Indian/Pakistani food restaurant in London.  All the food were great. Good service and good ambience.
